text: A senior manager at the trust, which now has 424 inpatients with Covid, said: “London Gold call has indicated that this position is expected to escalate for the next two weeks with 4 January potentially the zenith of critical care capacity needed.” The Independent Sage committee of scientific and medical experts is urging ministers to instigate an immediate further UK-wide lockdown to try to prevent an imminent “catastrophe”. Any delay will result in the deaths of tens of thousands of people who could otherwise have been saved, it said. The committee, headed by the government’s former chief scientific adviser Sir David King, also said schools should remain shut until the start of February because their planned reopening from next week risked worsening the already fast-deteriorating situation, especially given the new variant that has emerged that is more transmissable and appears to be more readily infect under-18s. “Things are as bad as they have ever been. The frightening thing is that they are going to continue to get worse. Action is needed now to avoid the collapse of the NHS in a few weeks. It is that serious”, said Christina Pagel, a member of Independent Sage and professor of operational research at University College London NHS Providers, which represents hospital trusts in England, also demanded more robust action. Referring to the Tiers review, Saffron Cordery, its deputy chief executive, said: “It will require difficult decisions, moving millions more people to the highest level.” A toughening is needed urgently because pressures on the NHS in some places is “rising at an unsustainable rate”, she said. Keir Starmer sounded a stark warning about the crisis facing the NHS and schools over the next month. The Labour leader told the Guardian that the UK was “staring down the barrel” of a third lockdown in January. Dr Claudia Paoloni, a consultant anaesthetist in the NHS and president of the HCSA, said ICU staff may end up having to in effect ration who received care that could help them survive. “Our NHS just doesn’t have the beds to cope. Some areas will be overwhelmed in days. If ventilation capacity is exceeded, horrendous choices will have to be made over those who live and die.

text: “The choices will be things like: which patients to admit to intensive care and which can only have limited care, excluding intensive care; how long to keep trying all stops maximum therapy on someone who appears to be making little progress when someone else comes into the intensive care unit and needs a haemodialysis machine when there are only limited numbers of machines; and who gets an intensive care or ventilatory support bed if all are being used,” she said. text: Throughout the pandemic, technology has been saving our jobs and our sanity – but in Barcelona the lockdowns have led to the revival of one of humanity’s simplest and most enduring inventions: the book. The city’s booksellers are reporting a boom in sales and, against all odds, new bookshops have opened. The latest of the new crop of shops is the Llibreria Byron, launched by the small academic publisher Huygens, which opened in November in the Sant Antoni area of the city. “We’d been planning this for three years and were set to open in April, but that obviously wasn’t possible,” said Mariana Sarrias, the shop’s co-owner. “After nine months of uncertainty and with everything that, as a small business, we had invested, it was very worrying,” she said, adding that they chose the name Byron “because he was romantic and also quite transgressive”. “The day we finally opened in November there was a queue of people waiting to get in. There wasn’t room for everyone. It was really quite moving. Since then people come every day. I don’t know if it’s out of solidarity or because the bookshop is something the barrio [suburb] lacked.” “The pandemic has made people aware of the need to support their local bookshop,” said Maria Carme Ferrer, president of the Catalan booksellers’ association. “Bookshops are local cultural centres.” Sarrias says that as publishers they had already noticed an increase in orders during lockdown. “Maybe people ran out of things to watch on Netflix,” she said, or perhaps, as they were forced into isolation, people realised that books are good company. And yet only recently the book business looked doomed. In 2013 the Catalonia bookshop, a magnet for the city’s readers since 1924, was forced to close and was replaced by a McDonald’s. That same year Canuda, the labyrinthine secondhand bookshop that was the inspiration behind the “cemetery of forgotten books” in Carlos Ruiz Zafón’s bestselling The Shadow of the Wind, also went out of business. It is now a branch of fashion chain Mango.
b2_text:
During the pandemic, technology helped us keep working and stay calm. But in Barcelona, the lockdowns made something old popular again: books.

Bookstores in the city are selling more books. Some new bookstores have even opened.

One of these new stores is called Llibreria Byron. It was started by a small company that publishes books for schools. It opened in November in the Sant Antoni area.

Mariana Sarrias is one of the owners of the store. She said they planned to open in April, but they could not because of the pandemic.

She said they were worried after waiting nine months. They had spent a lot of money on the store. They named the store Byron because he was a romantic and different person.

When they finally opened in November, many people were waiting outside. The store was too small for everyone. Mariana said it was very emotional. People come to the store every day. She does not know if it is to support them or because the area needed a bookstore.

Maria Carme Ferrer is the head of the booksellers' group in Catalonia. She said the pandemic made people want to help their local bookstores. She said bookstores are important places for culture in the community.

Mariana said that her publishing company saw more orders during the lockdown. Maybe people got tired of watching Netflix. Or maybe people felt lonely and realized books are good friends.

Not long ago, it seemed like bookstores would disappear. In 2013, a famous bookstore called Catalonia closed. It had been open since 1924. A McDonald's restaurant replaced it.

In the same year, Canuda, a big used bookstore, also closed. It inspired the book "The Shadow of the Wind" by Carlos Ruiz Zafón. Now, a Mango clothing store is in its place.

text: Perhaps this sudden revival is only to be expected in a city that is the capital of the Spanish publishing trade and where the Catalans’ love of books is celebrated every year on 23 April, birthday of the patron saint, Sant Jordi (St George), and coincidentally Shakespeare’s birthday. On this day people exchange gifts of books and roses and the streets are lined with impromptu book stalls. The pandemic meant that Sant Jordi was effectively cancelled this year and it’s likely to be a small-scale affair in 2021, according to Lluís Morral, manager of Laie, perhaps the city’s best-loved bookshop. Morral says sales have definitely increased during lockdown, especially among the classics rather than recent bestsellers. “A lot of people have come back to reading and they aren’t looking for the latest publication but are more catching up on books they meant to read a few years ago,” he said. “A lot of people buy books on Sant Jordi but don’t read them. Now they realise they have all these books at home and they’ve started reading them.” He agrees with Sarrias that isolation has led people to discover – or remember – that books are very companionable. “I can’t speak for everyone, but among my acquaintances a lot of people reached saturation point watching TV series,” Morral said. Both Laie and Byron are bookshop-cafes with quiet spaces for reading, a much-needed refuge in what is officially Europe’s noisiest city. Two other new outlets, Ona, which sells books only in Catalan, and Finestres, due to open in the spring, have also set themselves up as places to meet and read as well as to buy books. Both have been financed by local philanthropists and, while he wishes them well, Morral knows that like all bookshops these relative minnows will have a battle on their hands to compete with Amazon. “What we [independent bookshops] can offer is a personal service and an understanding of what book you’ve bought and what you might also enjoy, rather than have an algorithm tell you what to read next,” he said.
b2_text:
Maybe this good news is not surprising. This city is the center for selling books in Spain. The people of Catalonia love books. They celebrate this every year on April 23rd. This is the day of Saint George, their special saint. It is also Shakespeare's birthday. On this day, people give each other books and roses. The streets are full of small book stands.

This year, the celebration could not happen because of the sickness. It will probably be small in 2021 too. This is according to Lluís Morral. He manages Laie, a very popular bookstore in the city.

Morral says that they sold more books when people stayed home. People bought old, famous books more than new, popular ones. He said that many people started reading again. They did not want the newest books. They wanted to read books they planned to read before. Many people buy books on Saint George's day, but they don't read them. Now they know they have these books at home. So, they started to read them.

He agrees that being alone made people see that books are good friends. Morral said that many people got tired of watching TV.

Laie and Byron are both bookstores and cafes. They have quiet places to read. This is important because this city is known as the loudest in Europe. Two new stores are also opening. Ona sells books only in the Catalan language. Finestres will open in the spring. They want to be places where people can meet, read, and buy books. Local people who give money helped them start.

Morral hopes they do well. But he knows it will be hard for them. They will have to compete with Amazon, like all bookstores. He said that small bookstores can give personal help. They understand what books you like. They can suggest what you might enjoy reading next. This is better than a computer telling you what to read.

text: The French government has been accused of pandering to anti-vaxxers after figures showed that only a few hundred people had received a jab several days after the country’s vaccine programme began. Health officials said France is setting out for “a marathon, not a sprint” and that they are going slowly, in part, because of high levels of public scepticism about the vaccine. Only around 40% of people in France have said they are willing to be vaccinated, according to a recent poll. The figure has dropped since October, when just over half of French people said they were happy to be vaccinated. Willingness to have the vaccine is reportedly 77% in Britain and 69% in the US. France started administering the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine on Sunday, beginning with staff and residents in care homes and those considered at risk of developing severe symptoms of the virus. It is the only country insisting that those offered the vaccine give their written consent after being informed of possible contraindications. However, fewer than 100 people were vaccinated in the first three days. By Wednesday evening, only 332 people had received the vaccine, according to health ministry officials. The ministry has said the aim is to vaccinate 1 million elderly and at-risk people in January, requiring more than 31,200 vaccinations every day. The health minister, Olivier Véran, admitted that France was vaccinating more slowly than other countries and suggested this was a deliberate policy to enable an information campaign rather than the result of a lack of vaccines or a logistical failure. “We have the same number of vaccine doses as our German neighbours, we have the same aims and we will have the same results,” Véran told French television. “It’s taking a while to get off the ground … I don’t confuse speed with haste,” he added. The president, Emmanuel Macron, and ministers have promised the vaccine will not be obligatory and officials have assured the public there will be no list compiled of those who refuse to have the Covid-19 jab. However, Macron said people should be guided by “reason and science”. “The vaccine is not obligatory. Have confidence in our scientists and doctors,” he said.
b2_text:
The French government is getting criticism. Some people think they are trying to please people who don't want vaccines.

Recently, France started giving out vaccines. But only a few hundred people got the vaccine in the first few days.

Health workers in France said they are moving slowly. They said it is like a long race, not a fast one. They are going slowly because many people in France are unsure about the vaccine.

A recent survey said that only about 40% of people in France want to get the vaccine. This number was higher in October. Back then, a little more than half of French people wanted the vaccine.

In Britain, 77% of people are willing to get the vaccine. In the US, 69% of people are willing.

France started giving the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine on Sunday. They started with workers and people living in care homes. They also gave it to people who are likely to get very sick from the virus.

France is different from other countries. They want people to write down that they agree to get the vaccine. This is after they learn about possible problems with the vaccine.

But in the first three days, less than 100 people got the vaccine. By Wednesday evening, health officials said only 332 people had gotten the vaccine.

The health ministry said they want to give the vaccine to 1 million old and at-risk people in January. This means they need to give more than 31,200 vaccines every day.

The health minister, Olivier Véran, said France is giving vaccines slower than other countries. He said this is on purpose. He wants to give people information about the vaccine first. It is not because they don't have enough vaccines or because there are problems with getting the vaccines to people.

Véran said they have the same number of vaccines as Germany. He said they have the same goals and will get the same results.

Véran said it is taking some time to start. He also said that being fast is not the same as being rushed.

The president of France, Emmanuel Macron, and his ministers said the vaccine will not be required. Officials said they will not make a list of people who do not want the vaccine.

But Macron said people should listen to "reason and science."

Macron said the vaccine is not required. He said people should trust the scientists and doctors.

text: In his new year address on Thursday, Macron vowed to avoid “unjustifiable delays” to vaccinations but also struck a defensive note, saying he would let “no one play with the safety” of the campaign. Axel Kahn, a leading geneticist and head of the National League Against Cancer, told Europe 1 radio that France’s vaccine strategy was wrong. “It is not suited to a situation that is so dangerous,” he said. Philippe Juvin, head of the casualty ward at the Georges-Pompidou hospital in Paris, agreed. “As an individual, I would like to be vaccinated to set an example and show people that we don’t die from the vaccine, we die from Covid. And when we don’t die, we can get severe forms of it that are very disabling,” Juvin told CNews television. Opposition leaders said the slowness of the vaccination programme made France the “dunce” of Europe. Damien Abad, leader of the centre-right opposition Les Républicains in the Assemblée Nationale, demanded an urgent meeting with the health minister. In a letter, other opposition critics wrote: “Mass vaccination is the ultimate means of seeing our country emerge from the damaging economic situation caused by the health crisis. Yet France is vaccinating 10,000 times slower than the UK.” They added: “France cannot be one of the last countries to get vaccinated and yet that’s the picture we’re facing today.” Alain Fischer, the government official overseeing France’s vaccination programme, told Europe 1 the country had chosen to prioritise the elderly and vulnerable, as opposed to health professionals, as in other countries. “There is no good or bad choice … These are small details that will seem ridiculous in two or three months,” he said. Critics say this hesitation is feeding conspiracy theories and anti-vaxxer sentiment. Nathan Peiffer-Smadja, an infection specialist at Paris’s Bichat hospital, said the scientific data was clear. “The vaccine is safe and efficient. Like many of my colleagues, I think we should be giving the vaccines quicker in order to control the epidemic more rapidly. At the rate we’re going, we’ll still be in lockdown in 2022,” he tweeted.
b2_text:
On Thursday, President Macron spoke about vaccines for the new year. He said vaccinations must happen quickly. But he also said safety is most important. He will not let anyone risk safety.

Axel Kahn is a scientist. He leads a group against cancer. He said France's plan for vaccines is not good. He thinks it is not right for a dangerous time.

Philippe Juvin works at a hospital in Paris. He agrees with Kahn. Juvin wants to get the vaccine himself. He wants to show people it is safe. He wants to show that people die from COVID, not the vaccine. He said COVID can make people very sick.

Some leaders disagree with Macron. They said France is vaccinating people too slowly. They think France is the worst in Europe.

Damien Abad is a leader in the government. He wants to talk to the health minister soon. Other leaders wrote a letter. They said vaccines are important for the economy. They said France is vaccinating much slower than the UK. They said France might be one of the last countries to finish vaccinations.

Alain Fischer is in charge of the vaccine program in France. He said France is giving vaccines to old and sick people first. Other countries are giving them to doctors and nurses first. Fischer said there is no right or wrong way. He thinks it will not matter in a few months.

Some people think the slow start is bad. They think it makes people not trust the vaccine.

Nathan Peiffer-Smadja is a doctor in Paris. He said the vaccine is safe and works well. He thinks France should give vaccines faster. He said if they go slowly, they might be in lockdown next year too.

text: France reported 26,457 new confirmed cases on Wednesday in 24 hours, but attributed the rise to increased testing. There were 304 deaths in hospital. The number of positive tests remains low, at 2.9%.
b2_text:
Here is the rewritten text, simplified for CEFR B2 level:

France said they found 26,457 new cases of the virus on Wednesday. This was in one day. They think the number is higher because they are testing more people.

304 people died in the hospital. These people had the virus.

The number of tests that came back positive is still low. It is only 2.9%. This means not many people who get tested actually have the virus.

text: Officials in Gibraltar are making daily patrols of the territory’s Barbary macaque population amid fears that the iconic monkeys could be vulnerable to the coronavirus. The British overseas territory has been relatively spared by the virus, documenting about 1,500 confirmed cases and six deaths. But as governments around the world wrestle with how to keep the coronavirus at bay, authorities in the Rock are grappling with an additional worry: how to shield Europe’s only wild monkey population from the virus. “We knew it from day one,” said Mark Pizarro, the veterinary officer responsible for the care of Gibraltar’s macaque population. “It’s logical. You have a virus that lives in primates like us, then it’s going to always be a risk to other primates.” Earlier this year the government sought to crack down on interactions with the macaques, which rank among the territory’s top tourist attractions. A new law, passed in August, made it an offence to touch or interfere with the monkeys, adding to existing legislation that sets out hefty fines for feeding them. “Macaques are prone to succumb to human disease,” the government noted in a statement announcing the new law. “This has been seen in the past when our macaques have for example contracted hepatitis A.” Believed to have been living on the Rock since the Moorish occupation of the Iberian peninsula, local folklore has it that as long as the macaques roam Gibraltar, the territory will remain under British rule. Officials have at times gone to remarkable lengths to protect the population; during the second world war, Winston Churchill gave an order to bolster their dwindling numbers with macaques from north Africa. Today the population stands at about 220 macaques. Coronavirus tests carried out in recent months on four – all of which died of other causes, such as road traffic accidents – came back negative, reinforcing the government’s view that the virus poses only a mild risk to the macaques. But concerns grew again in November after Denmark announced plans to cull more than 15 million mink over fears that new mutations discovered in the animals could undermine the effectiveness of Covid-19 vaccines.
b2_text:
Officials in Gibraltar are checking on the monkeys every day. These monkeys are called Barbary macaques. People worry that the monkeys could get the coronavirus.

Gibraltar is a British place. Not many people there have gotten sick. About 1,500 people had the virus, and six people died.

Governments all over the world are trying to stop the virus. In Gibraltar, the government has another problem. They need to protect the monkeys from the virus. These monkeys are the only wild monkeys in Europe.

Mark Pizarro takes care of the monkeys. He said they knew about this problem from the start. He said that humans and monkeys are similar. If humans can get the virus, monkeys can too.

Earlier this year, the government made new rules. They wanted people to stop touching the monkeys. The monkeys are a popular place for tourists to visit.

In August, they made a new law. It said you cannot touch or bother the monkeys. Before this law, it was already against the rules to feed them. If you fed them, you had to pay a lot of money.

The government said that monkeys can get sick from humans. They said that the monkeys got sick with hepatitis A before.

People think the monkeys have lived in Gibraltar for a long time. They say that as long as the monkeys are there, Gibraltar will stay British.

Sometimes, people have tried very hard to protect the monkeys. During the war, Winston Churchill ordered more monkeys to come from Africa. He wanted to make sure there were enough monkeys.

Now, there are about 220 monkeys.

Recently, they tested four monkeys for the virus. The monkeys had died because of other things, like getting hit by cars. The tests showed that they did not have the coronavirus. This made the government think that the virus is not a big danger to the monkeys.

But in November, people got worried again. Denmark said they would kill many mink because of the virus. The virus changed in the mink, and people worried that the vaccines might not work.

text: The Gibraltar government described the Danish announcement as “particularly worrying” given that it suggested that the macaques, should they contract the virus, could become a source of infection for humans and potentially pass on mutations that could jeopardise vaccination efforts. Pizarro said his team of six had been monitoring the macaques on a daily basis. So far they have seen little sign of infection. What their patrols have made clear, however, is that the pandemic – and specifically the resulting plunge in tourism – has been a boon to the macaques. “Their behaviour in a lot of cases has reverted to normal. They interact with themselves, they forage naturally, they spend more time grooming each other, there’s less aggression between the macaques,” said Pizarro. “So there is a lot of positive spin from decreased human contact.”
b2_text:
Here is the rewritten text, simplified to CEFR B2 level:

The government in Gibraltar is worried. Denmark said something that made them anxious. Denmark thinks the monkeys could get the virus. If the monkeys get sick, they could give the virus to people. The virus could also change in the monkeys. This could make the vaccines not work as well.

Pizarro said he has a team. The team has six people. They watch the monkeys every day. They have not seen many signs of the virus in the monkeys.

But the team has seen something else. The pandemic changed things for the monkeys. Less tourism is good for them. Pizarro said the monkeys are acting normal again. They play with each other. They look for food in a natural way. They clean each other more often. They fight less. He said less contact with people is good for the monkeys.

text: Jonathan Pollard, a former US Navy analyst who served three decades in prison for leaking thousands of classified documents to Israel, has arrived in Tel Aviv after being released from parole. Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, greeted Pollard and his wife, Esther, as they walked down the steps from a private jet, footage distributed by the prime minister’s office showed. The couple, both Orthodox Jews, removed their masks and kissed the ground before greeting Netanyahu. “We are ecstatic to be home at last after 35 years,” said Pollard, who was born in the US but was granted Israeli citizenship during his imprisonment. “No one could be prouder of this country or this leader than we are.” After saying a Hebrew prayer of thanksgiving for the liberation of prisoners, Netanyahu presented Pollard, 66, with Israeli identification documents. “Welcome home,” the prime minister said. Having been arrested by FBI agents in 1985 after unsuccessfully seeking refuge at the Israeli embassy in Washington, Pollard was sentenced to life in prison in 1987. The initial shock between the US and its close ally, and Pollard’s continued imprisonment, has long strained relations between the two countries. Netanyahu has pushed for Pollard’s release for decades. During the leader’s first term in the late 1990s, Pollard was granted Israeli citizenship. However, repeated previous attempts to persuade US presidents to grant Pollard clemency have failed. Pollard’s release from parole last month was the latest in a series of gestures by the departing Trump administration towards Netanyahu’s government. In a phone call last month, Netanyahu said to Pollard: “When are we going to see you here? We’re waiting for you.” Pollard’s lawyer, Eliot Lauer, told the Times of Israel that his arrival was “a dream realised after 35 very difficult years”. The couple are expected to enter several days of quarantine, which is compulsory for all returning Israelis as a measure to guard against the spread of coronavirus.
b2_text:
Jonathan Pollard used to work for the US Navy. He gave secret US documents to Israel. He was in prison for 30 years. After prison, he was on parole. Now, he has arrived in Tel Aviv. Tel Aviv is a city in Israel.

Benjamin Netanyahu is the leader of Israel. He met Pollard and his wife, Esther. They came off a private plane. The Prime Minister's office showed a video of this.

Pollard and his wife are Jewish. They took off their masks. They kissed the ground. Then, they said hello to Netanyahu.

Pollard said they were very happy to be home after 35 years. He was born in the US. But he became an Israeli citizen while in prison. He said he was proud of Israel and its leader.

Netanyahu said a prayer. It was a prayer to thank God for freeing prisoners. Then, Netanyahu gave Pollard Israeli ID papers. He said, "Welcome home."

In 1985, the FBI arrested Pollard. He tried to hide in the Israeli embassy in Washington, but it didn't work. In 1987, he was sentenced to life in prison.

This situation caused problems between the US and Israel. They are usually good friends. Pollard being in prison made things difficult. Netanyahu wanted Pollard to be released for many years.

In the 1990s, Pollard became an Israeli citizen. Netanyahu tried many times to get US presidents to let Pollard go. But it didn't work.

Pollard was released from parole last month. This was one of the last things the Trump government did for Netanyahu.

Netanyahu called Pollard last month. He asked when Pollard would come to Israel. He said they were waiting for him.

Pollard's lawyer said it was a dream come true after 35 hard years.

Pollard and his wife must stay in quarantine for a few days. This is required for all people coming back to Israel. It is to protect against the coronavirus.

text: Campaigners are calling for social housing providers to put lives above profits following an Observer report on a black tenant who was left homeless after a racist campaign by neighbours. Former social housing chiefs, Lord Victor Adebowale, Aman Dalvi, Lord Geoffrey Filkin and Barry Simons have signed an open letter to the National Housing Federation highlighting wider failings to protect victims of racial harassment. The letter demands an urgent review of social housing policy to ensure that perpetrators of racial harassment are evicted, or their victims rehoused as a priority. The group acted after reading of the plight of Laura Tate (not her real name) who has been homeless for five years after fleeing her flat following death threats. Her housing provider, London and Quadrant (L&Q), refused to evict her abusers, despite their convictions for racially aggravated harassment and public order offences, and it failed to rehouse Tate. Last week a judge awarded her £31,000 in compensation after she sued L&Q for negligence. The Observer had also reported the case of another black tenant who has spent two years in a women’s refuge after fleeing an abusive ex-partner. L&Q failed to rehouse her without concrete evidence that she was endangered. “These are not isolated cases,” said the Labour peer Lord Filkin. “Board members and managers have a fundamental duty to ensure that tenants can live peacefully in their homes; there is more they need to do to ensure this duty is fulfilled.” L&Q, which houses 250,000 people in more than 105,000 homes across the south-east, has promised an independent review on how it handles abuse cases following the Observer investigation. In a statement on its website it admitted that there were lessons to be learned and said that it has a zero-tolerance policy on discrimination of any kind. The National Housing Federation, which represents housing associations, said that it would be glad to meet the letter’s signatories to discuss reforms. “We know that as a sector we can and must do better,” said chief executive Kate Henderson.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, simplified for a B2 level reader:

Some people are asking social housing companies to care more about people's lives than making money. This comes after a report in a newspaper called the Observer. The report was about a Black woman who lost her home. This happened because her neighbors were racist towards her.

Some important people who used to work in social housing have written a letter. These people are Lord Victor Adebowale, Aman Dalvi, Lord Geoffrey Filkin, and Barry Simons. They sent the letter to the National Housing Federation. They say that social housing companies need to do better at protecting people from racism.

The letter asks for a quick change in social housing rules. The rules should make sure that people who are racist are evicted from their homes. Or, the people who are being harassed should be given new homes first.

This group wrote the letter after reading about Laura Tate (not her real name). She has been homeless for five years. She left her home because people threatened to kill her.

The company that owned her home is called London and Quadrant (L&Q). They did not evict the people who were being racist. Even though those people were found guilty of crimes related to racism and public disorder, L&Q did not help Laura find a new home.

Last week, a judge gave Laura £31,000. This was because she sued L&Q for not taking care of her.

The Observer newspaper also wrote about another Black woman. She lived in a women's shelter for two years. She ran away from her ex-partner who was abusive. L&Q did not help her find a new home because she did not have enough proof that she was in danger.

Lord Filkin said that these are not the only cases like this. He said that the people in charge of social housing must make sure that tenants can live safely in their homes. He thinks they need to do more to make this happen.

L&Q gives homes to 250,000 people in the south-east of England. They have said they will check how they handle cases of abuse. This is because of the Observer's report.

L&Q said on their website that they can learn from these cases. They also said they do not allow any kind of discrimination.

The National Housing Federation represents social housing companies. They said they are happy to meet with the people who wrote the letter to talk about changes. Kate Henderson, who is in charge of the Federation, said that they know they can do better.

text: “Last month we launched our Equality, Diversity and Inclusion Insight report, which provided evidence of the change we need to deliver. “This, and our new code of governance, emphasise the importance of housing association boards and staff reflecting the diversity of the communities they serve and ensuring the sector is always working to strengthen relationships with residents.”
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, aiming for CEFR B2 level:

Last month, we shared our new report. It is about equality, diversity, and inclusion. The report shows what changes we need to make.

This report and our new rules about how we work are important. They show why housing groups must have boards and staff that look like the people in their communities.

This means the people who work for housing groups should be as diverse as the people who live there. Also, the housing sector must always try to improve its relationship with the people who live in the houses. We want to make these relationships stronger.

text: The ruthless campaign by the Chinese government to extinguish all memories of the massacre at Tiananmen Square has now resulted in the removal of the sculpture from the campus of the University of Hong Kong (Outcry as memorial to Tiananmen Square victims removed from Hong Kong University, 23 December). Since many of the countless victims were students, it is appropriate for universities elsewhere to ensure that their bravery and martyrdom is not eradicated from history. University student unions in the UK, not least at those institutions with many Chinese students, should keep their memory alive by renaming their building or part of it. This is what several did following the murder by the authorities of the black South African anti-apartheid student activist Steve Biko. The Steve Biko Bar at Bradford University closed in 2005 but the student union building at Manchester University (which has the largest student union in the UK) is still named after him. No doubt the chancellor of Oxford University, Chris Patten – who was the last British governor of Hong Kong – will be sympathetic. There is also plenty of space for the erection of a memorial near the Chinese embassy in central London. Dr Peter van den Dungen Ex-Bradford University lecturer, Halifax, West Yorkshire • Have an opinion on anything you’ve read in the Guardian today? Please email us your letter and it will be considered for publication.
b2_text:
The Chinese government is trying to make people forget what happened at Tiananmen Square. They are doing bad things to erase the memory. They even took away a statue from a university in Hong Kong.

Many students died at Tiananmen Square. So, universities in other countries should remember them. They should not let their bravery be forgotten.

Student groups in the UK should remember these students. This is especially true for universities with many Chinese students. They could rename a building or part of a building after them.

Some universities did this for Steve Biko. He was a student who fought against bad rules in South Africa. The government killed him. Bradford University used to have a bar named after him. Manchester University still has a building named after him.

Chris Patten is the head of Oxford University. He used to be in charge of Hong Kong. He will probably agree that it is important to remember the students.

There is also space for a memorial in London. It could be near the Chinese embassy.

Dr. Peter van den Dungen
Former lecturer at Bradford University
Halifax, West Yorkshire

If you want to share your opinion about something you read in the Guardian, send them a letter by email. They might publish it.

text: Confused anti-vaccine protesters entered a test-and-trace centre in Milton Keynes on Wednesday, appearing to believe it was a coronavirus vaccine centre, where they were filmed shouting abuse at staff and appearing to steal equipment. Video shared on social media showed the group of several dozen activists, led by former Ukip candidate Jeff Wyatt, walking through the facility holding signs encouraging people not to get vaccinated and criticising the BBC. Wyatt, a former deputy leader of the far-right For Britain Movement, addressed crowds at a rally held before the storming of the Covid-19 testing site, where he claimed there are “millions” of like-minded anti-vaccine activists who have “woken up”. Piers Corbyn, a prominent anti-lockdown protester and brother of the former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, could not be seen in the footage but was pictured attending other stops during the so-called Freedom Rally including an invasion of the Milton Keynes Theatre. Protesters were filmed walking towards the NHS test-and-trace centre while a man on a loudspeaker claims that it is where the “vaccine rollout” is taking place as activists walk by a sign that reads “Testing”. Other demonstrators are heard shouting “disgrace” and “shame on you” as staff appear to run away and take shelter in offices. In several videos, a woman is seen unfurling a sign that reads “Reclaim NHS, End Jab” in one of the cabins before taking a large box containing what appears to be testing equipment and papers. She is seen unmasked and smiling at the cameras as she leaves the testing site. Thames Valley police said they were aware of an anti-vaccination protest that took place in central Milton Keynes on Wednesday afternoon. In a statement, the police said: “Where criminal offences have been disclosed, we will take swift action and bring offenders to justice. “If anyone has any information or wishes to report they can do by calling 101 or online quoting reference 604 29/12/2021.” The actions of the anti-vaccine protesters at the test-and-trace centre were described as “disgraceful” and faced widespread criticism by MPs.
b2_text:
Some people who don't want vaccines were confused. They went to a test center in Milton Keynes on Wednesday.

They thought it was a place to get vaccines. But it was a place for COVID-19 tests.

People filmed them shouting at the workers. It looked like they were stealing things.

A video was shared online. It showed a group of people with signs. The signs said not to get the vaccine. They also criticized the BBC.

Jeff Wyatt was leading the group. He used to work for a political party. He said many people don't want vaccines. He said they have "woken up."

Piers Corbyn was also there. He is against lockdowns. He is the brother of Jeremy Corbyn. Jeremy used to lead the Labour party.

Piers Corbyn was at other places during the day. The group also went to a theater.

The video showed the group walking to the test center. A man said on a speaker that they give vaccines there. But the sign said "Testing."

Some people shouted "disgrace" and "shame on you." The workers ran away and hid.

A woman took a sign that said "Reclaim NHS, End Jab." She took a big box with test things and papers. She smiled at the camera. She was not wearing a mask.

The police know about the protest. It happened in Milton Keynes on Wednesday.

The police said they will take action if crimes happened. They will punish the people who did wrong.

The police asked people to call them if they have information. The phone number is 101. You can also report it online. Use the number 604 29/12/2021.

People said the protesters' actions were bad. Many politicians criticized them.

text: The local Tory MP Ben Everitt described the protesters as “dickheads” and urged anyone with information to contact police. Nick Thomas-Symonds, shadow secretary of state for international trade, described the protest as “dreadful”, at a site where “NHS staff are working over the festive season to help others”. He urged anyone with information to pass this on to Thames Valley police. Former health secretary Matt Hancock criticised the activists’ “appalling behaviour”. The Conservative MP for Rutland and Melton, Alicia Kearns, described the scenes as “shameful, self-aggrandising nonsense”. Helen Morgan, Liberal Democrat MP for North Shropshire, said the group’s actions were “totally unacceptable”. Stella Creasy, Labour MP for Walthamstow, said the scenes were “disgraceful”. “For months now we have been warning need legislation to tackle those who harass others seeking healthcare. Government promised to act weeks ago but nothing as yet. Enough. It’s not free speech when 50% of debate in fear,” she said. Matthew Barber, police and crime commissioner for Thames Valley, said it was “appalling” to see the protest “escalate into something much uglier”. He added that he had spoken to Thames Valley police officers to discuss the police response on Wednesday evening, and said that “criminal offences will be investigated and appropriate action taken”. “All of the events of today will be reviewed to help plan for future protest events and ensure that colleagues in the NHS can continue their fantastic work in delivering the vaccine rollout,” he said. Joe Harrison, CEO of Milton Keynes University hospital, said: “I am very sorry and angry to see NHS colleagues at Milton Keynes Covid testing centre harassed and intimidated at their place of work. “Our staff having to deal with increasing aggression and violence for simply doing their job. It’s abhorrent, unacceptable and we will not stand for it.”
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, simplifying the language to a B2 CEFR level while maintaining the original meaning and flow:

Ben Everitt, a politician, was angry about the protesters. He called them names. He asked people to tell the police if they had information.

Nick Thomas-Symonds, another politician, said the protest was very bad. He said NHS workers were helping people at the protest location during the holidays. He also asked people to give information to the police.

Matt Hancock, who used to be in charge of health, said the protesters' actions were terrible.

Alicia Kearns, another politician, said the protest was shameful and silly. She thought the protesters were only trying to make themselves look important.

Helen Morgan, a politician, said the group's actions were wrong.

Stella Creasy, also a politician, said the protest was disgraceful. She said that politicians have been warning that rules are needed for people who bother people getting healthcare. She said the government promised to make rules, but they have not done it yet. She said the government needs to act. She also mentioned that people cannot share opinion freely when others are in fear.

Matthew Barber is in charge of the police in the Thames Valley area. He said the protest got much worse. He talked to police officers about how they handled the protest. He said the police will investigate crimes and take action. They will look at what happened to plan for future protests. This will help NHS workers continue to give vaccines.

text: An Afghan former BBC journalist who managed to flee the Taliban has been stranded in a refugee camp for months because of delays to a resettlement scheme promised by the UK government. Mudassar Kadir* is the only one of 14 former BBC employees to have escaped Afghanistan since the Taliban took over in August. The other 13 remain in hiding in fear of their lives. Kadir, who also spent time working for the World Bank and the former Afghan government, had hoped he and his family could begin a new life after leaving Afghanistan, but since escaping in early October with the help of a US charity, Kadir and his wife and two young sons have been stuck in a refugee centre on the outskirts of Dubai. The Kadirs are grateful to the United Arab Emirates for the safe haven and are being well looked afte, but they are prevented from straying more than 100m from the building and the UAE will not accept asylum applications. Kadir is exasperated by the UK government’s repeated refusals in response to his request for help, and he still lives in fear of being sent back to Afghanistan where his work for the BBC has made him a target for the Taliban. “The UK should have a duty of care to me and my family. My life is at risk because I have worked for the BBC. The UK government knows this but they have done nothing to help me,” he said. “In the beginning we hoped that the UK would give me a visa, but now with each passing day my frustration grows.” Campaigners say the family’s predicament highlights the plight of thousands of Afghan immigrants caught in limbo, unable to return home for fear of persecution and prevented from travelling anywhere willing to grant them refugee status. The UK government has promised an Afghan citizens’ resettlement scheme (ACRS) to help as many as 5,000 people a year starting in January, alongside the existing more restrictive Afghanistan relocation and assistance policy (Arap). Kadir does not qualify for Arap, which has helped fewer than 400 people so far, and he is unable apply for ACRS because it is yet to open and when it does will only accept referrals for resettlements from NGOs. Campaigners fear the UK government is deliberately delaying the implementation of the scheme in an effort to reduce numbers.
b2_text:
Mudassar Kadir used to work for the BBC in Afghanistan. He had to leave his country because the Taliban took over. He is now in a refugee camp.

He is the only one of 14 BBC workers who got out of Afghanistan. The other 13 are hiding. They are afraid for their lives.

Mudassar also worked for the World Bank and the old Afghan government. He hoped to start a new life with his family after leaving Afghanistan.

He left in October with help from a charity in the USA. Since then, he, his wife, and two young sons have been in a refugee center near Dubai.

The family is thankful to the United Arab Emirates for keeping them safe. They are being taken care of. But they cannot go far from the building. The UAE will not give them asylum.

Mudassar is angry because the UK government has said no to his requests for help. He is still afraid of being sent back to Afghanistan. The Taliban might hurt him because he worked for the BBC.

He said the UK should help him and his family. His life is in danger because he worked for the BBC. He said the UK knows this but is not helping.

At first, he hoped the UK would give him a visa. But now, he is getting more frustrated every day.

Some people are trying to help. They say his situation shows how hard it is for many Afghan people. They cannot go home because they are afraid. They also cannot travel to countries that will take them in as refugees.

The UK government promised a plan to help Afghan people. It is called the Afghan Citizens’ Resettlement Scheme (ACRS). It is supposed to help 5,000 people a year, starting in January. There is also another plan called Arap.

Mudassar cannot use Arap. It has only helped a small number of people. He cannot apply for ACRS yet. It is not open. When it does open, only groups can suggest people to be helped.

Some people think the UK government is making the plan start later. They think this is to help fewer people.

text: The Home Office denies this. “The ACRS is one of the most generous schemes in our country’s history and will give up to 20,000 further people at risk a new life in the UK,” a spokesperson said. “We continue to work at pace to open the scheme amid a complex and changing picture, working across government and with partners such as UNHCR to design the scheme.” It refuses to discuss individual cases. When asked to explain the delay, the Home Office said it was working on a system of “biometric enrolment” and eligibility checks to ensure those accepted did not pose a threat to national security. The Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, which is representing Kadir and many others in the same predicament, says time is running out. Its interim chief executive, Minnie Rahman, said: “Three months ago, our government promised a ‘warm welcome’ to Afghan refugees but increasingly it seems that there’s precious little welcome to be found. “Like Kadir, many Afghans appear to have been shamefully abandoned by the British government, despite clear links to the UK. The resettlement scheme is still not open, family reunion routes are still extremely limited and our government seems unable to offer many who risked their lives working with us the refuge they so urgently need.” The National Union of Journalists has been lobbying the government to help secure visas for all Afghan former BBC staff, including one who survived an armed attack on a relative’s home in October. Its general secretary, Michelle Stanistreet, said: “Whilst progress on the resettlement process happens at a snail’s pace, journalists affected are living in fear and being forced into hiding. We need urgent and robust measures put in place to secure safe passage to the UK for all those Afghans at such high risk.” A spokesperson for the BBC said: “We have every sympathy with former staff, but we regret we are not in a position to extend our direct support to them.” Kadir said: “My hope is that the UK government will fulfil their commitment towards me and my family. But right now it seems no one is paying attention to my case. Since arriving in the UAE two months ago there has been zero progress.” * His name has been changed
b2_text:
The Home Office does not agree with this. A person from the Home Office said the ACRS program is very good. It will help 20,000 people who are in danger to live in the UK. They said they are working hard to start the program. It is a difficult situation. They are working with other groups like UNHCR.

The Home Office will not talk about specific people. When asked why it is taking so long, they said they are working on a system. This system will use things like fingerprints. They need to check who can come to the UK. This is to make sure no one is dangerous to the UK.

The Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants is helping Kadir and others like him. They say there is not much time left. Minnie Rahman works there. She said the government promised to help Afghan refugees three months ago. But it seems like they are not helping much.

She said many Afghans like Kadir seem to be left alone by the UK government. They should be helped because they have connections to the UK. The program to help them move is not ready. It is very hard for families to be together. The government does not seem able to help those who worked with them and are in danger.

The National Union of Journalists is asking the government to help Afghan BBC workers get visas. One worker was attacked in October. Michelle Stanistreet works there. She said it is taking a very long time to help. The journalists are scared and hiding. They need to be safe in the UK quickly.

A person from the BBC said they feel bad for the former workers. But they cannot help them directly.

Kadir said he hopes the UK government will do what they promised for him and his family. He said no one seems to care about his case. He has been in the UAE for two months. Nothing has happened to help him.

Kadir's name is not his real name.

text: On the brink of a new year, the world faces a daunting array of challenges: the resurgent Covid-19 pandemic, the climate emergency, the struggle between democracy and authoritarianism, humanitarian crises, mass migration, and trans-national terrorism. There is the risk of new inter-state conflicts, exacerbated by the breakdown of the rules-based international order, and the spread of lethal autonomous weapons. All in all, for most people on Earth – and a handful in space – 2022 will be another year of living dangerously. Middle East Events in the Middle East will make global headlines again in 2022 – but for positive as well as negative reasons. A cause for optimism is football’s World Cup, which kicks off in Qatar in November. It’s the first time an Arab or a Muslim country has hosted the tournament. It is expected to provide a major fillip for the Gulf region in terms of future business and tourism – and, possibly, more open, progressive forms of governance. But the choice of Qatar, overshadowed by allegations of corruption, was controversial from the start. Its human rights record will come under increased scrutiny. Its treatment of low-paid migrant workers is another flashpoint. The Guardian revealed that at least 6,500 workers have died since Qatar got the nod from Fifa in 2010, killed while building seven new stadiums, roads and hotels, and a new airport. Concerns will also persist about Qatar’s illiberal attitude to free speech and women’s and LGBTQ+ rights in a country where it remains dangerous to openly criticise the government and where homosexuality is illegal. But analysts suggest most fans will not focus on these issues, which could make Qatar 2022 the most successful example of “sports-washing” to date. More familiar subjects will otherwise dominate the regional agenda. Foremost is the question of whether Israel and/or the US will take new military and/or economic steps to curb Iran’s attempts, which Tehran denies, to acquire capability to build nuclear weapons. Israel has been threatening air strikes if slow-moving talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal fail. Even football fans could not ignore a war in the Gulf.
b2_text:
The new year is coming, but the world has many big problems. These problems include:

*   The Covid-19 virus is spreading again.
*   The climate is changing in dangerous ways.
*   There is a fight between countries with democracy and countries with strong leaders.
*   Many people need help because of bad situations.
*   Many people are moving from their homes.
*   Terrorists are attacking in different countries.

There is also a chance of new wars between countries. It is harder for countries to work together. New weapons that can decide to attack on their own are also a danger.

So, for most people, 2022 will be another year with risks.

**Events in the Middle East**

Things happening in the Middle East will be important news in 2022. Some of this news will be good, and some will be bad.

One good thing is the World Cup in Qatar in November. It is the first time a country in the Arab world has the tournament. This could help the area get more business and visitors. It might also lead to better ways of running the country.

But some people are not happy about Qatar hosting the World Cup. They say there was unfairness in choosing Qatar. They will also watch how Qatar treats people.

Qatar’s treatment of workers who are paid very little is a problem. A newspaper said that at least 6,500 workers have died since Qatar was chosen in 2010. They died while building stadiums, roads, hotels, and an airport.

People are also worried about Qatar not allowing free speech. They also worry about the rights of women and people who are LGBTQ+. It is dangerous to speak against the government in Qatar. Homosexuality is against the law.

But some experts think that most football fans will not think about these problems. If this is true, the World Cup in Qatar could be a good example of “sports-washing.” This means using sports to make a country look better than it is.

Other problems will still be important in the Middle East. One big question is: Will Israel or the United States do anything to stop Iran from making nuclear weapons? Iran says it is not trying to make nuclear weapons. Israel has said it might attack Iran if talks about the 2015 nuclear agreement fail.

Even football fans would not be able to ignore a war in the Gulf area.

text: Attention will focus on Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, whose neo-Islamist AKP party will mark 20 years in power in 2022. Erdoğan’s rule has grown increasingly oppressive at home, while his aggressive foreign policy, rows with the EU and US, on-off collusion with Russia over Syria and chronic economic mismanagement could have unpredictable consequences. Other hotspots are likely to be Lebanon – tottering on the verge of becoming a failed state like war-torn Yemen – and ever-chaotic Libya. Close attention should also be paid to Palestine, where the unpopular president, Mahmoud Abbas’s postponement of elections, Israeli settler violence and West Bank land-grabs, and the lack of an active peace process all loom large. Asia Pacific The eyes of the world will be on China at the beginning and the end of the year, and quite possibly in the intervening period as well. The Winter Olympics open in Beijing in February. But the crucial question, for sports fans, of who tops the medals table may be overshadowed by diplomatic boycotts by the US, UK and other countries in protest at China’s serial human rights abuses. They fear the Games may become a Chinese Communist party propaganda exercise. The CCP’s 20th national congress, due towards the end of the year, will be the other headline-grabber. President Xi Jinping is hoping to secure an unprecedented third five-year term, which, if achieved, would confirm his position as China’s most powerful leader since Mao Zedong. There will also be jostling for senior positions in the Politburo and Politburo standing committee. It will not necessarily all go Xi’s way. Western analysts differ sharply over how secure Xi’s position truly is. A slowing economy, a debt crisis, an ageing population, huge environmental and climate-related challenges, and US-led attempts to “contain” China by signing up neighbouring countries are all putting pressure on Xi. Yet, as matters stand, 2022 is likely to see ongoing, bullish attempts to expand China’s global economic and geopolitical influence.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a CEFR B2 level, focusing on simple language and clarity:

**Turkey**

People will watch Turkey closely. The president of Turkey is Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. He is seen as a leader who does not allow much freedom. His political party, AKP, has been in power for 20 years in 2022.

Erdoğan has become stricter in his own country. He also has a strong foreign policy. He has had problems with the EU and the US. He sometimes works with Russia about Syria. His poor handling of the economy could cause problems.

**Other Problem Areas**

Lebanon is in danger. It could become like Yemen, a country ruined by war. Libya is also very unstable.

Palestine also needs attention. The president, Mahmoud Abbas, is not popular. He has delayed elections. There is violence from Israeli settlers. They are taking land in the West Bank. There is no progress in peace talks.

**Asia Pacific**

The world will watch China closely all year.

The Winter Olympics will be in Beijing in February. Many people will watch the sports. But some countries like the US and UK will not send officials. This is because they are protesting China's human rights issues. They think China will use the games to show its power.

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will have a big meeting later in the year. This is called the 20th national congress. President Xi Jinping wants to stay in power for another five years. This would be his third term. If he gets it, he will be the most powerful leader since Mao Zedong.

There will be competition for important positions in the government. It might not all go as Xi wants.

Experts disagree about how strong Xi's position really is. China's economy is growing slower. It has a lot of debt. The population is getting older. There are big problems with the environment and climate change. The US is trying to limit China's power by working with other countries. All these things put pressure on Xi.

However, in 2022, China will likely continue to try to increase its power around the world. It will try to grow its economy and influence other countries.

text: A military attack on Taiwan, which Xi has vowed to re-conquer by any or all means, could change everything. India, China’s biggest regional competitor, may continue to punch below its weight on the world stage. In what could be a symbolically important moment, its total population could soon match or exceed China’s 1.41 billion, according to some estimates. Yet at the same time, Indian birth rates and average family sizes are falling. Not so symbolic, and more dangerous, are unresolved Himalayan border disputes between these two giant neighbours, which led to violence in 2020-21 and reflect a broader deterioration in bilateral relations. The popularity of Narendra Modi, India’s authoritarian prime minister, has taken a dive of late, due to the pandemic and a sluggish economy. He was forced into an embarrassing U-turn on farm “reform” and is accused of using terrorism laws to silence critics. His BJP party will try to regain lost ground in a string of state elections in 2022. Modi’s policy of stronger ties with the west, exemplified by the Quad alliance (India, the US, Japan, Australia), will likely be reinforced, adding to China’s discomfort. Elsewhere in Asia, violent repression in Myanmar and the desperate plight of the Afghan people following the Taliban takeover will likely provoke more western hand-wringing than concrete action. Afghanistan totters on the brink of disaster. “We’re looking at 23 million people marching towards starvation,” says David Beasley of the World Food Programme. “The next six months are going to be catastrophic.” North Korea’s nuclear brinkmanship may bring a showdown as Kim Jong-un’s paranoid regime sends mixed signals about war and peace. The Philippines will elect a new president; the foul-mouthed incumbent, Rodrigo Duterte, is limited to a single term. Unfortunately this is not the case with Scott Morrison, who will seek re-election as Australia’s prime minister.
b2_text:
A war over Taiwan could change a lot. China's leader, Xi, wants to take back Taiwan. He said he might use any way to do it.

India is China's biggest competitor in the area. India might become more important in the world. Soon, India might have as many people as China. China has about 1.41 billion people. But families in India are getting smaller.

India and China have problems with their border in the mountains. This is dangerous. They fought in 2020 and 2021. Their relationship is getting worse.

Narendra Modi is the leader of India. He is becoming less popular because of the virus and the slow economy. He had to change his plans for farms. People say he uses laws about terrorism to stop people from criticizing him. His party will try to win back support in elections in 2022.

Modi wants India to be closer to the West. He is part of the Quad group with the US, Japan, and Australia. This will make China unhappy.

In Myanmar, the government is hurting people. In Afghanistan, people are suffering after the Taliban took over. Western countries will worry, but they might not do much to help. Afghanistan is in danger. David Beasley from the World Food Programme says many people are starving. The next six months will be very bad.

North Korea might start a war with its nuclear weapons. Kim Jong-un is the leader. He seems worried and is sending unclear signals about war and peace.

The Philippines will choose a new leader. Rodrigo Duterte is the current leader, but he can only be leader for one term.

Scott Morrison wants to be the leader of Australia again.

text: Europe It will be a critical year for Europe as the EU and national leaders grapple with tense internal and external divisions, the social and economic impact of the unending pandemic, migration and the newly reinforced challenges, post-Cop26, posed by net zero emissions targets. More fundamentally, Europe must decide whether it wants to be taken seriously as a global actor, or will surrender its international influence to China, the US and malign regimes such as Vladimir Putin’s Russia. The tone may be set by spring elections in France and Hungary, where rightwing populist forces are again pushing divisive agendas. Viktor Orbán, the authoritarian Hungarian leader who has made a mockery of the EU over rule of law, democracy and free speech issues, will face a united opposition for the first time. His fate will be watched closely in Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia and other EU member states where reactionary far-right parties flourish. Emmanuel Macron, the neo-Gaullist centrist who came from nowhere in 2017, will ask French voters for a second term in preference to his avowedly racist, Islamophobic rivals, Marine Le Pen and Éric Zemmour. Polls put him ahead, although he also faces what could be a strong challenge from the centre-right Republicans, whose candidate, Valérie Pécresse, is the first woman to lead the conservatives. With the left in disarray, the election could radicalise France in reactionary ways. Elections are also due in Sweden, Serbia and Austria. Germany’s new SPD-led coalition government will come under close scrutiny as it attempts to do things differently after the long years of Angela Merkel’s reign. Despite some conciliatory pledges, friction will be hard to avoid with the European Commission, led by Merkel ally Ursula von der Leyen, and with France and other southern EU members over budgetary policy and debt. France assumes the EU presidency in January and Macron will try to advance his ideas about common defence and security policy – what he calls “strategic autonomy”. Macron’s belief that Europe must stand up for itself in a hostile world will be put to the test on a range of fronts, notably Ukraine.
b2_text:
Europe: A Difficult Year

This year will be very important for Europe. Leaders in the EU and in countries will face many problems. These problems include disagreements inside and outside Europe. The pandemic is still causing problems for people and the economy. Migration is also a challenge.

After the COP26 meeting, countries promised to have zero emissions. This is a new challenge for Europe.

Europe needs to decide what it wants to be in the world. Does it want to be important? Or will it let China, the US, and countries like Russia have more power? Russia is led by Vladimir Putin.

The elections in France and Hungary in the spring will be important. Right-wing groups are pushing ideas that divide people.

Viktor Orbán is the leader of Hungary. He has not followed the rules about law, democracy, and free speech. Now, for the first time, he will face a group that is against him. People in Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, and other EU countries will watch what happens. In these countries, right-wing parties are also strong.

Emmanuel Macron is the leader of France. He wants to be president again. He will run against Marine Le Pen and Éric Zemmour. Some people say these rivals have racist ideas and are against Muslims.

Polls say Macron is ahead. But he may also face a challenge from Valérie Pécresse. She is the first woman to lead the Republican party. The left-wing parties are not doing well. The election could make France more right-wing.

There will also be elections in Sweden, Serbia, and Austria.

Germany has a new government led by the SPD party. People will watch to see if it does things differently after Angela Merkel was leader for many years. The new government might have problems with the European Commission. Ursula von der Leyen leads the Commission. She is a friend of Merkel. Germany might also have problems with France and other countries about money and debt.

France will lead the EU in January. Macron will try to push his ideas about defence and security. He calls this "strategic autonomy."

Macron believes Europe needs to protect itself in a dangerous world. This will be tested in places like Ukraine.

text: Analysts suggest rising Russian military pressure, including a large border troop build-up and a threat to deploy nuclear missiles, could lead to renewed conflict early in the year as Nato hangs back. Other trigger issues include Belarus’s weaponising of migration (and the continuing absence of a humane pan-European migration policy) and brewing separatist trouble in Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Balkans. The EU is planning a China summit, but there is no consensus over how to balance business and human rights. In isolated, increasingly impoverished Britain, Brexit buyers’ remorse looks certain to intensify. Relations with the US, which takes a dim view of European autonomy but appears ambivalent over Ukraine, may prove tense at times. Nato, its credibility damaged post-Afghanistan, faces a difficult year as it seeks a new secretary-general. Smart money says a woman could get the top job for the first time. The former UK prime minister Theresa May has been mentioned – but the French will not want a Brit. Latin America The struggle to defeat Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s notorious rightwing president, in national elections due in October looks set to produce an epic battle with international ramifications. Inside Brazil, Bolsonaro has been widely condemned for his lethally negligent handling of the Covid pandemic. Over half a million Brazilians have died, more than in any country bar the US. Beyond Brazil, Bolsonaro is reviled for his climate change denial and the accelerated destruction of the Amazon rainforest. Opinion polls show that, should he stand, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president who was jailed and then cleared on corruption charges, would easily beat Bolsonaro. But that assumes a fair fight. Concern is growing that American supporters of Donald Trump are coaching the Bolsonaro camp on how to steal an election or mount a coup to overturn the result, as Trump tried and failed to do in Washington a year ago. Fears grow that Trump-style electoral subversion may find more emulators around the world.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a B2 level, following your instructions:

**Europe**

Experts think Russia might cause trouble soon. They are moving many soldiers to the border. Russia might also use nuclear weapons as a threat. This could cause a new war. NATO might not help much.

Other problems are happening too. Belarus is using people who want to move to Europe as a weapon. There is no good plan for helping these people across Europe. Also, some groups in Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Balkans want to break away from their countries. This could cause fighting.

The European Union (EU) is planning a meeting with China. But the EU countries do not agree on how to deal with China. Some want to do business, but others want to talk about human rights.

Britain is getting poorer and more alone. People who voted to leave the EU (Brexit) are starting to regret it. This problem will likely get worse.

Britain's relationship with the United States is not good. The US does not want Europe to be too independent. The US also seems unsure about what to do about Ukraine. This could cause problems between the US and Europe.

NATO's reputation is bad after what happened in Afghanistan. They need a new leader. It is likely that a woman will be chosen for the job for the first time. Some people think Theresa May, the former British Prime Minister, might be chosen. But France probably will not want someone from Britain.

**Latin America**

Brazil will have important elections in October. It will be a big fight to defeat Jair Bolsonaro. He is the current president and has right-wing political ideas. This election will affect other countries too.

Many people in Brazil are angry at Bolsonaro. They think he handled the COVID-19 pandemic badly. Over half a million people in Brazil have died from the virus. Only the US has more deaths.

People outside Brazil also dislike Bolsonaro. They are angry because he does not care about climate change. He is also letting people destroy the Amazon rainforest quickly.

Polls show that Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva will probably win the election if he runs. He was president before. He was in jail for corruption but was later found not guilty.

But some people are worried that the election might not be fair. Supporters of Donald Trump in the US are helping Bolsonaro. They are teaching him how to cheat in the election or take over the government, like Trump tried to do in the US. People worry that other leaders around the world will try to do the same thing.

text: Surveys in Europe suggest support for rightwing populist-nationalist politicians is waning, but that may not be the case in South America, outside Brazil, and other parts of the developing world in 2022. Populism feeds off the gap between corrupt “elites” and so-called “ordinary people”, and in many poorer countries, that gap, measured in wealth and power, is growing. In Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti and Venezuela, supposed champions of the people have become their oppressors, and this phenomenon looks set to continue. In Chile, the presidential election’s first round produced strong support for José Antonio Kast, a hard-right Pinochet apologist, though he was ultimately defeated by Gabriel Boric, a leftist former student leader, who will become the country’s youngest leader after storming to a resounding victory in a run-off. Argentina’s president, Alberto Fernández, faces a different kind of problem in what looks like a tough year ahead, after elections in which his Peronists, one of the world’s oldest populist parties, lost their majority in Congress for the first time in nearly 40 years. Mexico’s president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, will face ongoing tensions with the US over trade, drugs and migration from Central America. But at least he no longer has to put up with Trump’s insults – for now. North America All eyes will be on the campaign for November’s mid-term elections when the Democrats will attempt to fend off a Republican bid to re-take control of the Senate and House of Representatives. The results will inevitably be viewed as a referendum on Joe Biden’s presidency. If the GOP does well in the battleground states, Donald Trump – who still falsely claims to have won the 2020 election – will almost certainly decide to run for a second term in 2024. Certain issues will have nationwide resonance: in particular, progress (or otherwise) in stemming the pandemic and ongoing anti-vax resistance; the economy, with prices and interest rates set to rise; and divisive social issues such as migration, race and abortion rights, with the supreme court predicted to overrule or seriously weaken provisions of the landmark 1973 Roe v Wade decision.
b2_text:
Here is the text rewritten in simple English, suitable for a B2 level learner:

Some studies in Europe show that fewer people support right-wing politicians. But this might not be true in South America, except for Brazil. It may also not be true in other developing countries in 2022.

Populism happens when there is a big difference between rich leaders and regular people. In many poorer countries, this difference is getting bigger. This is about money and power.

In Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti, and Venezuela, leaders who said they would help people have become bad rulers. This problem may continue.

In Chile, there was an election. José Antonio Kast got a lot of support in the first part of the election. He was a politician on the right and liked Pinochet, a former leader. But he lost to Gabriel Boric. Boric is a leftist. He used to be a student leader. He won the election and will be the youngest leader of Chile.

Argentina's president, Alberto Fernández, has problems. It looks like the next year will be hard. His political party, the Peronists, lost in the elections. This party is very old. They lost control of Congress for the first time in 40 years.

Mexico's president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, will have problems with the US. These problems are about trade, drugs, and people moving from Central America. But at least he does not have to deal with insults from Trump anymore, for now.

In North America, everyone will watch the elections in November. The Democrats will try to stop the Republicans from taking control of the Senate and the House of Representatives.

The results of these elections will show what people think of Joe Biden, the president. If the Republicans do well, Donald Trump might run for president again in 2024. He still says he won the 2020 election, but this is not true.

Some issues are important all over the country. These are: how well we are dealing with the pandemic, people who don't want to get vaccinated, the economy, prices and interest rates going up, and social issues like immigration, race, and abortion. The Supreme Court might change the Roe v Wade decision from 1973, which protects abortion rights. They might make it weaker.

text: The Democrats’ biggest problem in 2022 may be internal party divisions. The split between so-called progressives and moderates, especially in the Senate, undermined Biden’s signature social care and infrastructure spending bills, which were watered down. Some of the focus will be on Biden himself: whether he will run again in 2024, his age (he will be 80 in November), his mental agility and his ability to deliver his agenda. His mid-December minus-7 approval rating may prove hard to turn around. Also under the microscope is Kamala Harris, the vice-president, who is said to be unsettled and under-performing – at least by those with an interest is destabilising the White House. Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary who sought the Democratic nomination in 2020, is a man to watch, as a possible replacement for Harris or even for Biden, should the president settle for one term. Concern has grown, meanwhile, over whether the mid-terms will be free and fair, given extraordinary efforts by Republican state legislators to make it harder to vote and even harder for opponents to win gerrymandered congressional districts and precincts with in-built GOP majorities. One survey estimates Republicans will flip at least five House seats thanks to redrawn, absurdly distorted voting maps. This could be enough to assure a Republican House majority before voting even begins. Pressure from would-be Central American migrants on the southern US border will likely be a running story in 2022 – a problem Harris, who was tasked with dealing with it, has fumbled so far. She and Biden are accused of continuing Trump’s harsh policies. Belief in Biden’s competence has also been undermined by the chaotic Afghan withdrawal, which felt to many like a Vietnam-scale humiliation. Another big foreign policy setback or overseas conflagration – such as a Russian land-grab in Ukraine, direct Chinese aggression against Taiwan or an Israel-Iran conflict – has potential to suck in US forces and wreck Biden’s presidency.
