In Canada, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is expected to push new policy initiatives on affordable childcare and housing after winning re-election in September.
b2_text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text, adjusted for CEFR B2 level English:

The Democratic party has problems. One big problem is that the party is divided. There are two groups: progressives and moderates. They disagree on many things.

This disagreement caused problems for President Biden. He wanted to pass laws about social care and infrastructure. But the two groups in his party could not agree. The laws were changed to be weaker.

People are watching President Biden. They want to know if he will run for president again in 2024. He will be 80 years old in November. Some people wonder if he is too old. They also wonder if he can still do his job well. His popularity is low right now. It may be hard for him to become more popular.

Vice-President Kamala Harris is also being watched. Some people say she is not doing a good job. They say she seems unhappy. Some people may want to cause problems for her and President Biden.

Pete Buttigieg is the transportation secretary. He wanted to be president in 2020. People are watching him too. He could replace Kamala Harris or even President Biden. This could happen if Biden only stays president for one term.

Some people are worried about the midterm elections. They are not sure if the elections will be fair. Republicans are trying to make it harder for some people to vote. They are also changing voting areas to help Republicans win.

One study says Republicans will win at least five more seats in the House of Representatives. This is because of the changed voting areas. It could mean Republicans will control the House, even before people vote.

Many people from Central America want to come to the US. They are going to the southern border. This will be a big problem in 2022. Kamala Harris is in charge of dealing with this problem. But some people say she is not doing a good job. People say that Biden and Harris are using the same harsh rules as Trump.

People are also worried about President Biden because of Afghanistan. The US left Afghanistan in a hurry. Many people thought this was a failure. It made Biden look bad.

Other things could also cause problems for Biden. A war or conflict in another country could involve the US. This could ruin Biden's time as president. For example, Russia could invade Ukraine. China could attack Taiwan. Or Israel and Iran could start a war.

In Canada, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau won the election. He wants to make new rules about childcare and housing. He wants to make them more affordable.

text: But in 2021’s snap election his Liberals attracted the smallest share of the popular vote of any winning party in history, suggesting the Trudeau magic is wearing thin. Disputes swirl over alleged corruption, pandemic management, trade with the US and carbon reduction policy. Africa As befits this giant continent, some of 2022’s biggest themes will play out across Africa. Among the most striking is the fraught question of whether Africans, still largely unvaccinated, will pay a huge, avoidable price for the developed world’s monopolising of vaccines, its reluctance to distribute surpluses and share patents – and from the pandemic’s myriad, knock-on health and economic impacts. This question in turn raises another: will such selfishness rebound on the wealthy north, as former UK prime minister Gordon Brown has repeatedly warned? The sudden spread of Omicron, first identified in South Africa, suggests more Covid variants could emerge in 2022. Yet once again, the response of developed countries may be to focus on domestic protection, not international cooperation. The course of the global pandemic in 2022 – both in terms of the threat to health and economic prosperity – is ultimately unknowable. But in many African countries, with relatively young populations less vulnerable to severe Covid harms, the bigger problem may be the negative impact on management of other diseases. It’s estimated 25 million people in Africa will live with HIV-Aids in 2022. Malaria claims almost 400,000 lives in a typical year. Treatment of these diseases, and others such as TB and diabetes, may deteriorate further as a result of Covid-related strains on healthcare systems. Replacing the Middle East, Africa has become the new ground zero for international terrorism, at least in the view of many analysts. This trend looks set to continue in 2022. The countries of the Sahel, in particular, have seen an upsurge of radical Islamist groups, mostly home-grown, yet often professing allegiance to global networks such as al-Qaida and Islamic State. Western efforts to counter this upsurge in jihadist violence may become more organised in 2022.
b2_text:
Okay, here is the rewritten text at a CEFR B2 level:

**Canada**

In 2021, there was a quick election. Justin Trudeau's Liberal party won. But they did not get many votes from the people. It was the lowest number of votes for a winning party ever. This means people may not like Trudeau as much now.

There are some problems. People are talking about possible unfair behavior. They also disagree about how the government handled the pandemic. Trade with the United States is another issue. The plan to reduce carbon is also causing arguments.

**Africa**

Africa is a big continent. Big events will happen there in 2022. One important issue is vaccines. Many Africans are not vaccinated. Rich countries have most of the vaccines. They are not sharing extra vaccines or patents. This could hurt Africa's health and economy.

Will this selfishness hurt rich countries later? Gordon Brown, a former UK leader, thinks so. The Omicron virus started in South Africa. This shows new viruses can appear in 2022. Rich countries might only protect themselves. They might not work together with other countries.

We do not know what will happen with the pandemic in 2022. It could affect health and money everywhere. In Africa, many people are young. They might not get very sick from Covid. But the bigger problem could be other diseases.

About 25 million people in Africa will have HIV-Aids in 2022. Malaria kills almost 400,000 people each year. It might be harder to treat these diseases. Covid has made the healthcare systems weaker. This can also affect treatments for other diseases, like TB and diabetes.

Some people think Africa is now the main place for terrorism. This will probably continue in 2022. The Sahel area has many radical groups. These groups are mostly from Africa. But they say they support groups like al-Qaida and Islamic State. Western countries may try harder to fight this violence in 2022.

text: This follows a cooperation agreement between the US and French presidents Joe Biden and Emmanuel Macron, who had wound down French military operations in Mali for lack of support. Western governments are watching with alarm the spread of radical Islamist ideas from key countries in west Africa, such as Nigeria, to the Democratic Republic of the Congo and energy-rich Mozambique. The failed state of Somalia, where the al-Shabaab group is active, is a cautionary tale of what may befall a country when terrorism is uncontained. In a year when the US is due to convene a second “summit for democracy”, the issue of global democratic governance – of the lack of it – will also loom large. In Africa, which experienced several coups in 2021, most recently in Sudan, this issue is especially pressing. Inextricably linked to it are the challenges posed by extreme poverty. According to the International Rescue Committee charity’s 2022 emergency watchlist, 12 of the 20 countries at greatest risk of worsening humanitarian crises are in Africa. They are Ethiopia, South Sudan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Somalia, Sudan, Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Central African Republic, Mozambique, Mali, Niger and Cameroon. (The most vulnerable, non-African countries are Afghanistan, Yemen, Syria, Myanmar, Haiti, Honduras, Lebanon and Venezuela.) In the Horn of Africa, what the IRC calls Ethiopia’s “perfect storm” of problems is being exacerbated by a worsening civil war that threatens the break-up of the country amid increased meddling by neighbouring Eritrea’s violently Stalinist regime. Meanwhile, the UN is warning a rapidly worsening drought will put 7.7 million Somalis at extreme risk by April. Unicef, the UN children’s charity, has launched a record $9.4bn worldwide funding appeal for 2022 to help more than 327 million people, including 177 million children, affected by humanitarian crises and Covid. These emergencies provide the context for another great challenge of 2022: international migration, whether it involves refugees from conflict, politically persecuted asylum-seekers, or economic migrants forced out of their homes by climate change, famine and drought.
b2_text:
The leaders of the US and France made an agreement to work together. This happened after France stopped its military actions in Mali because they did not have enough support.

Many countries are worried. They see dangerous ideas from radical Islamist groups spreading in West Africa. These ideas are going from countries like Nigeria to places like Congo and Mozambique.

Somalia is a country that is not doing well. A group called al-Shabaab is causing problems there. Somalia shows what can happen when terrorism is not stopped. This is a warning for other countries.

The US will have a meeting about democracy. The meeting will talk about how countries are governed. This is a big issue, especially in Africa. Several countries in Africa had changes in government in 2021. Sudan is one example.

Poverty is also a big problem. It is connected to the way countries are governed. The International Rescue Committee says that many countries in Africa are at risk of having very bad problems.

They say that the following countries are at risk: Ethiopia, South Sudan, Democratic Republic of Congo, Somalia, Sudan, Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Central African Republic, Mozambique, Mali, Niger, and Cameroon.

Other countries that are also at risk include Afghanistan, Yemen, Syria, Myanmar, Haiti, Honduras, Lebanon, and Venezuela.

In the Horn of Africa, Ethiopia has many problems. There is a civil war that is getting worse. This war could break up the country. The country next to Ethiopia, Eritrea, is also causing problems.

The United Nations says that there will be a bad drought in Somalia. This drought will put many people at risk. About 7.7 million people in Somalia could be in danger by April.

UNICEF is a charity that helps children. They are asking for a lot of money to help people around the world. They need $9.4 billion to help over 327 million people. This includes 177 million children. These people are having problems because of wars, sickness, and other bad things.

All these problems are making another big problem worse: migration. People are leaving their homes for different reasons. Some people are refugees because of war. Other people are asking for asylum because they are being treated badly. Some people are leaving because of climate change, hunger, and drought.

text: The UN’s International Organisation for Migration says a record 281 million people, or 3.6% of the global population, were classified as international migrants in 2020. This figure is climbing despite pandemic restrictions on movement across international borders. These extraordinary population shifts have yet to produce a coordinated, or even rational, response from most governments, notably in wealthy North America and Europe. Maybe this will change in 2022. But don’t hold your breath. Antarctica, the Arctic … and beyond Cop27, the follow-up to the Cop26 Glasgow climate crisis conference, will be held in Egypt in November. It will provide progress reports on the Glasgow pledges to reduce carbon and methane emissions, halt deforestation, “phase down” coal production, cut fossil fuel subsidies and provide finance to mitigate the loss and damage suffered by poorer countries. It’s unrealistic to expect any swift improvement in the global climate heating outlook in the coming year. Extreme weather events of the type seen across the world in 2021 – fires, droughts, floods, storms and record temperatures – are almost certain to be repeated. As before, these effects will be particularly felt in the world’s more sensitive environments, not least the Antarctic and Arctic. Both polar regions will see increased human activity in 2022 – not necessarily a happy prospect. In Antarctica, for example, mass tourism is taking off with the advent of ice runways accommodating wide-bodied jets. More problematic still is the growing interest of China, with other countries, in tapping into Antarctic’s resources and establishing military facilities there. Likewise the melting ice of the Arctic has opened up commercial and naval sea-lanes across the top of the world, currently being developed by Russia in heated competition with several other countries. Long neglected Greenland is a new El Dorado for mineral and mining companies, and also of growing interest to defence planners – but local people’s resistance to issuing licences is growing. It will be a busy year in space in terms of exploration and military competition. Nasa is preparing 18 separate missions in 2022 as it gears up to resume manned flight to the moon. A new space station – Gateway – is planned. Russia, South Korea, India and Japan will launch lunar spacecraft. The European Space Agency plans to send a mission to Mars.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a CEFR B2 level:

In 2020, a lot of people lived in countries that were not their own. The UN says this number was 281 million. That is about 3.6% of all the people in the world. This is a record number.

The number of migrants is still increasing. This is happening even though it is difficult to travel between countries because of the pandemic.

Many people are moving to different countries. But governments are not working together to handle this situation. Rich countries in North America and Europe especially need to do more. Maybe things will get better in 2022. But it might not happen.

The next big meeting about the climate is called Cop27. It will be in Egypt in November. This meeting will check on the promises made in Glasgow at Cop26. Countries promised to reduce carbon and methane. They also promised to stop cutting down forests, use less coal, and stop giving money to fossil fuels. Rich countries also promised to help poor countries with the damage caused by climate change.

We should not expect the climate to improve quickly. The extreme weather from 2021 will likely happen again. There will be fires, droughts, floods, storms, and very hot temperatures.

These problems will be worse in places that are already weak, like Antarctica and the Arctic. There will be more human activity in these areas in 2022. This might not be a good thing.

More tourists are visiting Antarctica. Big planes can now land there. China and other countries want to use Antarctica's resources and build military bases there. This is also a problem.

The ice in the Arctic is melting. This is opening up new shipping routes for businesses and the navy. Russia is building these routes. Other countries are competing with Russia.

Greenland has many minerals. Mining companies want to use them. Defence planners are also interested in Greenland. But people who live there do not want to give out mining licenses.

There will be a lot of activity in space this year. Countries will explore space and compete with each other for military reasons.

NASA will have 18 missions in 2022. They want to send people back to the moon. They are also planning a new space station called Gateway. Russia, South Korea, India, and Japan will send spaceships to the moon. The European Space Agency will send a mission to Mars.

text: China is said to be hoping to have a fully functional orbiting space station by the end of the year. Meanwhile space tourism organised by Russia and private companies such as Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic and Jeff Bezos’s Blue Origin is taking off. More sinisterly, a nuclear arms race in space will also accelerate. The US, Russia and China are all experimenting with new weapons, such as orbiting hypersonic glide vehicles capable of launching nuclear missiles from anywhere in the heavens. Russia caused anger in late 2021 with its reckless test of an anti-satellite missile. Others will follow suit, potentially threatening global communications. Not to be outdone, Nasa is planning to knock a giant asteroid off course in September by orchestrating a head-on collision, using a spacecraft launched on a rocket built by Elon Musk’s SpaceX. The US calls this “planetary defence” – but the technology plainly has offensive applications. Some will deem this progress, others a giant backward step for mankind.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, aimed at a CEFR B2 level:

China wants to finish building its space station this year. The space station will orbit the Earth.

At the same time, space tourism is becoming popular. Russia and companies like Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin are offering trips to space. Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos own these companies.

But there are also worries about weapons in space. Countries like the US, Russia, and China are testing new weapons. These weapons could launch nuclear missiles from space. This could start a dangerous arms race.

Russia made people angry when it tested a missile that could destroy satellites. This test happened in 2021. Other countries might do the same thing. This could damage how we communicate around the world.

NASA has a plan to protect Earth. They want to hit a big asteroid to change its path. They will use a spacecraft to crash into the asteroid. The spacecraft will be launched by a rocket from SpaceX, Elon Musk's company.

The US calls this "planetary defense." But the same technology could be used to attack other things in space.

Some people think this is progress. Others think it is a bad step for everyone.

text: The “appalling” scale of abuse, intimidation and threatening behaviour directed at the UK government’s scientific and medical advisers has been laid bare in a Guardian survey of experts working on the pandemic. Dozens of UK advisers described incidents ranging from coordinated online attacks to death threats and acts of intimidation, such as photos being taken of their homes and shared online and suspicious packages arriving in the post, some containing items with messages scrawled on them. Further harassment has included vitriolic tweets, emails and phone calls, hate mail, threats of violence, complaints sent to employers, referrals to the General Medical Council watchdog, offensive notes left on cars and abuse shouted through the letterbox. The police have brought charges in a small number of cases when individuals linked to specific threats were identified. Advisers were not the only ones targeted. The abuse spilled over to their students, colleagues and family members, including partners and children. One adviser who works as a GP said the surgery’s receptionists had been subjected to “vile tirades” from callers as a result of their advisory role. In another case, an adviser’s child was repeatedly targeted by a teacher who blamed the parent for the government’s lockdown policy. The family did not make a formal complaint because the child’s exam grade depended on the teacher’s assessment. The Guardian survey was sent to more than 100 scientists, doctors and other researchers who contribute to the advice ministers receive through bodies such as the Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage), the modelling and behavioural science subgroups that support Sage, and other expert groups such as the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group (Nervtag) and the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI). The responses have been anonymised. Three-quarters of the 42 respondents received significant abuse about government policy, their views on the science, or their research findings, often after being quoted in the media or speaking at open events such as parliamentary inquiries or webinars hosted by organisations such as the UK’s various royal societies. In an article for the Guardian today, Prof John Edmunds, an epidemiologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and a member of Sage, said he and junior staff were targeted regularly with abusive emails.
b2_text:
It is shocking how many UK scientists and doctors have been abused. These people give advice to the government about the pandemic.

A survey in The Guardian newspaper looked at this problem. Many experts said they were attacked online. Some even received death threats.

Some people took photos of the experts' houses. They shared these photos online. Some experts got strange packages in the mail. These packages had messages written on them.

The experts also received nasty messages. These included angry tweets, emails, and phone calls. Some people sent hate mail and threatened violence. They complained to the experts' bosses. Some even contacted the General Medical Council, a group that watches over doctors. People left mean notes on the experts' cars. They shouted insults through their doors.

The police have arrested some people who made specific threats.

The abuse did not only target the experts. Their students, coworkers, and families were also targeted. This included their partners and children.

One expert works as a doctor. The doctor said that people were very rude to the receptionists at the doctor's office. This happened because of the doctor's role as an advisor.

In another case, a teacher targeted an expert's child. The teacher blamed the parent for the government's rules about staying home. The family did not complain because the child needed the teacher to give them a good grade.

The Guardian sent the survey to over 100 scientists, doctors, and researchers. These people help advise the government. They work with groups like SAGE, Nervtag, and JCVI.

The answers to the survey are kept secret. Three out of four people who answered said they were abused. This was because of the government's rules, their science opinions, or their research. This often happened after they spoke to the news or at public events.

Professor John Edmunds is an expert at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. He is also a member of SAGE. He wrote in The Guardian that he and his staff often receive abusive emails.

text: “If you mention vaccination in the media, particularly vaccination of children, then there is likely to be a reaction,” he writes. “However, this only occurs if one’s comments are picked up by the rightwing press – particularly the Daily Mail.” One of the advisers surveyed received a death threat on Twitter, which was reported to the police, and experienced a “tidal wave of abuse” whenever they appeared in the media. “A lot of it is misogynistic and a lot of it is deeply unpleasant,” a doctor said. “I’ve never experienced anything like this before. I’m just trying to do the best I can to stop people dying.” Much of the activity comes from people who feel more threatened by the government’s response to the pandemic than the pandemic itself, even though advisers are not involved in policy decisions. Many advisers say abuse peaks whenever they speak publicly about masks, vaccines, Covid treatments, circuit-breakers or lockdowns, meaning it is increasing with the spread of the Omicron variant. At the beginning of the pandemic last year, a surge in threatening behaviour led government security experts to brief the advisers on how best to protect themselves, including how to increase computer security and improve their personal safety by varying the time they travelled to work and the route they used, and checking under their car before driving. Some advisers have had security reviews of their homes and workplaces and alarms and 24-hour surveillance cameras installed, linked to the local police station. A number of universities have hired private security firms to help the experts operate safely and to ensure campaigners and protesters do not disrupt their work. Government cybersecurity experts have removed some sensitive material posted online, but this has not always been possible. Many advisers reported a stream of hate via Twitter and email, with messages such as “I hope your family die”, “I hope cunts like you are fucking held accountable”, “you will pay for killing our children with vaccines” and “fuck off back to where you came from”. The mainstream media sometimes fuelled the activity by emphasising worst-case scenarios, some respondents said, or legitimised abuse from social media trolls by launching their own attacks on advisers.
b2_text:
If you talk about vaccines in the news, people might react. This is especially true if you talk about vaccines for children. But this usually happens if a newspaper like the Daily Mail writes about your comments.

One advisor got a death threat on Twitter. They told the police about it. They also got a lot of mean messages when they were on TV or in the newspaper.

One doctor said that a lot of the messages were mean to women. They said the messages were very bad. The doctor said they had never seen anything like it before. They just wanted to help stop people from dying.

Some people are more worried about the government's actions than about the virus itself. These people are often the ones who send the mean messages. But the advisors do not make the rules.

Advisors say the mean messages get worse when they talk about masks, vaccines, and treatments for COVID. It also gets worse when they talk about short lockdowns. This means it is getting worse as the Omicron virus spreads.

At the start of the virus problem, advisors got many threats. Government security experts told them how to stay safe. They told them how to make their computers safer. They also told them to change when they go to work and what roads they use. They also said to check under their car before they drive.

Some advisors had their homes and offices checked for safety. They got alarms and cameras that are watched all the time. The cameras are connected to the police.

Some universities hired security guards to help the experts. The guards make sure protestors do not bother the experts.

Government experts have taken down some private information from the internet. But they cannot always do this.

Many advisors got hateful messages on Twitter and email. Some messages said, "I hope your family dies." Other messages used bad words and said the advisors were killing children with vaccines.

Some news companies made the problem worse. They talked about the worst things that could happen. Some news companies also attacked the advisors. This made the mean messages from people online seem okay.

text: The survey found no clear evidence that women received more abuse than men, but some were less willing to describe their experiences. Numerous male counterparts expressed dismay at the intensity and nature of the abuse directed at women they knew. “There seems to be a huge gender imbalance with women being targeted so much more than men,” one said. Despite the torrent of abuse, several advisers emphasised that they also received praise, thanks and support from members of the public, which counterbalanced the vitriol. “It has vaccinated me against much of the hate,” one said. George Freeman, the science minister, called the abuse “appalling”. He said: “All of us who value our freedom and democracy need to call this out … Scientists and doctors should not be held responsible for decisions taken in good faith by ministers accountable to parliament.” Chi Onwurah, the shadow science minister, said the attacks were “wholly unacceptable” and the government’s much-delayed online safety bill was desperately needed to counter misinformation. While many advisers praised the Cabinet Office and the Sage secretariat for setting up “extensive support mechanisms”, some felt they would have benefited from a warning and security advice before signing up. The attention has led some scientists to keep their heads down, refuse interviews, and consider withdrawing from the public discussion. But most said the abuse had little effect or even emboldened them. “If anything, it motivated me to engage further,” one adviser said. “Clearly my voice was being heard and having an impact.” Another said: “If we stop speaking up, and stop providing advice, something else will fill the void and it will be misinformation, false narratives and so on. Do we acquiesce and allow them to take over and risk people’s lives?”
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a B1/B2 CEFR level:

The study did not find proof that women were abused more than men. But some women did not want to talk about what happened to them.

Many men were sad about the bad things said to women they knew. One man said that women seem to get much more abuse than men.

Even with all the bad comments, some experts said they also got good comments. People thanked them and supported them. This made the bad comments less important. One expert said that the hate did not bother him much anymore.

George Freeman, who is in charge of science, said the abuse was very bad. He said we all need to say this is wrong because we care about freedom. He also said that scientists should not be blamed for choices made by the government. The government is in charge of making decisions.

Chi Onwurah said the attacks were not okay. She said the government needs to help stop wrong information online. The government bill to do this is taking too long.

Many experts said that the Cabinet Office and the Sage team helped them a lot. But some experts said they wished they had been told about the abuse beforehand. They also wanted advice on how to stay safe.

Because of the attention, some scientists are staying quiet. They do not want to talk to the media or share their thoughts. But most scientists said the abuse did not change them. Some even said it made them stronger.

One expert said the abuse made him want to talk more. He felt like people were listening to him and that he was making a difference.

Another expert said that if they stop talking, bad information will spread. He asked if they should let bad information take over and risk people’s lives.

text: The former Afghan president Ashraf Ghani has broken his silence with his first interview since fleeing Kabul four months ago, in effect blaming the international community and in particular the Americans for the fall of the republic. Ghani told the BBC he was rushed into fleeing Kabul on a helicopter by his “terrified” national security adviser, Hamdullah Mohib, and the commander of the collapsing presidential security detail. “They said the PPS [presidential protection service] has collapsed, [and] if I take a stand they will all be killed,” Ghani said. “He [Mohib] did not give me more than two minutes.” He was speaking to the former chief of the British defence staff, Gen Sir Nick Carter, who was guest-editing BBC Radio 4’s Today programme. The Taliban were clearly on a path to controlling Afghanistan before Ghani’s flight into exile, but his hasty departure ended hopes of an orderly handover of power that might have kept some aid flowing, and scuttled plans for an inclusive government. Now Afghanistan is stalked by famine; its economy has contracted by more than a third, and its health and education sectors have been crippled by an abrupt halt to foreign funds on which they relied. Asked by Carter what he would say to the Afghan people, many of whom “blame you as their leader” for the current catastrophe, Ghani said his biggest mistake had been relying on Afghanistan’s allies. “What they rightly blame me for, they have a total right to, I trusted in our international partnership and pursued that path,” he said. “All of us made a huge mistake assuming the patience of the international community would last.” Ghani criticised Washington for leaving his government out of years of peace talks with the Taliban, claiming that deals signed under the US peace envoy Zalmay Khalilzad in effect sacrificed Afghans for a smooth departure of US troops. “Process-wise, outcome-wise, the responsibility has to clearly rest with the [American] team,” he said. “We were never given the opportunity to sit down with them [the Taliban].
b2_text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text using simpler language and shorter sentences, suitable for a CEFR B2 learner:

Ashraf Ghani used to be the president of Afghanistan. He has spoken for the first time since he left Kabul four months ago. He blames other countries for what happened in Afghanistan. He especially blames the United States. He says they caused the fall of the Afghan government.

Ghani spoke to the BBC. He said he had to leave Kabul quickly in a helicopter. His security advisor, Hamdullah Mohib, told him to go. Mohib was very scared. The head of the presidential security was also scared. Ghani said they told him the security guards had failed. They said if he stayed, they would all be killed. Mohib gave him only two minutes to decide.

Ghani was talking to Nick Carter. Carter used to be the head of the British army. He was in charge of a BBC radio show for one day.

The Taliban were taking control of Afghanistan. This happened before Ghani left. When Ghani left quickly, it stopped any chance of a peaceful change of power. This also stopped aid money from coming to Afghanistan. Plans for a government with different groups also failed.

Now, many people in Afghanistan are hungry. The country's economy is much smaller. The health system and schools are in trouble. This is because foreign money stopped coming. They depended on this money.

Carter asked Ghani what he would say to the Afghan people. Many people blame Ghani for the problems in Afghanistan. Ghani said his biggest mistake was trusting Afghanistan's allies. He said he trusted the international community too much. He thought they would help for a long time, but they did not.

Ghani said the United States did not include his government in peace talks with the Taliban. He said the US made deals with the Taliban. These deals were made to help US troops leave easily. He said this hurt the Afghan people. He said the US team is responsible. He said they never let him talk to the Taliban.

text: Ambassador Khalilzad sat down with them; it became an American issue, not an Afghan issue. They erased us.” Khalilzad said in his own interview with the Today programme that the collapse of the republic was due to a “failure of Afghan leadership” and Afghan troops that did not “resist hard” against the Taliban. Six months ago the two men were among the most influential figures shaping Afghanistan’s future; now neither are willing to accept any responsibility for the tragedy stalking the country. Carter asked the former president about any personal regrets that had surfaced in the last 100 days. Ghani did not mention the humanitarian crisis, but he lamented the damage to his reputation and legacy. “My work has been destroyed. My values have been trampled on, and I’ve been made a scapegoat.”
b2_text:
Here is the rewritten text at CEFR B2 level:

Ambassador Khalilzad talked with them. It was not just about Afghanistan anymore. It was now about America too. "They forgot about us," Khalilzad said in an interview. He said Afghanistan fell apart because the Afghan leaders were not good. He also said the Afghan soldiers did not fight hard enough against the Taliban.

Six months ago, these two men were very important. They helped decide what would happen in Afghanistan. Now, they do not want to be blamed for the bad things happening there.

Carter asked the former president if he felt sorry about anything in the last 100 days. Ghani did not talk about the people who need help. He said his name and what he did were ruined. "My work is gone," he said. "My ideas are not respected. People are blaming me for everything."

text: Thousands of South Africans will pause to remember the anti-apartheid icon Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who died on Sunday aged 90, every day this week as bells are rung at churches across the country for 10 minutes at noon. Tributes to Tutu, described as the “moral compass” of his country, have poured in from around the world since his death in a Cape Town care home, as a series of events commemorating his life and achievements begin. “A universal spirit, Archbishop Tutu was grounded in the struggle for liberation and justice in his own country, but also concerned with injustice everywhere,” former US president Barack Obama said in a statement. The Nobel laureate’s remains will lie in state for two days before his funeral is held on 1 January at Cape Town’s St George’s Cathedral, his former parish. The bells of the cathedral, where his ashes are to be interred, will toll for 10 minutes at noon daily until Friday in his honour. Dozens of memorial services are to be held across South Africa in the coming days and flags will be flown at half-mast. “Bells will ring at 12 noon each day at the cathedral and at many cathedrals and churches across the land. In Cape Town, the Angelus prayer will be recited,” said Archbishop Thabo Makgoba on Monday. In a troubled country still divided by deep inequality, polarised politics and the legacy of the repressive, racist apartheid system, the death of one of the leading figures of the freedom struggle has brought a rare moment of unity. Members of all communities have stopped by St George’s cathedral since the news of Tutu’s death broke, many laying flowers under a portrait of the cleric fixed to a wall of remembrance alongside a South African flag, or signing a book of condolence. Among them was Miriam Mokwadi, a 67-year-old retired nurse, who said the Nobel laureate “was a hero to us, he fought for us”. “We are liberated due to him. If it was not for him, probably we would have been lost as a country.
b2_text:
This week, many South Africans will remember Desmond Tutu. He was a famous person who fought against apartheid. Apartheid was a system that treated people of different races unfairly. Desmond Tutu died on Sunday. He was 90 years old.

Every day this week, bells will ring in churches. The bells will ring for 10 minutes at 12 o'clock. This is to honor Desmond Tutu. People all over the world are remembering him. They say he was a very good man. He helped his country a lot.

Barack Obama, who used to be the president of the United States, said Desmond Tutu cared about fairness. He wanted everyone to be treated well.

Desmond Tutu won a big award called the Nobel Prize. His body will be shown to the public for two days. Then, on January 1, there will be a funeral. The funeral will be at St George's Cathedral in Cape Town. This was Desmond Tutu's church.

The bells at the church will ring every day at 12 o'clock. This will happen until Friday. People will also have special services to remember him. Flags will be lowered to show respect.

Archbishop Thabo Makgoba said that the bells will ring in many churches. He also said that people in Cape Town will say a special prayer.

South Africa still has problems. There is inequality, and people have different political ideas. But Desmond Tutu's death has brought people together.

Many people have visited St George's Cathedral. They want to remember Desmond Tutu. They are leaving flowers and signing a book. Miriam Mokwadi, who is 67, said that Desmond Tutu was a hero. She said he fought for them. She said that South Africa is free because of him. She said they would have been lost without him.

text: He was just good,” said Mokwadi, clutching the hand of her granddaughter. “His significance supersedes the boundaries of being an Anglican,” said mourner Brent Goliath, who broke down in tears outside the old stone building. He said he had been an altar boy and had met Tutu several times. “I was very emotional this morning when I heard that he’d passed away. I thank God that he has been there for us,” he said, wiping his eyes as he placed a bouquet of pink flowers under Tutu’s photo. Daphney Ramakgopa, 58, a local government worker, spoke of the loss the entire country was feeling. “We looked up to him as the adviser to everyone in the country, especially our politicians,” she said. South Africa’s cricket team wore black armbands in Tutu’s honour on day one of the first Test against India in South Africa. Cape Town’s Table Mountain was lit up in purple in his honour. South Africa’s president, Cyril Ramaphosa, called him a man of “extraordinary intellect, integrity and invincibility against the forces of apartheid”. Ramaphosa said Tutu’s death was “another chapter of bereavement in our nation’s farewell to a generation of outstanding South Africans who have bequeathed us a liberated South Africa,” after the country’s last apartheid-era president FW de Klerk died in November. “Fighting for freedom from the trenches of South Africa required a courage that cannot be described,” said Graça Machel, the widow of Nelson Mandela. Though he had largely faded from public life in recent years, Tutu had continued his lifelong fight for causes he believed in, forcefully supporting LGBT rights, equal access to education and the assisted dying movement. The charismatic cleric, whose infectious laughter and informality masked a steely commitment to his principles, had also been fiercely critical of South Africa’s ruling African National Congress party.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a B1/B2 CEFR level:

Mokwadi held her granddaughter's hand. She said, "He was a very good person."

Brent Goliath was a mourner. He cried outside the old stone building. He said Tutu was important to everyone, not just people in the church.

Goliath said he used to help at the church. He met Tutu many times. "I felt very sad this morning when I heard he died," he said. "I thank God he was there for us." He wiped his eyes and put pink flowers under a picture of Tutu.

Daphney Ramakgopa is 58. She works for the local government. She said the whole country is sad. "We respected him. He gave advice to everyone, especially our leaders," she said.

The South African cricket team played a game against India. They wore black bands on their arms to honor Tutu. Table Mountain in Cape Town was lit up with purple light to remember him.

Cyril Ramaphosa is the President of South Africa. He said Tutu was very smart, honest, and strong against the unfair system of apartheid.

Ramaphosa said Tutu's death is a sad time for the country. South Africa is saying goodbye to many important people who helped make the country free. FW de Klerk, another leader from the time of apartheid, died in November.

Graça Machel is Nelson Mandela's widow. She said, "It took great courage to fight for freedom in South Africa."

Tutu did not appear in public often lately. But he still fought for what he believed in. He supported equal rights for LGBT people. He wanted everyone to have equal education. He also supported the right to choose when to die.

Tutu was a popular religious leader. He laughed a lot and was easy to talk to. But he was also very strong in his beliefs. He often criticized the political party in charge of South Africa, the African National Congress.

text: Covid regulations currently in force in South Africa would restrict attendance at the funeral to a maximum of 100, church authorities said, explaining that “only a fraction of those who want to be there can be accommodated in the cathedral.” The service will be an Anglican requiem mass, “as Archbishop emeritus Desmond wanted”, led by Michael Nuttall, the retired bishop of Natal, who was known as “number 2 to Tutu”. The close relationship between Nuttall and Tutu in the 1980s “modelled how a white leader could work for and closely with a black leader,” Anglican church officials told reporters. Tutu was born in the small town of Klerksdorp, west of Johannesburg, on 7 October 1931. His career in the church began after he resigned a sought-after teaching post in protest at South Africa’s discriminatory laws in 1958, a decade after the victory of the National party in elections ushered in the apartheid system. After studying theology in the UK, where he would needlessly ask for directions only to be called “Sir” by white police officers. Tutu rose rapidly up the religious hierarchy. By the late 1970s, Tutu was one of the leaders of the freedom struggle best known overseas and played a leading role in forcing western leaders to confront the moral cost of cold war calculations that led to tacit support for white-minority rule in South Africa. In 1984, Tutu’s commitment to non-violent struggle won him the Nobel peace prize and he was appointed archbishop of Cape Town shortly afterwards When Mandela became president after South Africa’s first free elections in 1994, Tutu coined the term “Rainbow Nation” to describe his homeland and then led the truth and reconciliation commission, which revealed the horrors of apartheid. But Tutu did not spare his country’s new rulers, challenging Mandela, a close friend, over generous salaries for cabinet ministers and stridently criticising the rule of president Jacob Zuma, which ended in 2018 amid allegations of systematic graft. Tutu was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 1997 and repeatedly underwent treatment. His public appearances became rarer.
b2_text:
The rules about Covid in South Africa say that only 100 people can go to a funeral. Church leaders said that not everyone who wants to come to the funeral can fit in the church.

The funeral will be a special church service. It is what Desmond Tutu wanted. Michael Nuttall will lead the service. He used to be a bishop. People called him "number 2 to Tutu".

Nuttall and Tutu were very close in the 1980s. They showed how a white leader and a black leader could work together. Church leaders told reporters about this.

Tutu was born in a small town. The town is called Klerksdorp. It is near Johannesburg. He was born on October 7, 1931.

He used to be a teacher. He quit his job because he did not like the unfair laws in South Africa. This was in 1958. The unfair system of laws was called apartheid. It started ten years before.

Tutu studied religion in England. He sometimes asked police officers for directions, even when he knew the way. He did this to see if they would call him "Sir". This was important because he was Black and the police were white.

Tutu became more and more important in the church. In the late 1970s, he was a leader in the fight for freedom. Many people in other countries knew about him. He helped make leaders in other countries think about the bad things that were happening in South Africa. These leaders were supporting the white leaders in South Africa, even though it was wrong.

In 1984, Tutu won the Nobel Peace Prize. He believed in fighting without using violence. After that, he became the leader of the church in Cape Town.

In 1994, South Africa had its first free elections. Nelson Mandela became president. Tutu called South Africa the "Rainbow Nation". He led a group that told the truth about the bad things that happened during apartheid.

Tutu also spoke out against the new leaders of South Africa. He told Mandela that government leaders were getting paid too much money. He also criticized President Jacob Zuma, who was president until 2018. People said that Zuma was stealing money.

Tutu found out he had cancer in 1997. He had treatment many times. He did not appear in public very often anymore.

text: In one of his last this year, he emerged from hospital in a wheelchair to get a Covid-19 vaccine, waving but not offering comment. The archbishop had been in a weakened state for several months and died peacefully at 7am (0500 GMT) on Sunday, according to several of his relatives. The Nelson Mandela Foundation called Tutu “an extraordinary human being. A thinker. A leader. A shepherd.”
b2_text:
He was sick this year. He left the hospital in a wheelchair near the end of the year. He got a Covid-19 vaccine. He waved to people. He did not say anything.

The archbishop was not strong for many months. He died quietly on Sunday at 7am. This was confirmed by his family.

The Nelson Mandela Foundation spoke about Tutu. They said he was a very special person. They called him a thinker, a leader, and a shepherd. This means he guided people like a shepherd guides sheep.

text: In a terrible year for human rights in Russia, beginning with the imprisonment of the opposition leader Alexei Navalny, the closure of International Memorial stands out for its ruthlessness. Founded in the late 1980s by Andrei Sakharov and other Soviet-era dissidents, the group took the new freedoms offered under Mikhail Gorbachev and used them to reveal raw truths about the fate of millions of victims of Stalin’s repressions. It was a poignant symbol of Russia’s new openness, but for many the meaning was anything but abstract: Russians discovered the tragic fates of their parents, grandparents and great-grandparents after decades of secrecy and official cowardice. Memorial’s closure is also a potent symbol – one of Russian civil society being dismantled at lightning speed. Its leadership had hoped that public support, including from prominent Russians such as Gorbachev, would stay the Kremlin’s hand. Or that closing down an organisation dedicated to uncovering Soviet atrocities would be a step too far, even for Vladimir Putin. But on Tuesday, almost exactly 30 years after the Soviet Union was dissolved, a judge showed otherwise. “When Russia chose to take a democratic, legal path forward, I couldn’t in my darkest dreams have imagined that everything would eventually start going in reverse,” Nikita Petrov, a historian and researcher who helped found Memorial, told the Guardian last month. “Probably I was naive then.” It is not hard to see how Putin, mired in historical conflicts over Crimea, Nato expansion and the fall of the Soviet Union, the second world war and more, sees investigation of Soviet history as a threat to national security. He is far more interested in perceived historical injustices committed against Russia than in the uncomfortable truths dug up by Memorial during the organisation’s three decades of work in the Russian archives. “Our country needs an honest and conscientious understanding of the Soviet past; this is the key to its future,” the organisation wrote in a statement after its liquidation.
b2_text:
Here's a B2-level rewrite of the text, following your instructions:

The year was very bad for human rights in Russia. A big problem was that Alexei Navalny, an important leader against the government, was put in jail. Another big problem was that the group International Memorial was shut down. This was a very harsh action.

International Memorial started in the 1980s. Andrei Sakharov and other people who disagreed with the Soviet government created it. At that time, the Soviet Union was starting to allow more freedom. The group used this freedom to find out the truth about what happened to many people under Stalin. Stalin was a leader who killed or hurt millions.

The group was a sign that Russia was becoming more open. It helped Russians learn about the sad stories of their families. For many years, these stories were secret because the government was afraid to tell the truth.

Closing Memorial shows that Russian society is changing very quickly. The leaders of Memorial thought people would support them. They hoped important people, like Gorbachev, would help them. They also thought the government would not close a group that was finding out about bad things from the past. They believed that would be too much, even for President Putin.

But on Tuesday, a judge decided to close the group. This was almost exactly 30 years after the Soviet Union ended. Nikita Petrov helped start Memorial. He is a historian who studies the past. He told a newspaper that he never thought things would get so bad. He said he was probably too hopeful in the past.

It is easy to see why President Putin does not like Memorial. He is very concerned about the past, like Crimea, NATO, and the end of the Soviet Union. He thinks that looking into the past of the Soviet Union is a danger to Russia. He cares more about things he thinks were unfair to Russia in the past. He does not care about the truths that Memorial found in the Russian archives.

After the group was closed, Memorial said something. They said that Russia needs to understand its past honestly. They think this is important for the future.

text: In place of Memorial, which spoke out eloquently and aggressively about mass atrocities, the state is creating a more manicured and careful presentation of the deaths of millions, one that condemns their deaths more than their murders, identifying victims but not their killers. The Russian government would like to portray Memorial’s closure as a simple, bureaucratic extension of its “foreign agents” laws. But on Tuesday a prosecutor in court made the political motive explicit, saying in an impassioned speech that Memorial was “mendaciously portraying the USSR as a terrorist state”. “Why should we, the descendants of the victors, have to see the vindication of traitors to their homeland and Nazi henchmen?” the prosecutor asked. A lawyer for Memorial said it reminded him of a 1930s show trial. Memorial’s leadership has said it is useless trying to understand which of the government’s red lines it crossed to prompt the authorities to shut it down. Some believe it has to do with its archival and historical work on Soviet terror, others with its support for political prisoners such as Navalny. Yet the truth is that Memorial has continued to do what it did since day one, while it is Russia that has changed again, perhaps ending a brief window when it would tolerate an independent reckoning of its past. “It speaks to the fears of the government that it is no longer willing to tolerate the honest accounting of its conduct that Memorial provides,” said Kenneth Roth, the head of Human Rights Watch. “If that mirror is too awful to look at, the answer is to change the conduct, not to shatter the mirror.”
b2_text:
Instead of Memorial, the government wants something different. Memorial talked strongly about terrible things that happened to many people. The new group will talk about deaths in a more careful way.

This new group will say the deaths were bad. But it will not say who killed the people. It will name the people who died, but not the people who did the killing.

The Russian government wants people to think closing Memorial was simple. They say it was because of rules about "foreign agents."

But in court, a lawyer showed the real reason. He said Memorial was lying about the USSR. He said Memorial was saying the USSR was like a terrorist country.

The lawyer asked why people should see traitors being praised. He said these traitors helped the Nazis.

A lawyer for Memorial said this reminded him of a trial from the 1930s. These trials were not fair.

The people who lead Memorial do not know why the government closed them. They do not know what they did wrong.

Some people think it is because of Memorial's work about Soviet terror. Others think it is because Memorial helps political prisoners like Navalny.

But Memorial has always done the same thing. Russia has changed. Russia used to let people talk honestly about the past. Maybe that time is over.

Kenneth Roth from Human Rights Watch said something important. He said the government is afraid of the honest stories Memorial tells.

He said the government does not want to see the truth about what it did. He said if the truth is too bad, the government should change its actions. It should not try to hide the truth.

text: A handful of local administrations in Spain have become among the first in western Europe to offer menstrual leave to their employees, in an attempt to strike a better balance between workplace demands and period pains. This year the Catalan city of Girona became the first in the country to consider flexible working arrangements for any employee experiencing discomfort due to periods. In June it announced a deal with its more than 1,300 municipal employees to allow women, trans men and non-binary individuals to take up to eight hours menstrual leave a month, with the caveat that any time used must be recovered within a span of three months. “Girona is known for many things and I think today we’re adding a new item to the list as we pioneer the approval of menstrual leave,” the city’s deputy mayor, Maria Àngels Planas, said at the time. “We are eliminating the taboo that exists around menstruation and the pain that some women suffer – that we suffer – during menstruation.” Soon afterwards the Catalan municipalities of Ripoll and Les Borges Blanques announced similar policies. In September the eastern Spanish city of Castellón de la Plana said it had signed an agreement with its 1,500 municipal workers that included a menstrual leave policy similar to Girona’s after requests from several employees. Period policies have long been enshrined in law in many parts of Asia, often rooted in concerns that workplace demands could hinder women’s ability to bear children. In 2016 the Guardian spoke to several women in Japan and China who said they were reluctant to use the entitlement over fears that doing so would antagonise male colleagues or damage their chances of a promotion. That same year Coexist, a social enterprise in Bristol, said it would become one of the first workplaces in the west to embrace menstrual leave, hoping to do away with an office culture that forced employees to choose between working while grappling with severe menstrual symptoms or using sick days or holiday. The decision triggered global debate over the policy’s merits, even as managers at Coexist reported increased commitment and productivity, and research suggested as many as 14% of women had taken time off from work or school due to periods. It was against this backdrop that the local workers union in Girona first proposed the measure.
b2_text:
Some towns in Spain are starting to offer "menstrual leave" to their workers. This is new in Europe. Menstrual leave means women can take time off work when they have pain from their periods.

The city of Girona in Spain was the first to think about this. They wanted to help workers who felt bad because of their periods.

In June, Girona made an agreement with its workers. The agreement said women, trans men, and non-binary people could take up to eight hours of menstrual leave each month. But, they have to work those hours back within three months.

Maria Àngels Planas is the deputy mayor of Girona. She said Girona is doing something new by approving menstrual leave. She said they are talking openly about periods and the pain some women have.

After Girona, two other towns in Spain, Ripoll and Les Borges Blanques, also made similar rules.

In September, the city of Castellón de la Plana said they also agreed to menstrual leave. They have 1,500 workers. The workers asked for this rule. It is like the rule in Girona.

In some countries in Asia, menstrual leave has been a law for a long time. This is because people thought work could make it harder for women to have babies.

In 2016, a newspaper talked to women in Japan and China. The women said they did not want to use menstrual leave. They were worried that men at work would be angry. They also thought it could hurt their chances of getting a better job.

In 2016, a company in England called Coexist also started offering menstrual leave. They wanted to change the work culture. Before, women had to choose between working when they felt very bad or using sick days.

This idea caused a lot of discussion around the world. But, the managers at Coexist said workers were more dedicated and worked better. Studies showed that many women have missed work or school because of their periods.

The workers union in Girona thought about all of this when they suggested menstrual leave.

text: “There was a lot of controversy,” said Sílvia Rubio of the Intersindical-CSC union. Union reps initially considered asking for up to two days of leave a month, but the idea was quashed owing to concerns that it might make employers more reluctant to hire women or give them decision-making roles. “To avoid any discrimination based on sex, we made it so that any hours used would be made up later,” said Rubio. The negotiations with the city council proved another obstacle, forcing them to whittle down their initial request of 16 hours a month to eight hours. But what surprised many of them was that the policy was also a tough sell among some of their colleagues. “There was a lot of conflict,” she said. “We had women who said: ‘My husband has migraines, why can’t he take this leave?’” Others worried the policy would stigmatise women or brand menstruation as something that is always painful. Rubio responded by pointing to the wider picture. “We think it’s fantastic that we’ve achieved this. This is a women’s issue around the globe, there’s a lot of embarrassment around it and nobody is tackling it. We managed to do it,” she said. “But we don’t want the struggle to end here.” Instead she saw the policy as a first step towards building a workplace culture that would allow greater flexibility to address needs ranging from chronic illness to care obligations. “All of this ends up being a journey to improve workplaces for both women and men, and in both the public and the private sector.”
b2_text:
Sílvia Rubio works for a union called Intersindical-CSC. She said there were many problems with a new idea.

At first, the union wanted women to have two days off each month. But some people did not like this idea. They thought companies might not want to hire women. They worried companies would not give women important jobs.

Rubio said they changed the idea to stop unfairness. Now, women can take hours off, but they must work those hours later.

It was hard to talk to the city council. The union first wanted 16 hours off each month. But they had to change it to eight hours.

Some people in the union did not like the idea either. This was surprising. Rubio said there were arguments.

Some women said their husbands have headaches. They asked why men could not have the same time off. Other women worried the idea would make women look bad. They thought it would make periods seem like something always painful.

Rubio said this is a big step forward. She said it is a women's issue all over the world. Many people are embarrassed to talk about it. She said they did something important.

Rubio does not want the work to stop here. She thinks this idea is a beginning. It can help make workplaces better. People can be more flexible with problems like sickness or taking care of family.

Rubio wants to make workplaces better for everyone. This includes both women and men. It includes jobs in the government and in private companies.

text: France has registered a national and European record for new coronavirus infections as the Omicron variant fuels a surge in cases across the continent, with multiple countries hitting new highs. France on Wednesday reported 208,000 cases in the previous 24 hours, up from its previous record of almost 180,000 set the day before. “This means that 24 hours a day, day and night, every second in our country, two French people are diagnosed positive for the coronavirus,” said the health minister, Olivier Véran. “We have never experienced such a situation,” he said, calling the increase “dizzying”. He said the situation in France’s hospitals was already worrying because of the Delta variant. Although the “massive wave” of Omicron cases had yet to have an impact on the healthcare system, he said it would inevitably do so eventually. The UK, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Denmark and Greece have all reported new case records this week, while beyond Europe the rolling seven-day average of new cases in the US hit a high of 267,000 on Tuesday, with Omicron accounting for 59% of these. New infections in Australia rose to nearly 18,300 on Wednesday, eclipsing the previous high of about 11,300 a day earlier. The prime minister, Scott Morrison, said the country needed “a gear change”. The World Health Organization (WHO) said the simultaneous circulation of the Delta and Omicron variants was driving an alarming wave of infections that could lead to increases in hospitalisation and deaths. Its director general, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, said he was “highly concerned that Omicron, spreading at the same time as Delta, is leading to a tsunami of cases”. The WHO has said Omicron poses a “very high” risk and could submerge health systems. Studies in Britain, South Africa and Denmark suggest Omicron is less deadly than some of its predecessors, but the huge numbers of people testing positive mean hospitals in some countries might soon be overwhelmed and businesses could struggle to carry on operating because of workers having to quarantine. The rapid transmission rate of the new variant is forcing governments to find a delicate balance between reimposing restrictions to protect hospitals and keeping economies and societies open.
b2_text:
France has a record number of new COVID-19 cases. This is a record for France and for Europe. The Omicron variant is making cases increase quickly.

On Wednesday, France said there were 208,000 new cases in one day. The day before, there were almost 180,000 cases. That was also a record.

The health minister said that every second, two people in France are getting the virus. He said they have never seen so many cases. He called the increase "very fast."

The health minister said that hospitals in France are already worried because of the Delta variant. He said that Omicron will also affect the hospitals soon.

The UK, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Denmark, and Greece also have new records for cases this week. In the US, there are also many new cases. On Tuesday, the average was 267,000 new cases per day. Omicron is 59% of these cases.

In Australia, there were almost 18,300 new cases on Wednesday. This is more than the old record of 11,300 cases. The Prime Minister said Australia needs to change how they are dealing with the virus.

The World Health Organization (WHO) said that Delta and Omicron are spreading at the same time. This is causing many new infections. More people may need to go to the hospital and some people may die.

The head of the WHO said he is worried that Omicron is spreading fast. He said it is like a "tsunami" of cases because it is happening at the same time as Delta.

The WHO said Omicron is a "very high" risk. It could make hospitals unable to help everyone.

Studies say Omicron might not be as dangerous as other versions of the virus. However, many people are getting sick. Hospitals in some countries might get too full. Businesses may have problems because workers have to stay home.

The new variant spreads very quickly. Governments are trying to find a good way to stop the virus and keep the economy working. They want to protect hospitals, but they also want people to be able to work and live normally.

text: Spain reduced its Covid self-isolation period to seven days from 10, even as the number of new infections hit record highs, after businesses expressed fears the Omicron surge would leave them with mounting staff shortages. The Italian cabinet decided on Wednesday night to scrap the isolation period for people who have received three shots of a Covid vaccine and are subsequently exposed to someone who has tested positive. The cabinet also tightened measures against the unvaccinated, and from 10 January a health pass proving immunisation or recovery from coronavirus will be required when travelling by bus, metro, train and taking domestic flights. Meanwhile, a proposal to tighten measures against unvaccinated workers was rejected. Authorities reported another new record daily tally of 98,030 cases on Wednesday. French MPs on Wednesday started debating a new law that would allow only vaccinated people to enter bars, restaurants, cinemas, museums, sports arenas and other public venues, with a negative Covid test no longer to be accepted. Italy is one of several countries to have cancelled or restricted public celebrations since the resurgence of the virus. Greece, which has also banned Christmas and new year festivities in public places, on Wednesday imposed new restrictions on the hospitality sector, bringing forward measures planned for early January, after authorities announced a new daily record of 21,657 cases, more than double Monday’s figure. Bars, nightclubs and restaurants will have to close at midnight, with no standing customers and no music, with the exception of New Year’s Eve when they can stay open until 2am. “These measures, if they are applied in our entirety, will allow us from mid-January to go back to our normal lives,” said the health minister, Thanos Plevris. Some countries are still waiting for the Omicron wave to hit. Case numbers are still falling in Germany, but its health minister, Karl Lauterbach, said the true number could be much higher because fewer tests were being done over the holiday season. He said the real incidence was “two or three times as high” as Wednesday’s reported rate of 205 Covid cases per 100,000 people over seven days, the lowest since November, adding that a sharp jump was expected “within a very short period of time”.
b2_text:
Spain has changed its COVID rules. People who have COVID now only need to stay home for seven days instead of ten. This is because many new people are getting sick. Businesses worry they will not have enough workers.

Italy has also made some changes. People who have had three COVID vaccine shots do not need to stay home if they are near someone with COVID. But, Italy has made rules stricter for people who have not been vaccinated. Starting January 10, people need a health pass to travel. This pass shows they have had the vaccine or got better from COVID. You will need it for buses, trains, and planes inside Italy. A plan to make rules stricter for unvaccinated workers was not approved. Italy reported a lot of new COVID cases on Wednesday, 98,030 in one day.

In France, lawmakers are talking about a new law. This law would only let people with vaccines go to certain places. These places include bars, restaurants, movie theaters, and sports places. You would not be able to use a negative COVID test to enter.

Italy and other countries have stopped or made changes to public parties because COVID is spreading again.

Greece has also stopped Christmas and New Year's parties in public. They now have new rules for restaurants and bars. These rules started earlier than planned. Greece had many new COVID cases, 21,657 in one day. This is more than double the number from Monday. Bars, clubs, and restaurants must close at midnight. People cannot stand up inside, and there is no music. But on New Year's Eve, they can stay open until 2 AM. The health minister said these rules should help them get back to normal in mid-January.

Some countries are waiting for the Omicron wave of COVID to arrive. In Germany, the number of COVID cases is going down. But the health minister said the real number might be higher. This is because fewer people are getting tested during the holidays. He thinks the real number of cases is two or three times higher than what they reported. He said the number of cases is expected to go up soon.

text: On Tuesday Germany closed nightclubs and ordered organisers of sports events to hold them behind closed doors. It also limited private gatherings to 10 vaccinated people, or just two households if an unvaccinated person is present. The rules came on top of restrictions already hitting the unvaccinated, who are barred from shops, restaurants and cultural events. Lauterbach said the rules may have to be toughened further, as existing measures “will not be enough to prevent a significant rise in Omicron cases”. In Belgium, however, where case numbers are also relatively low, the government reversed course on Wednesday, allowing theatres and cinemas to reopen after a court suspended their closure. Meanwhile, other European countries are still grappling with the Delta variant. Poland reported 794 Covid-related deaths on Wednesday, the highest number in the fourth wave of the pandemic. The deputy health minister, Waldemar Kraska, said more than 75% of those who died were unvaccinated.
b2_text:
On Tuesday, Germany made new rules because of the virus. Nightclubs had to close. Sports events could not have people watching.

People could only meet in small groups. If everyone was vaccinated, ten people could meet. If someone was not vaccinated, only two families could meet.

People who are not vaccinated already have rules. They cannot go to shops, restaurants, or shows.

A German leader, Lauterbach, said the rules might need to be stricter. He said the current rules may not stop the virus from spreading. Omicron is a new type of virus.

In Belgium, things changed. The government first closed theatres and cinemas. But a court said they could open again. So, theatres and cinemas are now open in Belgium.

Other countries in Europe are still having problems with the Delta virus.

Poland said that 794 people died from the virus on Wednesday. This is the highest number in the last few months. A health leader in Poland, Waldemar Kraska, said most of the people who died were not vaccinated.

text: Ukrainian forces appear to have edged closer to recapturing the key-Russian controlled city of Kreminna in Luhansk province as heavy fighting continued in the east and south of the country. The regional governor of Luhansk, Serhiy Haidai, said fighters in part of the city controlled by Russian command were forced to retreat to Rubizhne, a town a few miles to the south-east, as a result of Ukrainian military pressure. “The Russians understand that if they lose Kreminna, their entire line of defence will fall,” Haidai wrote on the Telegram messaging app on Tuesday. “The Russian occupation troops managed to build a very powerful defence in a month, even a little more. They are bringing there a huge amount of reserves and equipment. They are constantly renewing their forces.” The Guardian could not independently confirm the battlefield developments. Recapturing Kreminna and nearby Svatove could open the way for Kyiv to launch an offensive on Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk, two cities Ukraine lost in the summer. The fierce fighting continues amid no sign of imminent peace talks. Late on Monday Russia’s foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, said Kyiv must accept Moscow’s demands of “demilitarisation and denazification” or suffer defeat on the battlefield. Lavrov’s statements show the Kremlin has no intention of climbing down from its maximalist goals of regime change in Ukraine, despite Vladimir Putin’s claims on Sunday that Russia was ready for talks to end the war. In its daily military briefing on Tuesday, Britain’s defence ministry said Russian troops continued to focus their efforts on capturing the city of Bakhmut in the Donetsk region. Russian soldiers, alongside fighters from the Wagner private military group, have been trying to seize Bakhmut since July, after reaching the outskirts of the city. Bakhmut has been largely ravaged after nearly five months of fighting and has been referred to by both sides as the “Bakhmut meat-grinder”. The battle for Bakhmut is seen as an important test for the Wagner head, Yevgeny Prigozhin, who is believed to have recruited thousands of Russian convicts to help storm the city.
b2_text:
Ukrainian soldiers are getting closer to taking back Kreminna. Kreminna is a city in the Luhansk area. Russia controls this city now. There is a lot of fighting in the east and south of Ukraine.

Serhiy Haidai is in charge of the Luhansk area. He said that Russian soldiers had to move back. They moved to a town called Rubizhne. Rubizhne is close to Kreminna. The Ukrainian army made them move.

Haidai said that Russia knows it is important to keep Kreminna. If Russia loses Kreminna, it will lose its defense line. Russian soldiers built strong defenses in Kreminna. They have been building it for over a month. They are sending more soldiers and equipment there.

It is hard to know exactly what is happening in the fighting. Taking back Kreminna and Svatove could help Ukraine. Then Ukraine could attack Sievierodonetsk and Lysychansk. Ukraine lost these cities in the summer.

The fighting is very bad. There is no sign of peace talks soon. Sergei Lavrov is a Russian leader. He said Ukraine must agree to Russia's demands. He wants Ukraine to become less strong. He also used the word "denazification." This means he wants to change the government. If Ukraine does not agree, Russia will defeat them.

Lavrov's words show that Russia still wants to control Ukraine. Russia wants to change the government there. Vladimir Putin said Russia was ready to talk about ending the war. But Lavrov's words show this is not true.

The British defense ministry gave an update. They said that Russian soldiers are trying to take Bakhmut. Bakhmut is a city in the Donetsk area. Russian soldiers and Wagner group fighters are trying to capture Bakhmut. They have been trying since July.

Bakhmut is badly damaged from the fighting. The fighting has been going on for almost five months. People call Bakhmut the "Bakhmut meat-grinder" because so many soldiers are getting hurt or killed there.

The fight for Bakhmut is important for Yevgeny Prigozhin. He is the leader of the Wagner group. He has hired many Russian prisoners to fight in Bakhmut.

text: Prigozhin has previously criticised the Russian defence ministry for its performance in Ukraine and has lauded Wagner as the country’s most capable fighting force. In a video published on Monday and purportedly filmed near Bakhmut that will further fuel speculations over tensions within the Russian forces, two apparent Wagner soldiers are seen insulting the chief of general staff, Valery Gerasimov. “You are … the damn devil. We have nothing to fight with, we have no shells,” one of the men is heard saying. The Guardian could not independently verify the footage, but when asked about the video by Russian journalists, Prigozhin appeared to express his approval for the actions of the soldiers, saying he travelled to Bakhmut to meet them. “The guys asked me to convey that when you sit in a warm office, the problems of the frontline are hard to hear,” Prigozhin said in a statement, in an apparent dig at the country’s top military command. Last Thursday, Ukraine claimed Russia had “relocated” some of its aircraft away from the Engels airfield, which Moscow said was struck by a Ukrainian drone a day earlier, resulting in the death of three Russian servicemen. “After yesterday’s well-known events, we see that the planes are dispersed there, namely strategic aviation … Of course, a certain number of aircraft still remain there, but many of them have already been relocated to various airfields,” Col Yuriy Ignat, the chief spokesperson for the Ukrainian Air Force Command, told Ukrainian media. Elsewhere, Russia’s security services claimed they had “liquidated” four Ukrainian soldiers who were on a reconnaissance mission in Russia’s southern Bryansk region, near Ukraine’s border.
