If confirmed, the incident sheds light on the ongoing activities of Ukrainian saboteurs inside Russian territory. Since the start of the war, a number of military targets, including oil and weapon depots have been damaged after catching fire. Kyiv does not publicly admit to attacks inside Russia but has previously cheered such incidents as payback.
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, aiming for CEFR B2 level:

Prigozhin has said bad things about the Russian army. He thinks his Wagner group fights better in Ukraine.

A video was released on Monday. People think it was filmed near Bakhmut. It shows two men who seem to be Wagner soldiers. They are saying bad things about Valery Gerasimov. He is a top general in the Russian army.

The men are angry. One man says Gerasimov is like a devil. He says they do not have enough weapons or shells to fight.

The Guardian newspaper could not be sure if the video was real. Russian reporters asked Prigozhin about the video. He seemed to agree with what the soldiers did. He said he went to Bakhmut to meet them.

Prigozhin said the soldiers want people to know about the problems at the front. He seemed to be criticizing the army leaders who sit in comfortable offices.

Last Thursday, Ukraine said Russia moved some planes. The planes were at the Engels airfield. Russia said Ukraine attacked the airfield with a drone the day before. Three Russian soldiers died in the attack.

A Ukrainian spokesperson said many planes have been moved to different airfields. Some planes are still at the Engels airfield.

In another place, Russia said they killed four Ukrainian soldiers. The soldiers were on a secret mission in the Bryansk region. This region is in Russia, near the border with Ukraine.

If this is true, it shows that Ukrainian soldiers are doing secret things inside Russia.

Since the war started, some military places in Russia have been damaged. These places include oil and weapon storage areas. They caught fire.

Ukraine does not say they attacked these places. But they are happy when these things happen inside Russia. They think it is like getting revenge.

text: Also on Tuesday, Putin concluded his two-day “informal summit” in St Petersburg with the heads of the Commonwealth of Independent States, a Moscow-led group consisting of former Soviet states, by gifting the eight leaders present gold rings. The meeting came on the back of growing unease between the Russian president and the rest of the CIS bloc, as nations have sought to distance themselves from Moscow’s faltering war.
b2_text:
Okay, here's the rewritten text at a B2 CEFR level:

On Tuesday, Putin finished a meeting in St Petersburg. The meeting lasted two days. It was a meeting with leaders from the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). The CIS is a group of countries. These countries used to be part of the Soviet Union. Russia leads this group.

Putin gave the eight leaders gold rings as gifts.

Recently, some countries in the CIS have been worried. They are worried about Russia's war. They want to be separate from Russia. They do not want to be connected to the war. This made the meeting tense.

text: European countries are preparing to scale up the monitoring of potential new coronavirus variants from China, as Spain and France brought back mandatory testing at airports in response to Beijing’s rapid rollback of anti-infection measures. The two countries on Friday followed Italy’s lead by requiring arrivals from China to show a negative test result, though unlike Rome, Spain makes exceptions for those who can prove they are fully vaccinated. At a press conference announcing Spain’s new measures, the country’s health minister, Carolina Darias, also said she was pushing to revise the conditions that had to be met in order for travellers to obtain the EU’s digital Covid certificate. A rise in infections across China and doubts over the regime’s official data have prompted the return of Covid checks in several countries outside the EU, including the US, India, Israel, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan. The UK has announced a similar move. Chinese state media said the return of such testing requirements for travellers from China was “discriminatory” and politically motivated in an attempt to undermine China’s reopening. In Brussels, Berlin and Paris, however, officials said this week it was important to be vigilant but too early to raise alarm over the outbreak in the world’s most populous country. Germany’s health minister, Karl Lauterbach, said it was “not yet necessary” to bring back mandatory testing for travellers coming into the borderless Schengen area from China via Germany. Data on Covid variants provided by Beijing was not sufficiently reliable, the centre-left politician said. “And therefore we very much have to rely on doing that ourselves,” for example by carefully looking at individual flights, he said. The European Commission’s health policy chief on Friday urged the EU’s 27-member states to consider scaling up gene sequencing of Covid-19 infections and monitoring of wastewater, including from airports, to detect any new variants that could be brought in from China. In a letter to health ministers of the EUmember states, Stella Kyriakides said the bloc should be “very vigilant” when China lifts travel restrictions on 8 January, since reliable epidemiological and testing data for China were quite scarce.
b2_text:
Many countries in Europe are getting ready to watch for new types of coronavirus. These new types could come from China. Spain and France are now making people get tested at airports again. This is because China is stopping its strict rules about the virus.

On Friday, Spain and France did what Italy did before. They want people coming from China to show a test result that says they do not have the virus. But Spain is different from Italy. Spain does not require tests for people who have proof they are vaccinated.

The health minister of Spain, Carolina Darias, spoke at a meeting. She said she wants to change the rules for the EU's digital Covid certificate. People need this certificate to travel easily.

More people in China are getting sick. Some people do not trust the numbers that China is sharing about the virus. Because of this, some countries are checking people for the virus again. These countries include the US, India, Israel, Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan. The UK will also start doing this.

Chinese news said that these tests for travelers from China are unfair. They said these tests are done for political reasons. They think other countries are trying to hurt China's plan to open up again.

But in Brussels, Berlin, and Paris, leaders said it is important to be careful. They said it is too soon to be very worried about the virus in China. China has the most people in the world.

The health minister of Germany, Karl Lauterbach, said that mandatory tests for travelers from China are "not yet necessary." People can travel to Germany from China through other countries in Europe without showing their passports. This area is called the Schengen area.

Mr. Lauterbach said that the information about the virus that China is giving is not good enough. He said that Germany needs to check for the virus themselves. They can do this by looking at people on airplanes carefully.

The person in charge of health for the European Commission, Stella Kyriakides, spoke on Friday. She asked the 27 countries in the EU to check the virus more carefully. She wants them to study the virus's genes and check the water from airports. This can help find any new types of the virus that might come from China.

Ms. Kyriakides wrote a letter to the health ministers of the EU countries. She said the EU should be "very careful" when China stops its travel rules on January 8. She said that it is hard to get good information about the virus and tests in China.

text: In the letter, Kyriakides advised ministers to assess their practices on gene sequencing of the coronavirus “as an immediate step”, Reuters reported. Earlier in the week, Italy’s far-right prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, argued that requiring Covid tests for all passengers from China was “only effective if it is taken at the European level”, noting that many people arrive in Italy on connecting flights through other European countries. After an announcement made by Italy’s health ministry on Thursday, travellers from China are obliged to show a negative test result upon embarking on their flight and to take a second antigen test upon their arrival.
b2_text:
Here is the text rewritten for CEFR B2 level:

Kyriakides wrote a letter to ministers. Reuters news said she told them to check how they study the coronavirus genes. This should happen quickly.

Earlier in the week, Giorgia Meloni spoke. She is the leader of Italy. She said everyone from China should take a Covid test. But she said this only works if all of Europe does it together. Many people fly to Italy through other European countries.

Italy's health ministry said something on Thursday. People flying from China must now show a negative Covid test before their flight. They must also take another quick test when they arrive in Italy.

text: Brazil has been gearing up for one of the most monumental new years in its history as the South America nation prepared to both welcome a new president and say goodbye to one of its most famous sons. Huge crowds are expected in Brasilia on 1 January to see Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva inaugurated for a four-year term, while a day later football fans will gather in Santos to bid farewell to Pelé, the football legend who died on Thursday. Edson Arantes do Nascimento died of multiple organ failure after battling colon cancer for more than a year. The 82-year-old former Santos and New York Cosmos player had been in hospital for more than a month. “The city is in mourning,” said Walter Dias, an 87-year-old journalist who covered Santos during their glory days in the 1960s and remained a friend to both Pelé and his family. “Everyone here is sad because at the end of the day Pelé was such a part of our lives. He brought us so much joy. It’s like we’ve lost a member of the family.” Brazilian funerals customarily take place within 24 hours of bereavement, but Pelé’s family reportedly asked for more time to allow family members to gather for what is expected to be an emotional farewell. Pelé was married three times and had seven children and many more grandchildren. Some live in the United States and others are scattered across Brazil, a nation almost as big as Europe. Big crowds are expected to converge in the city and surrounding area that is home to almost 2 million people, and the world’s media will also be there in massive numbers. The outgoing president, Jair Bolsonaro, who was named Jair after the former Santos player Jair da Rosa Pinto, is not expected to attend the funeral. Reports on Friday said the far-right president would fly to Florida in the coming hours and avoid handing over the sash of office to his leftist successor. In his final address as president on Friday, Bolsonaro criticised Lula’s new cabinet as well as one of his own supporters who was caught in an alleged plot to blow up a fuel lorry ahead of Sunday’s inauguration.
b2_text:
Brazil is getting ready for a very important New Year. The country will welcome a new president. They will also say goodbye to a famous person.

Many people will go to Brasilia on January 1. They will see Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva become president. He will be president for four years.

The next day, football fans will meet in Santos. They will say goodbye to Pelé. Pelé was a great football player. He died on Thursday.

Pelé's real name was Edson Arantes do Nascimento. He died because his organs stopped working. He had colon cancer for over a year. He was 82 years old. He used to play for Santos and New York Cosmos. He was in the hospital for over a month.

Walter Dias is a journalist. He is 87 years old. He wrote about Santos when they were very good in the 1960s. He was friends with Pelé and his family. He said that the city is sad. Everyone feels bad because Pelé was important in their lives. He made them happy. It is like losing a family member.

Usually, funerals in Brazil happen quickly. But Pelé's family asked for more time. They want all family members to come and say goodbye. It will be a sad goodbye.

Pelé was married three times. He had seven children and many grandchildren. Some live in the United States. Others live in different parts of Brazil. Brazil is a big country, almost as big as Europe.

Many people will come to the city of Santos. About 2 million people live there. Many news reporters from all over the world will also be there.

The current president is Jair Bolsonaro. He is named after a football player, Jair da Rosa Pinto. He will not go to the funeral. He will fly to Florida. He will not give the president's symbol to the new president.

On Friday, Bolsonaro spoke for the last time as president. He said bad things about Lula's new team. He also talked about a supporter of his. This supporter tried to blow up a truck with fuel. This happened before the new president starts.

text: That terrorist threat has darkened the mood in Brasilia, and the weekend is set to be both tense and festive – but whatever happens could be overshadowed by the following day’s events. Although dignitaries from more than 120 nations are due to attend Lula’s inauguration, Pelé’s death is a truly global story and preparations for his farewell are akin to a state funeral. Presidents, prime ministers, sports stars and former teammates all sent messages of love and sympathy after the news of his death broke on Thursday afternoon. Bolsonaro decreed three days of state mourning. The incoming leader, Lula, said: “Few Brazilians have taken our country’s name as far as he has. However different their language was to Portuguese, foreigners from all over the planet always found a way of pronouncing the magic word: ‘Pelé.’” In a sombre message, the president of Santos, the club where Pelé made his name, said he would never be forgotten. “Pelé did not die, Pelé is eternal and he will live in our hearts forever,” Andres Rueda said. “He came here to Santos as a boy, and he left as a king. He was idolised not just by the Santos nation but by the whole of Brazil and by all football fans. Edson, rest in peace. Pelé, keep watching over us.” Santos said Pelé’s body is being held at the Albert Einstein hospital in São Paulo until the early hours of Monday morning, when it will be taken 50 miles down the coast to the club’s Vila Belmiro stadium. The coffin will be laid in the middle of the pitch and fans will be allowed into the ground to pay their respects. His body will be laid out in the centre circle for 24 hours before being taken for a private family funeral at 10am on Tuesday. The funeral cortege will leave the ground and be driven through the streets of the port city, along the road where Pelé’s mother, Celeste, who celebrated her 100th birthday in November, still resides.
b2_text:
There is a worry about terrorists in Brasilia. This makes the city feel unsafe. The weekend will be exciting, but also stressful. Something else might become more important than the weekend.

Lula will become president soon. People from many countries will come to his celebration. But Pelé died. This is big news all over the world. People are getting ready to say goodbye to him. It will be like a funeral for a very important person.

Presidents and other leaders sent messages. Sports stars and old teammates sent messages too. They all said they were sorry about Pelé's death. This happened on Thursday. Bolsonaro said the country will be sad for three days.

Lula will be the new president. He said Pelé made Brazil famous. People all over the world could say his name, even if they spoke a different language. They knew the name "Pelé".

The president of Santos said Pelé will always be remembered. Santos is the soccer club where Pelé became famous. Andres Rueda said Pelé did not die. He will live forever in people's hearts. Pelé came to Santos as a young boy. He left as a king. People loved him in Santos, in Brazil, and all over the world. Andres Rueda told Edson (Pelé's real name) to rest in peace. He asked Pelé to watch over them.

Pelé's body is in a hospital in São Paulo. It will stay there until Monday morning. Then, it will be taken to the Santos soccer stadium. This is about 50 miles away. The coffin will be placed on the soccer field. People can come to the stadium to say goodbye to Pelé.

His body will stay there for one day. Then, on Tuesday morning, his family will have a private funeral. After the funeral, the cars with the body will drive through the city. They will go past the house where Pelé's mother lives. She is 100 years old.

text: The former athlete of the century will be laid to rest at the Memorial Necrópole Ecumênica, a vertical cemetery with space for 18,000 bodies that claims to be the tallest in the world. Pelé chose and paid for a space on the ninth floor of the building almost two decades ago, according to the newspaper O Globo. He wanted to be laid to rest on the ninth floor because his father, Dondinho, wore the No 9 shirt as a player. The location has a view overlooking the Vila Belmiro stadium and was chosen by Pelé because it transmitted “spiritual peace and tranquility” and “didn’t look like a cemetery”, O Globo said. “I think there will be lots of people,” Dias said of the public commemoration. “The city is preparing and people will turn out. Pelé is loved by people here and by fans of the club because he projected the name of Santos all over the world.”
b2_text:
The famous football player, Pelé, has died. He will be buried in a special place. This place is called the Memorial Necrópole Ecumênica. It is a very tall building where people are buried.

This building has space for many people. It says it is the tallest cemetery in the world.

Pelé chose this place a long time ago. He wanted to be buried on the ninth floor. He paid for this space. This was almost twenty years ago.

His father was also a football player. His father wore the number nine shirt. That is why Pelé wanted to be on the ninth floor.

From this place, you can see the Vila Belmiro stadium. Pelé chose this place because it made him feel calm. He said it felt peaceful there. He also said it did not look like a normal cemetery.

Someone named Dias talked about the event. He thinks many people will come. The city is getting ready. People will come to remember Pelé.

People in the city love Pelé. Fans of his football club love him too. He made the city of Santos famous all over the world.

text: As 2022 began, while swaths of the world were struggling with Covid and a looming war in Ukraine, life in China was relatively calm. Xi Jinping’s zero-Covid strategy was working and cases were low. There were lockdowns but they were orderly and people were compliant. This stability was exactly what Xi probably hoped would surround his taking of a historic third term, at the helm of a rising China. Economic dominance, domestic control, an annexed Taiwan, and increased global influence were all on the agenda. But as the year closes and 2023 begins, China is, instead, entering uncharted territory. In the last 12 months there have been significant housing and economic issues, the Taiwan strait crisis in August, western sanctions on China’s human rights abuses and US curbs on its burgeoning chips industry, and a messy friendship with Russia. Xi took his third term, but weeks later protests swept the country, featuring astonishingly brave acts of dissent and appearing to herald the abrupt end of the zero-Covid policy. Politically, 2022 was supposed to be a year of glory for the Chinese president, but instead it “gave Xi much more to worry about than to gloat over”, says the veteran China expert Jerome Cohen. “His country is in turmoil, and he has suffered a lot of damage in the eyes of the masses.” At the 20th party congress in October, Xi secured a third five-year term, becoming China’s most powerful leader since Mao Zedong. It upended what his predecessors had established specifically to prevent power centralising around an individual. He enshrined “Xi Jinping thought” as the core of the party’s platform, and purged members of a rival faction, symbolised by the bizarre removal of the faction’s leader, the former president Hu Jintao, from the Congress hall. Xi’s now unchecked political power has provoked fears over what decisions he may make while surrounded by yes-people. “Xi securing a third term is, in my view, the biggest thing for China in 2022,” says Prof Steve Tsang, director of the Soas China Institute.
b2_text:
In 2022, many countries had problems with Covid and a war in Ukraine. But China seemed peaceful at the start.

China's leader, Xi Jinping, had a plan called "zero-Covid." It kept the number of Covid cases low.

Sometimes, cities were locked down. But people followed the rules.

Xi probably wanted this calm situation as he took power for a third time. This was a big event in China.

He had big goals for China. He wanted the economy to be strong. He wanted to control the country. He also wanted to take over Taiwan and have more power in the world.

But as 2022 ends and 2023 starts, China is facing new and difficult problems.

In the past year, there have been problems with houses and the economy. There was also tension with Taiwan in August.

Other countries put rules on China because of human rights issues. The US also made rules about China's chip industry. China's friendship with Russia is also causing problems.

Xi did get his third term as leader. But then, people started protesting. They were very brave. These protests seemed to end the "zero-Covid" plan suddenly.

Politically, 2022 was supposed to be a good year for Xi. But now, he has many worries.

Jerome Cohen, a China expert, said that China is in trouble. He thinks Xi has lost respect from many people.

In October, there was a meeting called the 20th Party Congress. At this meeting, Xi got a third term. This made him the most powerful leader since Mao Zedong.

Before Xi, leaders had rules to stop one person from having too much power. But Xi changed that.

He made his own ideas, called "Xi Jinping thought," the most important ideas of the party. He also got rid of people who disagreed with him. One example was when the former president, Hu Jintao, was taken out of the meeting hall.

Now Xi has a lot of power. Some people worry about what he will do. They think he might make bad decisions because he is surrounded by people who always agree with him.

Professor Steve Tsang said that Xi getting a third term is the most important thing that happened in China in 2022.

text: “Xi may think that he has a good chart (Xi Jinping Thought) to guide China moving forward, but he is effectively taking China into uncharted territory.” The most alarming of Xi’s plans is to annex Taiwan, but analysts do not foresee any attempt to take it in the near future. The past year had a record-breaking increase in Chinese military activity towards the self-ruled democracy. In August, the Xi era’s first white paper on Taiwan reiterated the Chinese Communist party’s (CCP) willingness to use force to take the island. A visit by the US House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, to Taipei gave Beijing cause to demonstrate its force, escalating already aggressive military harassment to record levels. The US is a key player in cross-strait relations and has increased its support for Taiwan with signals about giving it “non-major Nato ally” status, and big defence spending bills to sell it weapons. Ma Chun-Wei, of Tamkang University in Taiwan, says China cannot really counter the US so instead directs reaction at Taiwan and its 23.5 million people. Cognitive and cyberwarfare and acts of economic coercion are expected to increase before Taiwan’s next presidential elections in early 2024. “China will dial up its coercive actions against Taiwan … as long as the [independence-leaning] Democratic Progressive party is in power, there is little question,” says Yun Sun, director of the China Program at the Washington-based Stimson Center thinktank. On Monday, Taiwan reported 71 Chinese air force aircraft including fighter jets and drones had entered the island’s air defence identification zone over the previous 24 hours, the largest reported incursion to date. The CCP’s moves on Taiwan have been a key reason for Xi’s plummeting relationship with the west. The party’s continued persecution of dissenters in Hong Kong and abuses in Xinjiang – which the UN’s human rights chief declared in August may amount to crimes against humanity – have also increased the division. Relations were further strained by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine just weeks after Xi and Vladimir Putin announced a “limitless” friendship, and which Beijing refused to condemn.
b2_text:
Xi Jinping has a plan for China. He calls it "Xi Jinping Thought." But some people think his plan is taking China in a new and risky direction.

One of Xi's biggest plans is to take over Taiwan. Taiwan is an island that governs itself. Some experts do not think China will attack Taiwan soon.

Last year, China's military did more near Taiwan than ever before. In August, China said it might use force to take Taiwan.

Nancy Pelosi, a leader from the United States, visited Taiwan. This made China angry. China showed its power by sending more military planes and ships near Taiwan.

The United States is important for Taiwan. The US is giving more support to Taiwan. They might call Taiwan a "non-major Nato ally." The US is also selling weapons to Taiwan.

Ma Chun-Wei is a professor in Taiwan. He says China cannot fight the US. So, China is showing its anger towards Taiwan and its people.

China might use tricks to influence Taiwan before its next election in 2024. They might use fake news online or pressure Taiwan's economy.

Yun Sun is an expert on China. She says China will put more pressure on Taiwan. This will happen as long as the Democratic Progressive party is in power in Taiwan. This party wants Taiwan to be independent.

On Monday, Taiwan said that many Chinese planes flew near the island. There were 71 planes, including fighter jets. This was the most planes ever reported at one time.

China's actions towards Taiwan have made Xi's relationship with the West worse.

China's actions in Hong Kong and Xinjiang have also caused problems. China is treating people unfairly in these places. The United Nations says China's actions in Xinjiang might be crimes against humanity.

Russia attacked Ukraine. This also made things worse. Xi and Vladimir Putin, the leader of Russia, said they were good friends. But China did not say that Russia's attack was wrong.

text: The invasion caused a political headache for Xi and has left him in a complicated spot on the world stage for as long as the war continues. He has had to balance his alliance with Putin, his wish to avoid getting caught up in anti-Russia sanctions, and the ongoing China-Russia rivalry for soft power – and trade routes – in central Asia. US officials said in March that Putin had asked China for weapons support. Beijing did not answer the call but has provided help in other ways, including apparent cooperation on propaganda and disinformation campaigns, and lobbying against western sanctions. Chinese officials have offered explicit approval of the invasion, and the two countries’ armies recently conducted joint military drills. Meanwhile, brawling diplomats have also not helped Xi’s relationship with the west. In December, China’s consul general in Manchester, England, and five other diplomats were sent home by Beijing and escaped questioning by UK police for their role in beating up a pro-Hong Kong democracy protester outside the consulate in the city in October. But global relationships still matter to Xi. After he inked his third term he hit the global meeting ground running, talking to dozens of heads of states, including Joe Biden. Cohen says Xi is trying to improve his government’s image “after too many strident and provocative policies”. Xi’s overtures will test the global community, which had taken a tougher stance on China’s human rights this year, says Maya Wang, the associate director of Human Rights Watch’s Asia division. “I worry that, after these kinds of outreach, many governments, for example Germany, would soften their approach to China, pushing human rights from the fore to the back burner, once again,” she says. For now, government stances remain tough, and the US is pushing ahead with measures, including sanctions on China’s semiconductor industry, which Japan and the Netherlands are expected to join, causing trouble for Xi’s plans to get the faltering Chinese economy back on track. Soas’s Tsang says these measures “may have longer and wider impact [than Covid] on the economy of China in 2023”. Zero-Covid restrictions and the near collapse of the property development sector punished China’s economy this year.
b2_text:
The war in Ukraine has made things hard for Xi Jinping. He is the leader of China. The war has created problems for him in the world.

Xi wants to stay friends with Putin, the leader of Russia. But he does not want to be punished with rules against Russia. China and Russia also compete for power in Asia. They both want to control trade in that area.

America said that Putin asked China for weapons. China did not give weapons to Russia. But China has helped Russia in other ways. They seem to work together to spread news. China also tries to stop rules against Russia.

Chinese leaders have said they agree with Russia's actions in Ukraine. The armies of China and Russia have practiced fighting together.

Chinese diplomats have also caused problems for Xi. A Chinese diplomat in England hurt a person who was protesting for democracy in Hong Kong. This made China's relationship with other countries worse.

But Xi still cares about global relationships. After he became leader for the third time, he talked to many leaders. He spoke with Joe Biden, the leader of America.

A person named Cohen says Xi is trying to make China look better. China has been acting too strong and causing problems.

Xi is trying to be friendly. But people are watching to see what he does. They have been worried about human rights in China.

Maya Wang from Human Rights Watch says some countries might become nicer to China. They might stop worrying about human rights.

For now, countries are still being tough on China. America is making rules against China's computer chip industry. Japan and the Netherlands will probably do the same. This will cause problems for China's economy. Xi wants to make the economy better.

Tsang says these rules might hurt China's economy more than Covid did.

China's economy was bad this year. This was because of Covid rules and problems with houses being built.

text: To address the property collapse, the CCP has allocated 1.4tn yuan (£166bn) to restarting construction projects, which Trivium analysts believe “will allow developers to start ramping up construction” and boost China’s economy. But the government will still be reckoning with the economic fallout of zero-Covid and the coming waves of outbreaks now the policy has gone. A faltering economy could further provoke domestic frustrations, which peaked in 2022 over the impact of Xi’s signature hardline zero-Covid policy. For two years China ran the strategy that allowed most people to live a largely normal life, and kept deaths low. But then the highly transmissible Omicron overwhelmed the policy, wreaking economic and social chaos. As people lost tolerance with rampant sudden and badly run lockdowns, sporadic protests broke out that were further inflamed by a string of fatal tragedies, including a quarantine bus crash and a building fire in locked-down Xinjiang. What became the most significant protests in China since 1989 were mostly against the deprivations of Covid-zero, but censorship complaints and anti-Xi sentiment also featured. The protests awakened some Chinese to the government’s treatment of their minority and dissident compatriots. “The pandemic fiasco has increased popular awareness of the party’s lack of respect for the laws and regulations it has promulgated, despite its great efforts to establish a ‘rule by law’ regime,” Cohen says. Authorities launched a swift police response to shut down dissent, but the protests seemed to have had an effect: within a week, the zero-Covid system that many thought would be in place for many more months, if not years, was abruptly dismantled. With no more lockdowns, quarantine, travel restrictions or mass testing, Covid cases have soared across China. Mass fatalities are predicted, with estimates of up to a million people dying from the virus.
b2_text:
The Chinese government wants to fix the problem of buildings falling apart. They will give 1.4 trillion yuan to start building again. This money will help companies build more things. Experts think this will help China's economy grow.

But the government still has problems. The "zero-COVID" policy hurt the economy. Now, the policy is gone, but more people are getting sick. A weak economy could make people angry.

In 2022, people were very upset about the "zero-COVID" policy. For two years, this policy helped most people live normally. It also kept the number of deaths low. But then, a new kind of COVID, called Omicron, spread quickly. This made the economy and people's lives difficult.

People did not like the sudden and badly managed lockdowns. There were some small protests. These protests became bigger after some sad accidents. One accident was a bus crash. Another was a fire in a building where people were locked down.

These protests were the biggest in China since 1989. People were mostly angry about the "zero-COVID" rules. They also complained about censorship. Some people even said they did not like the leader, Xi.

The protests made some people think about how the government treats minorities and people who disagree with them. One expert said that the COVID problems showed people that the government does not always follow its own rules, even though it says it wants to have "rule by law."

The government quickly used the police to stop the protests. But the protests seemed to work. After one week, the "zero-COVID" policy suddenly ended. Many people thought this policy would last much longer.

Now, there are no more lockdowns or travel rules. People do not have to get tested all the time. But COVID cases are increasing a lot. Experts think many people will die from the virus, maybe even one million.

text: On Monday, in his first remarks on Covid since the shift in policy, Xi urged officials to take steps to “feasibly protect people’s lives” and said: “We should launch the patriotic health campaign in a more targeted way ... fortify a community line of defence for epidemic prevention and control, and feasibly protect people’s lives, safety and health.” Trivium says what happens next with Covid and Covid policy is “the most important question” politically and economically, for China and Xi in 2023: “It’s not at all clear how this plays out.” The past year has brought far more for China than Xi would have hoped, or analysts expected. Tsang says that, in the end, events have still largely worked out for Xi, even if protests took the shine off his leadership. “He mostly got what he wanted, including not just a third term as top leader but also a leadership filled by his supporters,” says Tsang. “It is less clear that it was equally good for China, as Xi’s amassing of near dictatorial power is costing China dearly.” Additional reporting by Chi Hui Lin
b2_text:
On Monday, Xi spoke about Covid. This was his first time talking about it since the rules changed. He told leaders to help people stay alive. He said they should start a health program that focuses on what people need. This program will help stop the virus in communities. It will protect people's lives, safety, and health.

Trivium says the next steps with Covid are very important. This is important for China and Xi in 2023. It is important for politics and the economy. It is hard to know what will happen.

The last year was not what Xi wanted. It was also not what experts thought would happen.

Tsang says things have still been good for Xi. Even though there were protests, he still got what he wanted. He got a third term as leader. He also has leaders who support him.

Tsang also says this might not be good for China. Xi has a lot of power, like a dictator. This is costing China a lot.

Chi Hui Lin helped with this report.

text: China is preparing for another wave of Covid to hit its more vulnerable countryside in early 2023, as the current wave of infections overwhelms hospitals and intensive care units in many cities. The lunar new year, China’s most important holiday, falls in late January. It offers a chance of reunion after years of separation under the harsh internal travel restrictions and lockdowns of the previous zero-Covid policy. But as hundreds of millions of workers head home, many are expected to take the disease with them, to areas that have fewer hospitals and clinics, fewer medical professionals, less equipment and medicine, and less money to pay for care. “In the face of a virus like Omicron, all people should be equal, but the fact is that as far as the virus is concerned, urban and rural areas are not equal,” said one post on the Chinese social media platform WeChat, from a user in a small town in central Henan province. “Not only are resources and opportunities unequal but there is also a wide gap in the understanding of how to handle public health.” The next wave of infections is likely to hit rural areas in late winter, the British health analytics company Airfinity predicts, and could affect even more people than the one racing through cities now. The toll may be worsened by the government’s abrupt shift in propaganda messaging about Covid. The virus had been presented as a menace to be avoided at almost any cost, but now Chinese citizens are told it is little worse than a cold. “My home town has quietly changed the way they talk about getting sick,” said the person posting on WeChat from Henan. “‘Every family has caught the cold’, so there is nothing to be afraid of.” That position means there is little official promotion of basic measures such as social distancing that could slow the spread of the disease and possibly buy time for overwhelmed hospitals. Jeremy Wallace, a professor of government at Cornell University, said: “I’m very surprised that the messaging seems to be denial of the depth of suffering from this wave and, as far as I’ve seen, no communication about flattening the curve to reduce pressure on its overburdened health systems.
b2_text:
China is getting ready for more COVID-19 cases. This could happen in the countryside in early 2023.

Right now, many cities have a lot of people sick. Hospitals and special care units are very full.

The Chinese New Year is in late January. It is a very important holiday. People can see their families after a long time. They could not travel easily before because of COVID-19 rules.

But many people will travel home for the holiday. They might bring the virus with them. These people will go to areas that do not have many hospitals or doctors. They also have less medicine and equipment. People there may not have enough money for medical care.

One person wrote on a Chinese social media site. They said that everyone should have the same chance to fight the virus. But cities and rural areas are not equal. The person said that rural areas have fewer resources. They also do not know as much about how to handle health problems.

A British company called Airfinity said the next wave of infections will likely happen in rural areas in late winter. It could affect even more people than the current wave in cities.

The government has changed how it talks about COVID-19. Before, they said it was very dangerous. Now, they say it is like a cold.

The person on the social media site said their hometown is talking differently about getting sick. They say that everyone has a cold, so people should not be scared.

Because of this, the government is not telling people to do things like stay away from each other. This could slow down the spread of the virus. It could also give hospitals more time to help people.

Jeremy Wallace is a professor at Cornell University. He said he is surprised that the government is not talking about how many people are suffering. He also said that the government is not telling people how to slow down the spread of the virus. This could help the hospitals that have too many patients.

text: As such, I would expect staggering death totals, as predicted by models looking at the experience of Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong, on the order of 1 million.” In some urban areas, Covid has spread so fast that infections may soon reach a peak, analysts believe, although the course of the disease is difficult to trace because when China cut back on disease controls, it also cut back on publishing Covid statistics. China was once proud of its Covid statistics. Then, as deaths and infections mounted, the National Health Commission (NHC) said it would no longer publish a daily death toll. On Friday, despite widely circulating images and stories of hospitals unable to cope with the influx of patients, the NHC said there had been one Covid death and 5,500 new cases in the last 24 hours, AFP reported. By contrast, Airfinity estimates that about 9,000 people a day are dying from Covid in China. Next month that could rise to as many as 25,000 a day, and the company forecasts a death toll by April of up to 1.7 million people. An NHC spokesperson, Jiao Yahui, admitted this week that China was excluding from tolls many deaths that would be counted in other countries as Covid fatalities, AFP reported. Elsewhere in the world, any death within 28 days of a positive nucleic acid test is counted. Beijing has decided to count only those who die of respiratory failure caused by the virus. “China has always been committed to the scientific criteria for judging Covid-19 deaths, from beginning to end, which are in line with the international criteria,” Jiao said. While China’s propaganda systems are claiming the government’s sudden pivot on the pandemic – from harsh controls to letting the disease rip – has been managed perfectly, social media is filled with the grim realities of life mid-pandemic. Chinese authorities are normally quick to stifle online dissent and criticism, but a surprising number of posts discussing the reality of Covid in China today are making it online and staying up for some time, said Charlie Smith, a co-founder of Greatfire.org, a censorship monitoring site. “Most of these posts are surviving because the censorship boundaries are changing so quickly and the censors cannot keep up.
b2_text:
I think many people will die. Models looked at Taiwan, South Korea, and Hong Kong. They show that maybe 1 million people will die.

In cities, COVID is spreading very fast. Experts think the infections might soon be at their highest point. But it is hard to know what is happening. China stopped controlling the disease as much. They also stopped sharing COVID numbers.

China used to be proud of its COVID numbers. Now, many people are sick and dying. The National Health Commission (NHC) said they will not share the daily death numbers anymore.

AFP news said that on Friday, the NHC said only one person died from COVID. They said there were 5,500 new cases in one day. But we see many pictures and stories of hospitals with too many patients.

Airfinity thinks that about 9,000 people are dying each day from COVID in China. They think this number could go up to 25,000 each day next month. By April, they think 1.7 million people could die.

Jiao Yahui is a spokesperson for the NHC. She said that China is not counting all deaths as COVID deaths. Other countries count deaths differently. AFP reported this.

In other countries, if someone dies within 28 days of testing positive for COVID, it is counted as a COVID death. But China only counts deaths caused by breathing problems from the virus.

Jiao said that China follows scientific rules for counting COVID deaths. She said these rules are like the rules used by other countries.

China says they are handling the pandemic well. They went from strict rules to letting the disease spread. But social media shows a sad reality.

Usually, China quickly stops people from criticizing the government online. But now, many posts about the real situation with COVID in China are online. These posts are staying online for a while. Charlie Smith from Greatfire.org said this. Greatfire.org watches what is censored online.

He said the rules about what is allowed online are changing fast. The people who censor the internet cannot keep up. That is why many posts are still online.

text: But it also makes sense that the real humans who are behind censorship can see for themselves that current Covid management is all over the place,” he said. “They must be asking themselves how they could possibly censor Covid-related posts when everyone has Covid.”
b2_text: He also said something important. The people who decide what to censor are also human. They can see what is happening with the virus. The rules about Covid are confusing. Maybe they are thinking about this. They might be wondering how to stop Covid posts. Everyone is getting Covid now.

text: Taiwan will extend its compulsory military service from four months to one year amid mounting military tensions with China, the island’s president has announced. Under the plans due to come into effect in 2024, conscripts will undergo more intense training, including shooting exercises and combat instruction used by US forces. Conscripts will be tasked with guarding key infrastructure, enabling regular forces to respond more swiftly in the event of any attempt by China to invade. The announcement of the change came after Taiwan’s defence ministry reported that 71 Chinese air force jets and drones had entered the island’s air defence identification zone within 24 hours on Monday – the largest reported incursion to date. “As long as Taiwan is strong enough, it will be the home of democracy and freedom all over the world, and it will not become a battlefield,” President Tsai Ing-wen told a news conference after a national security council meeting. “Taiwan wants to tell the world that between democracy and dictatorship, we firmly believe in democracy. Between war and peace, we insist on peace. Let us show the courage and determination to protect our homeland and defend democracy.” The defence authority also plans to raise the monthly wage of regular conscription soldiers from about NT$6,500 (US$211) to NT$26,307 (US$856), almost in line with the minimum wage. Since 2013, Taiwan has required men over 18 to serve four months in the military, with the first five weeks in a basic training boot camp. The new plan will put mandatory recruits on eight-week basic training. Chen Chi-mai, mayor of Kaohsiung city and the acting chairperson of the ruling Democratic Progressive party, told reporters on Tuesday that it was essential to strengthen national security, the official news agency CNA reported. Taiwan has been gradually shifting from a conscript military to a volunteer-dominated professional force, but China’s growing assertiveness towards the island it claims as its own, as well as Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, have prompted debate about how to boost defence. Tsai said “a few things” had been learned from that war which have been incorporated into Taiwan’s defence reforms, and noted that Ukraine’s ability to hold off much larger Russian forces had given the international community time to render assistance.
b2_text:
Taiwan will make its military service longer. Now, young men must serve for four months. Soon, they will need to serve for one year.

This change is because of problems with China. China and Taiwan have disagreements. The leader of Taiwan announced this new plan. It will start in 2024.

The soldiers will have harder training. They will learn to shoot better. They will learn fighting skills from the United States military.

The soldiers will guard important places. This will help the main army respond quickly if China tries to attack.

Recently, many Chinese planes flew near Taiwan. The defense ministry said 71 planes and drones came close. This was the most ever in one day.

The leader of Taiwan, Tsai Ing-wen, spoke to the news. She said Taiwan must be strong. She said Taiwan is a place for freedom and democracy. It will not become a war zone.

She also said Taiwan chooses democracy over dictatorship. It wants peace, not war. She wants people to protect their home and democracy.

The government will pay soldiers more. Now, they get about $211 each month. Soon, they will get about $856. This is close to the lowest wage a person can earn.

Now, soldiers train for five weeks when they start. With the new plan, they will train for eight weeks.

A mayor named Chen Chi-mai said it is important to make the country safer.

Taiwan used to make many people join the army. Now, it wants more volunteers. But China is becoming stronger. China says Taiwan is part of China. Also, Russia attacked Ukraine. These things made Taiwan think about how to protect itself better.

Tsai said Taiwan learned from the war in Ukraine. These lessons are now part of Taiwan's plans to protect itself. Ukraine fought against Russia, which is a much bigger country. This gave other countries time to help Ukraine.

text: Previous governments cut compulsory service for men from more than two years to four months to please younger voters during a period of easing tensions between Taipei and Beijing. Taiwan’s efforts to bolster the readiness of its defence forces accelerated after the visit to the island from the US House Speaker, Nancy Pelosi, in August. China immediately staged military drills around Taiwan in response to Pelosi’s visit. The de facto US embassy in Taiwan welcomed the announcement on conscription reform. “The United States’ commitment to Taiwan and steps Taiwan takes to enhance its self-defence capabilities contribute to the maintenance of peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and within the region,” the American Institute in Taiwan said. A survey conducted by the Taiwanese Public Opinion Foundation in December found that 73.2% of respondents were in favour of an extension to compulsory service. Joseph Wu, Taiwan’s foreign minister, told the Guardian in an exclusive interview earlier this month that the Chinese military threat was “getting more serious than ever”, with a five-fold increase in warplane incursions into the island’s defence zone since 2020. Wu said the drills conducted after Pelosi’s visit were also aimed at scaring off other governments which might support Taiwan. As part of the efforts to ramp up the island’s combat strength, on Friday Tsai inaugurated new military facilities at an army base in the southern city of Kaohsiung, which she said offers “a better living environment” for military personnel, according to a statement released by the president office. Reuters contributed to this report
b2_text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text, suitable for a B2 level English speaker:

In the past, Taiwan had leaders who changed the rules about military service. They made the time shorter for young men. They wanted young people to like them. At that time, Taiwan and China were not fighting much. The service was more than two years, but it became only four months.

Things changed after a visit to Taiwan. Nancy Pelosi, a leader from the United States, went to Taiwan in August. After that, Taiwan started to work harder to be ready to defend itself.

China was not happy about Pelosi's visit. China showed its power by doing military training near Taiwan.

The American Institute in Taiwan is like the US embassy. They were happy about Taiwan's plan to change the military service. They said it helps keep peace. They think Taiwan's ability to defend itself makes the area safer.

A study asked people in Taiwan what they thought. Most people, about 73%, said they wanted the military service to be longer.

Joseph Wu is Taiwan's foreign minister. He said that China is becoming a bigger threat. He said China's military planes are flying into Taiwan's defense area much more often than before. It is five times more than in 2020. Wu believes that China's training exercises after Pelosi's visit were also meant to scare other countries that might help Taiwan.

Taiwan wants to be stronger in case of a fight. Tsai, the leader of Taiwan, opened new buildings at a military base. The base is in Kaohsiung, a city in the south. She said the new buildings will give the soldiers a better place to live. This information came from a statement from the president's office. Reuters helped write this news report.

text: Kherson city was liberated by Ukrainian forces in November. But for some, the horrors of the Russian occupation are still not over. Nadia* sent her 14-year-old son to a Russian-run summer camp in Crimea – occupied by Moscow since 2014 – in October. He was meant to return after two weeks. It has now been more than two months. In late November, he forwarded her a series of chilling voice messages from his camp leader telling him he would not be allowed back to Kherson because of his pro-Ukraine views. “You are in Russia! You shouldn’t be doing different [types] of weird bullshit,” the camp leader in Yevpatoria, Crimea, said in the voice messages, which have been forwarded to the Guardian. “I don’t know who is going to deal with you now, but you are not going back to Kherson, that’s 100% [certain] … You can thank your mother for that.” Like many parents, Nadia did not see sending her child to such a camp – known as summer camps even at other times of year – as making a pro-Russia statement. Parents often decided to send their children because their classmates were going and they were being offered a free holiday by the sea. Nadia’s son left Kherson on 4 October and his stay at the camp was repeatedly extended by the authorities, said his mother, speaking from central Kherson after Russian forces left the city. At first, the camp leaders told her that this was for safety reasons and then, after Ukrainian forces had entered Kherson city, they said he could not return because the city was now “occupied” by Ukraine. In the messages, the camp leader outlined his problem with the boy. Firstly, his Telegram profile picture featured a Ukrainian trident, Ukraine’s national symbol, on the wall in the background. Secondly, his mother had said she wanted her son to return to Ukraine, signifying that she saw Kherson city as part of Ukraine, not Russia, thereby going against the grain of Russian propaganda that still insists the city is part of Russia. Nadia’s case is one of many. Hundreds of Ukrainian children as young as six and as old as 16 from Kherson and Kharkiv regions have been stuck in Russian summer camps for weeks and in some cases months.
b2_text:
Kherson is a city in Ukraine. Ukrainian soldiers freed it from Russian control in November. But some people in Kherson still have problems from when Russia controlled the city.

Nadia* is a mother. She sent her 14-year-old son to a camp in Crimea in October. Crimea has been controlled by Russia since 2014. The camp was run by Russians. The camp was supposed to be for two weeks. But now it has been more than two months.

In November, Nadia got voice messages from the camp leader. The camp leader said her son could not go back to Kherson. The leader said this was because her son supported Ukraine.

The camp leader was in Yevpatoria, Crimea. He said in the messages: "You are in Russia! You should not do strange things." He also said: "I don't know who will deal with you now. But you are not going back to Kherson. This is sure. You can blame your mother for this." Nadia sent these messages to a newspaper called The Guardian.

Many parents did not think sending their children to the camp was supporting Russia. The camps were called summer camps. Parents sent their children because other children were going. The camp was a free trip to the sea.

Nadia's son left Kherson on October 4. The camp leaders kept him there longer and longer. At first, they said it was for safety. Then, Ukrainian soldiers freed Kherson. The camp leaders said he could not return because Ukraine was now controlling the city.

The camp leader said he had problems with the boy. First, the boy's picture on Telegram showed a Ukrainian symbol. It was a trident on the wall. The trident is a symbol of Ukraine. Second, Nadia said she wanted her son to return to Ukraine. This meant she thought Kherson was part of Ukraine, not Russia. This was against what Russia was saying. Russia was saying Kherson was part of Russia.

Nadia's story is not the only one. Many Ukrainian children are stuck in Russian summer camps. They are from Kherson and Kharkiv. Some children are only six years old. Some are sixteen. They have been in the camps for weeks or months.

text: Over the summer, Russia offered parents in the occupied areas of Ukraine a chance to send their children to summer camps in Crimea and southern Russia for free. But it has been refusing to return the children to their parents, citing the ongoing fighting as well as Ukraine’s “occupation” of areas Russia claimed to have annexed and has now retreated from. Parents are told they can collect the children if they come in person, which requires them to cross the dangerous unofficial checkpoint through the frontline or leave Ukraine and travel via Poland and the Baltics. But many of the parents are from very low-income backgrounds and have not been able to make the journey. Though the parents sent them willingly, they had agreed to a short stint. The UN convention on children’s rights bans the “illicit transfer and non-return of children abroad”, so Russia is obliged to return the children. The Guardian spoke to eight parents who had sent their children to the summer camps. Some say they believe that Russia wants to use the children to exchange for Russian prisoners of war. Others believe Moscow wants to assimilate the children and plan to keep them in Russia. The camps were advertised through schools in the occupied areas as restorative breaks, offering a mix of sports, arts, games, and sea air or lake swimming. But the children have also been taught Russian narratives about the invasion of Ukraine, Russian and Soviet history as well as Russian culture, according to several interviewed and videos posted online. In one video, hundreds of children can be seen in a school playground in Crimea singing the Russian national anthem. Most appear not to know the words. The hundreds of children stuck in the Russian-run summer camps are in addition to the thousands of children living in orphanages in the occupied areas who were illegally taken to Russia during the Russian occupation. Ukraine’s human right’s ombudsman, Dmytro Lubinets, has said this is part of Russia’s “genocide against Ukraine”, erasing Ukrainian identity through “re-educating the future generations”. Lubinets said the Russians were not interested in returning the children, and though Ukraine was trying, “the return of each child is like a special operation”. Ukraine asks parents not to publicly name their children as they then become harder to exchange.
b2_text:
In the summer, Russia had a program for children from Ukraine. These children lived in areas taken over by Russia. Russia offered their parents free summer camps for them. The camps were in Crimea and southern Russia.

But now, Russia is not sending the children back home. They say it is because of the fighting. They also say that Ukraine is occupying some areas that Russia used to control.

Parents can get their children back. But they must go to Russia themselves. This is very hard. They must cross a dangerous checkpoint. Or, they must leave Ukraine and travel through Poland and other countries.

Many parents do not have enough money for this trip. They are poor. They cannot afford to go to Russia.

The parents agreed to send their children for a short time. But now, Russia is keeping them longer.

There is an international rule about children. It says that countries cannot take children to another country and not return them. Russia should send the children back.

The Guardian newspaper talked to eight parents. They sent their children to the summer camps. Some parents think Russia wants to trade the children. They think Russia will exchange them for Russian soldiers who are prisoners.

Other parents think Russia wants to keep the children. They think Russia wants the children to become Russian.

The camps were advertised in schools. They were said to be good for the children. They offered sports, art, games, and swimming.

But the children are also learning about Russia. They are learning Russian stories about the war. They are learning about Russian history and culture.

One video shows many children in Crimea. They are singing the Russian national anthem. Most of them do not know the words.

There are also many children in orphanages. These children were taken to Russia illegally. They were taken when Russia controlled their areas.

Dmytro Lubinets is from Ukraine. He works to protect people's rights. He says Russia is doing something very bad. He says Russia is trying to destroy Ukrainian identity. They are doing this by teaching the children to be Russian.

Lubinets says Russia does not want to return the children. Ukraine is trying to get them back. But it is very difficult. Getting each child back is like a special mission.

Ukraine asks parents not to say their children's names publicly. This makes it harder to get them back from Russia.

text: For a domestic audience, Russia portrays the deportation of the children as an attempt to save Ukrainian children from the war – ignoring Russia’s role in starting the conflict. Since October, the children have started attending Russian schools while living on the camps’ premises. It is not clear what plans Russia has for these children beyond this school term. One of them is Natalia’s* 12-year-old daughter, who left her home in Balakliia in late August and is still in southern Russia, attending a school in Krasnodar by bus. Natalia has managed to keep in daily contact with her but cannot afford to make the journey to collect her. “I think it’s some sort of blackmail,” said Natalia. “I think they want to use them as bargaining chips.” In at least some cases, the Russian camp leaders have said they do not plan to send the children back. In other cases, children have been moved from one camp to another without the parents being informed. Ivana*, a mother from Kherson region, made the long journey to collect her daughter from a camp in Crimea, only to be told the child was not there any more and had been moved to a camp in the Republic of Adygea. She then made a second long trip, where eventually she found her. * * * Exactly how many Ukrainian children remain in Russian hands is very difficult to tell. In mid-October, Russia’s state news agency Tass said there were about 4,500 children from Kherson and Zaporizhzhia in Crimean summer camps. Natalia said at least 100 of those who travelled with her daughter were still there. Recent videos taken from some of the five camps in Crimea hosting children from Kherson indicate that at least several hundred children are still there. Part of the issue is that many of the parents refuse to come forward to the Ukrainian authorities. Dmytro*, who managed to get his son back by threatening a teacher into putting him on a bus in early October, said parents he knew feared being labelled as collaborators or supporters of Russia. They were trying to resolve things on their own, he said, without official help.
b2_text:
Russia says they took Ukrainian children to help them. They say they wanted to save the children from the war. But Russia started the war.

The children now live in camps in Russia. Since October, they go to Russian schools. We do not know what Russia will do with them after school.

Natalia's daughter is twelve years old. She left her home in Ukraine in August. Now, she is in Russia, in a school in Krasnodar. She goes to school by bus.

Natalia talks to her daughter every day. But Natalia cannot go to Russia to get her daughter. Natalia thinks Russia is using the children. She thinks Russia wants to use them to get something they want.

Some camp leaders in Russia say they will not send the children back to Ukraine. Sometimes, the children are moved to other camps. The parents do not know about it.

Ivana is a mother from Ukraine. She went to Crimea to get her daughter from a camp. But her daughter was not there. Her daughter was moved to another camp. Ivana went to the other camp and found her daughter.

It is hard to know how many Ukrainian children are in Russia. In October, Russia said there were 4,500 children in camps in Crimea. These children were from Kherson and Zaporizhzhia. Natalia knows that at least 100 children who went with her daughter are still in the camps.

There are videos of children in camps in Crimea. These videos show that many children are still there.

Some parents do not want to talk to the Ukrainian government. They are afraid people will think they support Russia. They want to get their children back without help.

Dmytro got his son back. He told a teacher to put his son on a bus. He said other parents are afraid. They do not want problems with the government.

text: An adviser to the new Kherson regional authorities on missing people, Volodymyr Zhdanov, questioned how the parents “could give their children to the occupiers”, though he admitted it was a grey area and the full picture was unclear. “We are hearing a lot of stories through the grapevine [of children stuck in Crimea],” said Zhdanov, who noted that the gathering of information on what had happened in occupied Kherson was only just beginning. “But the police say parents have not come forward.” Andrii Kovanyi, a spokesperson for Kherson police, said they could not comment on the matter as it was being dealt with by several bodies. Most parents and children who attended the camps said the conditions were good. Children were given the equivalent of hotel rooms to share, taken to see dolphins, to museums and to the beach. The Russian-appointed authorities in Crimea claim to have spent 1.2bn rubles (£16.4m) in 2022 on the camps, which were also attended by Russian children. The idea behind the camps appears to be to demonstrate the best of Russia and to integrate the children into their new state. In interviews, the adults in charge portray themselves and others as saving children who are victims of the war as well as the Ukrainian state. In videos from the children’s camps posted on the Russian-installed Kherson authority’s social media, children can be seen with the Russian flag, singing the Russian national anthem as well as classic Soviet songs. A nine-year-old girl in Kherson city, whose mother collected her in October, said that as well as games and sports they had lectures “about the war”. One history teacher from Kherson, Maksym Ivchenko, who like many other teachers accompanied the children to Crimea, was asked by Russia’s Crimea24 TV to explain how the history curriculum in Russia differed from that of Ukraine. “The most egregious thing was the reversal of modern history. We’re talking first of all about the great patriotic war [the second world war], what happened in the Soviet period, its collapse and everything up until the present day,” Ivchenko said.
b2_text:
Volodymyr Zhdanov works for the new leaders in Kherson. He helps find people who are missing. He asked why parents sent their kids to the other side. He said it is hard to understand. We do not know everything yet.

Zhdanov said that he heard stories about children in Crimea. Crimea is a place controlled by Russia. He said they are just starting to find out what happened in Kherson. Kherson was also controlled by Russia. Zhdanov said the police say parents have not reported missing children.

Andrii Kovanyi speaks for the Kherson police. He said he cannot talk about this. Many groups are working on this problem.

Most parents and kids who went to the camps said they were good. The kids stayed in rooms like in a hotel. They saw dolphins and museums. They went to the beach.

The Russian leaders in Crimea said they spent a lot of money on the camps. Russian children also went to these camps. They wanted to show the children the good things about Russia. They wanted the children to feel like they belonged in Russia.

The adults in charge said they are helping children. They said the children are victims of the war and the Ukrainian government.

Videos from the camps show children with the Russian flag. They sing Russian songs. They also sing old Soviet songs.

One girl from Kherson went to the camp. Her mother brought her home in October. The girl said they played games and sports. They also had lessons about the war. She was nine years old.

Maksym Ivchenko is a history teacher from Kherson. He went to Crimea with the children. Russia's Crimea24 TV asked him about history. They asked how Russian history lessons are different from Ukrainian history lessons.

Ivchenko said the biggest difference was about recent history. He said they changed the story of World War II. They also changed the story of the Soviet Union. He said they changed everything up to now.

text: Tatiana Makarova, the head of the programme for Kherson and Zaporizhzhia at one the biggest camps in Crimea, Artek, told the same TV channel: “Our task is to remove the psychological pressure put on the children who come from the areas where the war is happening.” Nadia said she and her son had argued at first because she did not want him to go to the camp, but eventually she gave in. “I thought: OK, it’s two weeks, there’s the seaside, he’ll get a rest and come back.” * Names have been changed
b2_text:
Tatiana Makarova works at Artek. Artek is a very big camp in Crimea. She is in charge of the program for children from Kherson and Zaporizhzhia. She spoke on TV. She said their job is to help the children. The children are stressed. They come from places where there is war.

Nadia sent her son to the camp. At first, she did not want to. She and her son argued about it. But then she changed her mind. She thought it was only for two weeks. The camp is by the sea. She hoped her son would rest. She wanted him to come back feeling better.

* The names used are not real names. They were changed to protect people.

text: It’s nearly 9pm in Kyiv. Here’s where things stand: Ukrainian officials are urging residents to evacuate from the city of Kherson as Russian forces stepped up mortar and artillery attacks on the recently liberated southern Ukrainian city. Some residents who lived through the Russian occupation are reluctant to leave despite the bombardment, according to a local official who has been involved in the evacuation. Russian troops fired 33 rockets at civilian targets in a series of aerial and artillery bombardments in Kherson over the course of 24 hours, Ukraine’s armed forces said Wednesday morning. A maternity wing of a hospital in Kherson city was shelled by Russian forces late on Tuesday, according to Kyrylo Tymoshenko, the deputy head of the president’s office. Volodymyr Zelenskiy said “only a few” civilians remain in the embattled frontline city of Bakhmut in the eastern province of Donetsk. In a Telegram post, Ukraine’s leader said “there is no place that is not covered with blood” in the Ukrainian-held city, where his troops are waging a battle that has come to symbolise the grinding brutality of the war. Ukraine has secured the release of 1,456 prisoners of war since Russia invaded in February, according to Zelenskiy. Ukraine’s president was speaking in an annual address to the Ukrainian parliament, where Valeriy Zaluzhnyi, the commander-in-chief of Ukraine’s armed forces, cabinet ministers, foreign diplomats, military personnel and family members of fallen soldiers were reportedly present. The Kremlin has insisted any proposals to end the conflict in Ukraine must take into account what it calls “today’s realities” of four Ukrainian regions Moscow has unilaterally declared part of Russia. In a regular briefing with reporters, the Kremlin’s spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, dismissed President Volodymyr Zelenskiy’s 10-point peace plan, which includes the restoration of Ukraine’s territorial integrity, the withdrawal of Russian troops, the release of all prisoners, a tribunal for those responsible for the aggression and security guarantees for Ukraine.
b2_text:
It is almost 9 pm in Kyiv. Here is what is happening.

Ukrainian leaders are telling people to leave the city of Kherson. Russian soldiers are attacking the city with bombs. Kherson is a city in the south of Ukraine that Ukraine recently took back.

Some people in Kherson do not want to leave. They lived there when Russia controlled the city. A local leader said they do not want to leave even though the city is being bombed. This leader is helping people to leave.

The Ukrainian army said that Russian soldiers fired 33 rockets at Kherson in one day. The rockets hit places where normal people live.

Kyrylo Tymoshenko works for the President of Ukraine. He said that Russian soldiers bombed a hospital in Kherson on Tuesday night. The part of the hospital for new mothers was hit.

Volodymyr Zelenskyy is the President of Ukraine. He said that only a few people are still in the city of Bakhmut. Bakhmut is a city in the east of Ukraine. It is near the fighting.

President Zelenskyy said that everywhere in Bakhmut is covered in blood. Ukrainian soldiers are fighting hard in Bakhmut. The fighting there shows how terrible the war is.

President Zelenskyy also said that Ukraine has freed 1,456 soldiers who were prisoners. Russia took them as prisoners after the war started in February.

President Zelenskyy spoke to the Ukrainian parliament. Valeriy Zaluzhnyi was there. He is the head of the Ukrainian army. Government workers, diplomats from other countries, soldiers, and families of soldiers who died were also there.

The Russian government said that any plan to end the war must accept that Russia now controls four areas of Ukraine. Russia says these areas are now part of Russia. Other countries do not agree.

Dmitry Peskov speaks for the Russian government. He said that he does not agree with President Zelenskyy's peace plan. Zelenskyy wants Russia to leave Ukraine, free all prisoners, and pay for the damage it has caused. He also wants a court to punish those who started the war and guarantees that Ukraine will be safe in the future.

text: A Crimean human rights activist has been sentenced to seven years in prison after a Moscow-installed court in the Russian-annexed peninsula found her guilty of carrying an explosive device, in a trial rights activists have described as “trumped-up” and “illegal”. Iryna Danilovich was sentenced to seven years in a general regime colony by a court in Russian-controlled Feodosia, Crimea, which Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014, the Kyiv-based organisation Institute of Mass Information (IMI) said. Authorities in the city of Odesa have begun dismantling a monument to Catherine the Great, the Russian empress who founded the city in the late 18th century. Last month, the local parliament voted to dismantle the statue, as well as another to the Tsarist general Alexander Suvorov. Russian soldiers mobilised to fight in Ukraine will be able to store their frozen sperm in a cryobank for free, a leading Russian lawyer has said. Demographers have warned that Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine and its “partial” military mobilisation could further deepen Russia’s demographic crisis. The United Nations high commissioner for human rights (OHCHR) has released a count of the number of civilian casualties in Russia’s war on Ukraine so far, saying that 6,884 people are known to have died in Ukraine, including 429 children, between 24 February 2022 to 26 December 2022. The actual figure is likely to be “considerably higher”, it added. That’s it from me, Léonie Chao-Fong, and the Russia-Ukraine war live blog today. Thank you for reading. The head of Ukraine’s military intelligence service, Kyrylo Budanov, made a visit to Bakhmut on Tuesday and Wednesday to meet special forces detachments working at the front and to distribute medals, according to a statement released by the service. Russian strikes have continued in the recently liberated city of Kherson, launching attacks against the city on Tuesday and Wednesday. According to Ukrainian military, 33 strikes were launched in the past 24 hours. One of the targets included a maternity ward in a hospital in the city.
b2_text:
A human rights worker from Crimea will go to prison for seven years. Crimea is a place that Russia took from Ukraine.

A court in Crimea said Iryna Danilovich had a bomb. But other human rights workers say this is not true. They say the trial was unfair and against the law.

The court that made the decision is in Feodosia, a city in Crimea. Russia controls this city. The organization IMI said that Russia took Crimea from Ukraine in 2014.

In Odesa, a city in Ukraine, people are taking down a statue. The statue is of Catherine the Great. She was a Russian ruler who started the city a long time ago.

Last month, leaders in Odesa voted to take down the statue. They also want to take down a statue of Alexander Suvorov, a general from Russia.

Russian soldiers going to fight in Ukraine can keep their sperm frozen for free. A lawyer in Russia said this.

Experts say that the war in Ukraine could make Russia's population problem worse. They say that many people could die or leave the country because of the war.

The United Nations said that many people have died in Ukraine because of the war. They know that 6,884 people have died, including 429 children. This was between February 24, 2022, and December 26, 2022.

The United Nations thinks that even more people have died.

Thank you for reading this news. My name is Léonie Chao-Fong.

Kyrylo Budanov, the head of Ukraine's military intelligence, went to Bakhmut. This was on Tuesday and Wednesday. He met with soldiers and gave them awards.

Russia is still attacking Kherson, a city that Ukraine recently freed. They attacked the city on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The Ukrainian military said that Russia attacked 33 times in the last day. One attack hit a hospital where babies are born.

text: Footage shows the aftermath of the strike where windows were shattered and staff and patients were forced to take cover in the basement. One staff member told reporters: I don’t even want to think about [what could have happened]’ after surgeons were in theatre just 30 minutes earlier. The secret to Igor Pedin’s survival had been his invisibility, the 61-year-old had said.
