The study also found that BAME workers are paid less than white British workers. This is even when they have the same age, skills, and experience.

This means that BAME people are more disadvantaged than we thought.

BAME men earn 65p less per hour than white British men on average. BAME women also earn less than white British women, but the difference is smaller.

Many young people work in hospitality. More than one-third of workers are between 16 and 24 years old. But this is not always true for BAME workers.

For example, many Bangladeshi hospitality workers are older. The average age is 42. This is older than other Bangladeshi workers and white British workers in hospitality.

Indian hospitality workers earn more than other ethnic groups. They earn about £8.96 per hour. They are also more likely to have high-paying jobs like managers.

Many Indian workers in hospitality have a university degree (41%).

Bangladeshi workers often have less education. One in four have no qualifications. They earn about £7.85 per hour, which is 12% less than Indian workers.

text: Nye Cominetti, the senior economist at the Resolution Foundation, said: “As workers from BAME backgrounds are disproportionately likely to work in hospitality, a significant number of workers risk moving into unemployment when the furlough scheme ends in the spring. “The government should bear that in mind for the jobs support programmes it is providing.” A report by the British Beer & Pubs Association and the consultancy Oxford Economics has previously warned that 291,000 jobs in the hospitality trade could be lost as a result of coronavirus restrictions. The forecast was based on industry data suggesting that 25% of pubs could close, with the remainder barely breaking even as they struggle to cope with reduced custom and limited opening hours. Oxford Economics said the worst-case scenario would reduce the sector’s economic output by £7.4bn and cut wages by £3.9bn.
b2_text:
Here is the rewritten text in B2 level English:

Nye Cominetti is an economist. He works for the Resolution Foundation. He said something important. Many workers from BAME groups work in hospitality. BAME means Black, Asian, and Minority Ethnic. These workers might lose their jobs. This could happen when the furlough scheme ends. The furlough scheme is help from the government. It pays workers who cannot work. The scheme will end in the spring.

Mr. Cominetti thinks the government should remember this. They should help these workers. The government has job support programs. These programs should help people in hospitality.

A report said many jobs could be lost. The British Beer & Pubs Association made the report. Oxford Economics helped them. They said 291,000 jobs could be lost. This is because of the coronavirus rules.

The report thinks many pubs might close. About 25% of pubs could close. The other pubs might not make much money. They have fewer customers. They can only open for a short time.

Oxford Economics said things could be very bad. The economy could lose a lot of money. The hospitality sector could lose £7.4 billion. Workers could lose £3.9 billion in wages.

text: Family-owned Welsh brewer SA Brain & Co has handed over the running of its 156 pubs to Marston’s, saving 1,300 jobs, after the coronavirus pandemic threatened their closure. Brains, whose pubs are mainly based in south and west Wales, said it had come “under significant financial pressure” during the pandemic, as restrictions mean pubs must remain closed except for takeaway and delivery. The company closed its entire pub estate on 4 December after the announcement of a ban on alcohol sales and enforced 6pm closing across Wales to try to contain a worsening Covid-19 outbreak. Remaining open under those restrictions was “not a viable option”, Brains said. SA Brain & Co was established in 1882 in Cardiff, and became Wales’s biggest brewer and pubs company while remaining under family ownership. John Rhys, the company chairman who oversaw the deal, is the great-grandson of founder Samuel Arthur Brain. Before the pandemic, the pubs included in the deal made £14m a year in core earnings. Marston’s will take over the pubs in February, mostly under 25-year leases from Brains. The annual rent on the pubs was £5.5m. The pubs will be run under the Brains brand, and will continue to sell its beer, which is brewed at a facility in Cardiff Bay that was opened in March 2019. Before that Brains was made in breweries in Cardiff’s city centre. Rhys said: “We know and trust Marston’s to be excellent custodians of our pubs and, while this is not a decision we have taken lightly, we are confident that our pubs and our pubs teams will thrive under their stewardship. “Furthermore, this transaction enables Brains to recapitalise its balance sheet and continue its long heritage as an independent entity, preserving this great Welsh business for generations to come.” Marston’s, formerly known as Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries until a 2007 rebrand, runs about 1,400 pubs across the UK, including 106 in Wales. The 1,300 employees in Brains pubs will transfer to Marston’s, which employs a further 14,000 people across the UK.
b2_text:
A Welsh company called SA Brain & Co owns many pubs. They have had problems because of the coronavirus.

The coronavirus made it hard for pubs to stay open. Pubs could only sell takeaway food and drinks.

Brains had to close all their pubs in December. This was because Wales said pubs could not sell alcohol after 6 pm. It was too hard for Brains to stay open with these rules.

Brains decided to let another company run their pubs. This company is called Marston’s. This will save 1,300 jobs.

Brains is a family company. It started in 1882. It is the biggest beer and pub company in Wales.

John Rhys is the boss of Brains. He is the great-grandson of the person who started the company.

The pubs made a lot of money before the coronavirus. They made £14 million each year.

Marston’s will start running the pubs in February. They will rent the pubs from Brains for 25 years. They will pay £5.5 million each year to rent them.

The pubs will still be called Brains pubs. They will still sell Brains beer. Brains beer is made in Cardiff Bay. The beer factory opened in 2019. Before that, Brains beer was made in the city center of Cardiff.

John Rhys said he trusts Marston’s. He thinks Marston’s will take good care of the pubs. He said this was a hard decision. But he thinks the pubs will do well with Marston’s.

He also said this deal will help Brains. It will help them to have more money. Brains can stay an independent company. This will keep the Welsh business going for a long time.

Marston’s used to be called Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries. They changed their name in 2007. Marston’s runs about 1,400 pubs in the UK. They have 106 pubs in Wales.

The 1,300 people who work in Brains pubs will now work for Marston’s. Marston’s has 14,000 workers in the UK.

text: Ralph Findlay, the Marston’s chief executive, said the deal would be mutually beneficial and that it “strengthens our representation in south and west Wales, while protecting the heritage and independence of an iconic Welsh business”.
b2_text: Ralph Findlay is the boss of Marston's. He talked about a new agreement. He said it would be good for both sides. He believes it will make Marston's stronger in South and West Wales. It will also help a famous Welsh company. The agreement will protect what makes the Welsh company special and keep it independent.

text: Britain’s independent shops had a sales boost in 2020 despite an overall drop in retail spending, as Covid travel restrictions and working from home prompted consumers to shop on local high streets instead of city centres. Data from Barclaycard shows spending at independent food and drink shops, including off-licences, butchers and bakeries, jumped 28.6% in 2020 compared with a year earlier. In contrast, total consumer spending fell 7.1%, as social distancing rules left shoppers with fewer opportunities to spend on overseas holidays, hospitality and in city centres. Barclaycard, which covers nearly half of the UK’s credit and debit card transactions, found that while spending on essential goods such as groceries rose by 4.1% compared with 2019, non-essential spending fell 11.3%. Department stores were particularly hard hit, with spending down 17.2%, while clothing retailers experienced a 15.6% slump, leading to the financial problems at the likes of Debenhams and the Topshop owner, Arcadia. However, bricks and mortar discounters had a 25.4% increase, as Britons facing furlough and job cuts sought value for money deals. Consumers forced to spend more time at home turned to DIY projects to spruce up their living space. Pent-up demand after the reopening of non-essential shops in June pushed overall spending at DIY and home goods stores up 9.8% for the year. Furniture retailers reported a 5.3% rise, as consumers invested in big ticket items. Britons treated themselves – as well as friends and family they could not see – to flowers throughout the year, with spending at florists rising 22.7%. Crafts and hobby spending increased 9.8%, and pets were given extra attention with vet and pet retail increasing 10.7%. But the report also shows how much restaurants suffered despite Rishi Sunak’s “eat out to help out” initiative over the summer. Restrictions throughout the rest of the year contributed to a 47% drop in restaurant spending, while bars and pubs took a 36.7% hit. However, Covid restrictions contributed to a 49.1% rise in spending on online takeaway orders, while meal subscription services jumped 62.4%. Demand for at-home entertainment pushed spending on digital subscriptions up 31.5%, while money spent on electronics including game consoles rose 10.8%.
b2_text:
In 2020, shops in Britain had a difficult time because of Covid. But some small, local shops did better than expected.

People could not travel easily. Many people worked from home. So, they shopped in their local areas instead of going to big cities.

Barclaycard has information about how people spent their money. They found that spending at small food shops increased a lot. These shops include butchers, bakers, and places that sell alcohol. Spending at these shops went up by about 29% compared to the year before.

But overall, people spent less money. Total spending went down by about 7%. This is because people could not go on holiday or spend money in restaurants and city centers.

Barclaycard also found that people spent more on important things like food. This spending went up by about 4%. But they spent less on things that were not important. This spending went down by about 11%.

Big department stores had a very hard time. Spending in these stores went down by about 17%. Shops that sold clothes also did badly. Their sales went down by about 16%. This caused problems for some big companies.

But discount shops that have physical stores did well. Their sales went up by about 25%. This is because many people lost their jobs or earned less money. So, they wanted to find good deals.

People spent more time at home. So, they started doing projects to improve their homes. After the shops opened again in June, people bought a lot of things for their homes. This made spending at DIY and home goods stores go up by about 10% for the whole year.

Shops that sold furniture also did well. Their sales went up by about 5%. People bought new furniture for their homes.

People also bought flowers for themselves and for their friends and family. Spending on flowers went up by about 23%.

People spent more money on crafts and hobbies. Spending on these things went up by about 10%. They also took care of their pets. Spending on vets and pet shops went up by about 11%.

But restaurants had a very hard time. The government tried to help them with a plan called "eat out to help out". But it was not enough. Because of Covid rules, spending in restaurants went down by about 47%. Bars and pubs also suffered. Their sales went down by about 37%.

However, people ordered more takeaway food online. Spending on online takeaways went up by about 49%. People also used meal subscription services more. Spending on these services went up by about 62%.

People wanted to be entertained at home. So, they spent more money on things like Netflix. Spending on these services went up by about 32%. They also spent more money on electronics like game consoles. Spending on electronics went up by about 11%.

text: Meanwhile, general online retailers benefited from a 52.5% hike in spending. Raheel Ahmed, Barclaycard’s head of consumer products, said: “2020 has accelerated many trends. E-commerce has seen huge growth, working from home has meant many are shopping more locally, and experiences within the home, such as virtual workouts, have become the norm.” Travel spending, including on airlines and travel agents, tumbled 61.1% in August and 63.1% in September, as coronavirus restrictions and quarantine rules took their toll. “Hopefully with a vaccine being rolled out in 2021 we will see green shoots for the most severely impacted sectors,” Ahmed said. “Having said that, some of the trends and changes we have seen in customer habits may be here to stay.”
b2_text:
Online shops that sell many different things did very well. People spent much more money there. The amount spent went up by 52.5%.

Raheel Ahmed works for Barclaycard. He said that 2020 changed many things very quickly.

Shopping online grew a lot. Many people worked from home. Because of this, they shopped more in their local areas. They also did things like exercise online at home. This became normal.

People did not spend as much money on travel. This includes flights and travel companies. Spending went down a lot in August (61.1%) and September (63.1%). This was because of the virus rules. People had to stay home or quarantine. This hurt the travel business.

Ahmed hopes things will get better in 2021. He said a vaccine might help. The businesses that were hurt the most could start to recover.

However, Ahmed also said that some changes might stay. The way people shop may have changed for good.

text: The plus-size clothing brand Evans has been bought out of administration in a £23m deal that will result in the closure of all its stores and concessions with the potential loss of hundreds of jobs . The chain is the first part of Sir Philip Green’s Arcadia Group to be sold off, marking the beginning of the breakup of his fashion empire, which also includes Topshop, Dorothy Perkins, Burton and Miss Selfridge. City Chic Collective, an Australian retailer, plans to operate Evans, which made sales of £26m online and via wholesale last year, as an online-only brand. That will mean the closure of more than 100 Evans concessions and outlets within other Arcadia stores. Five standalone stores will permanently close with the loss of 25 jobs. The concessions and other outlets will not close immediately but hundreds of jobs are at risk at those outlets. Arcadia, which employs 13,000 people at about 500 outlets, collapsed into administration last month as high street lockdowns prompted by the coronavirus pandemic piled on pressure after years of flagging sales amid heavy competition from rivals such as Boohoo and Primark. Bids for all the brands are due to be filed on Monday, with Topshop expected to attract offers of up to £200m. Bidders are thought to include the online specialist Boohoo, the fashion and homewares group Next, and Authentic Brands, the owner of the US department store Barneys. Mike Ashley’s Frasers Group, formerly known as Sports Direct, is also thought to be interested in the smaller Arcadia brands. Administrators from Deloitte said on Monday there had been “significant expressions of interest for all brands”. They said they did not expect to provide a further update on the process until January. City Chic Collective said it had bought Evans as part of a plan to extend its portfolio of plus-size brands, which include City Chic and Hips & Curves, into Europe. It operates in Australia, New Zealand and the US, where it bought the Avenue brand last year. The company already had a relationship with Evans, which has sold City Chic products via its website for the past five years. “Our vision has always been to lead a world of curves,” said Phil Ryan, the chief executive of City Chic Collective.
b2_text:
Evans is a shop that sells clothes for bigger people. It has been sold for 23 million pounds. This means all of the Evans shops will close. Many people may lose their jobs.

Evans was part of a bigger group of shops called Arcadia. The Arcadia group belongs to Sir Philip Green. Arcadia also owns Topshop, Dorothy Perkins, and other shops. Selling Evans is the first step in breaking up the Arcadia group.

A company from Australia called City Chic Collective is buying Evans. City Chic Collective will only sell Evans clothes online. Last year, Evans sold 26 million pounds worth of clothes online. Because Evans will only sell online, over 100 Evans shops inside other Arcadia stores will close. Five Evans shops that are separate will also close. 25 people will lose their jobs at these shops.

The other Evans shops inside Arcadia are not closing right away. But many people who work at these shops may lose their jobs soon.

Arcadia has 13,000 workers in about 500 shops. Arcadia had problems and could not pay its bills. This is because many shops had to close because of the coronavirus. Before the coronavirus, Arcadia was already selling less because other shops like Boohoo and Primark were selling better.

Other companies want to buy the other shops in the Arcadia group. Topshop could be sold for 200 million pounds. Some companies that want to buy Topshop are Boohoo, Next, and Authentic Brands. Mike Ashley's company, Frasers Group, may also want to buy some of the smaller shops.

Deloitte is helping to sell the Arcadia shops. They said that many companies want to buy them. They will give more news about the sales in January.

City Chic Collective wants to buy Evans to sell more clothes for bigger people in Europe. They already sell clothes in Australia, New Zealand, and the United States. They bought a brand called Avenue last year. City Chic Collective already worked with Evans. Evans sold City Chic clothes on its website for five years.

The boss of City Chic Collective, Phil Ryan, said they want to be the best at selling clothes for bigger people.

text: “From modern fashion to casual apparel, intimates and footwear, designing fashion for the curvy woman that fits and flatters, is all we do.”
b2_text: We make clothes. We design clothes for curvy women. We make different kinds of clothes. We make modern fashion clothes. We also make casual clothes. We make underwear and shoes too. Our clothes fit well. They make curvy women look good. That is our only job.

text: Retail sales fell by 3.8% in November on the previous month as the coronavirus lockdown in England and restrictions elsewhere in the UK shut much of the high street. Ending a six-month run of rising sales, the figures revealed the impact of the pandemic on the sector as the infection rate increased across the country. A 19% fall in clothing sales followed the closure of most department stores and non-essential shops. A government message that workers should stay at home if they could caused car journeys to slump and petrol sales to follow suit, with a 16.6% decline. The only bright spot for retailers was an increase in the sale of household goods of 1.6% as shoppers went online to stock up for Christmas. Supermarkets and food stores increased sales by 3.1%. Analysts said it was no surprise the lockdown bolstered online shopping to a record total of 31.4% of all spending, after an increase of almost 75% since November 2019. The Office for National Statistics said 90% of businesses continued to trade in some form through the month, mostly via a click-and-collect service. But only 68.8% of department stores continued trading. Meanwhile, many online retailers reported a boom in sales, as they did during the UK-wide lockdown in spring, though heavy discounting helped to keep the tills ringing. The ONS said this week price-cutting by clothing retailers last month pushed UK inflation down to 0.3%, from 0.7% a month earlier. The Bank of England’s inflation target is 2%. Aled Patchett, the head of retail at Lloyds Bank, said: “November’s sales highlight once again the polarising effect of Covid-19 on retail. Sectors like grocery and homeware perform well – and should be expected to have a strong finish to the year – while others including big-name high street brands fall foul of significantly reduced footfall. “Despite most shoppers having wrapped up their Covid Christmas shopping online this year, shops – particularly in smaller towns – will be hoping that the vaccine rollout inspires greater consumer confidence in the new year as people return to city centres for both work and play.” In October, a 6.4% increase in online sales spurred a 1.2% rise in the total volume of retail spending, mainly driven by shoppers rushing to buy early Christmas presents before the second lockdown in England.
b2_text:
Shops sold less in November. Sales went down by 3.8% compared to the month before. This happened because of the coronavirus lockdown in England. There were also rules in other parts of the UK. These rules closed many shops.

Sales had been going up for six months. But now, the pandemic is affecting shops. More people were getting sick across the country.

Clothes shops sold 19% less than before. This is because most big shops and non-essential shops closed.

The government told people to work from home if they could. Because of this, fewer people used their cars. Petrol sales went down by 16.6%.

But some shops did well. Shops that sell things for the house sold 1.6% more. People were buying things online for Christmas. Supermarkets and food shops sold 3.1% more.

Experts said it was not surprising that online shopping increased. People shopped online a lot because of the lockdown. Online shopping was 31.4% of all spending. This is a record. It has gone up almost 75% since November 2019.

The Office for National Statistics said that most businesses were still open in some way. About 90% of businesses were open. They were mostly using a service where people could order online and pick up their items. But only 68.8% of big shops were still open.

Many online shops sold a lot. This also happened during the lockdown in spring. They had sales to get people to buy things.

The Office for National Statistics said that clothes shops had sales last month. This made prices go down. The UK inflation went down to 0.3%. It was 0.7% the month before. The Bank of England wants inflation to be 2%.

Aled Patchett works at Lloyds Bank. He said that the sales in November show how the coronavirus is affecting shops in different ways. Shops that sell food and things for the house are doing well. They should have a good end to the year. But other shops, like big name shops, are not doing well. This is because fewer people are going to the shops.

Most people bought their Christmas presents online this year because of the coronavirus. Shops hope that the vaccine will make people feel more confident. They hope that people will go back to city centers to work and have fun.

In October, online sales went up by 6.4%. This made total sales go up by 1.2%. This happened because people were buying Christmas presents early. They wanted to buy them before the second lockdown in England.

text: Lee Lucas, the chief executive of the Fashion Retail Academy, which has partnerships with some of Britain’s biggest retailers including Marks & Spencer and Next, said he was not surprised the November lockdown triggered a fall in clothing sales. “November is one the busiest months of the year for retailers, so this emergency measure by the government will have been directly responsible for the unusually high level of discounting currently in stores, with shops fighting for every consumer in the briefest of run-ups to Christmas.”
b2_text:
Lee Lucas is in charge of the Fashion Retail Academy. This school works with big shops like Marks & Spencer and Next. He said he knew that closing shops in November would make clothing sales go down.

November is usually a very busy month for shops. The government made a rule to close shops quickly. This made shops lower their prices a lot. They were trying hard to get people to buy things before Christmas. The time before Christmas was very short. So, shops had to compete for customers.

text: The UK public’s appetite for eating out has plunged to its weakest since the spring amid growing evidence of the impact of the Omicron variant on the hospitality sector during its crucial pre-Christmas period. The number of seated diners fell by 14 percentage points in the week ending 20 December to 88% of the level in the same period of 2019, before the start of the pandemic, according to the weekly digest of flash economic indicators from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). Using data from the online restaurant booking site OpenTable and other sources, the ONS said Britons were eating out less and working from home more in response to rising infection rates and the government’s plan B measures. Amid widespread reports of bookings being cancelled, the drop in the number of diners in the latest week was the sharpest since early September and the lowest level since restaurants reopened indoors in England, Scotland and Wales in May after last winter’s lockdown. It was also the first time the weekly comparison with 2019 has dropped below 100% since May. Restaurants in London have been especially hard hit by Omicron, with the number of diners in the latest week falling 18 points to 57% of the level in the same period of 2019. In Manchester, despite an eight-point drop on the week, the number of diners stood at 104% of the level in the run-up to Christmas 2019. The ONS said the number of firms reporting staff working from home in the latest two weeks had risen by two points to 14%, with a marked impact on businesses reliant on consumers. Transactions at Pret a Manger sandwich outlets were lower in the week ending 16 December than in January 2020 in six of seven urban locations, with London again the most affected city. While trade in regional towns remained above pre-pandemic levels, sales in the capital dropped by 29 points to barely 50% of the January 2020 level. The ONS report showed retailers doing less badly than restaurants, with footfall in the latest week 81% of its 2019 level – a drop of only one percentage point. Credit and debt card payment purchases were up 4% on a year ago. Earlier this week, the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, announced an emergency £1bn package to help businesses struggling with the impact of Omicron.
b2_text:
People in the UK are not eating out as much. This is because of the Omicron virus. It is affecting restaurants and cafes. This is especially true before Christmas.

The number of people eating in restaurants went down. It went down by 14% in one week. This was compared to the same week in 2019. 2019 was before the virus started.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) collects data. They use information from websites like OpenTable. The ONS said people are eating out less. They are also working from home more. This is because there are more virus cases. The government has also asked people to be careful.

Many people are cancelling their restaurant bookings. The drop in diners was the biggest since September. It was the lowest number since restaurants opened again. Restaurants had closed during the winter lockdown. This was in England, Scotland, and Wales. This is also the first time the number of diners is less than in 2019.

Restaurants in London are suffering the most. The number of diners went down a lot. Now, it is only 57% of what it was in 2019. In Manchester, the number of diners is higher than in 2019.

The ONS said more people are working from home. About 14% of companies said their staff are working from home. This is affecting businesses that need customers.

People are buying less from shops like Pret a Manger. In London, sales are much lower than before the virus. Sales in other towns are doing better. But London is affected the most.

Shops are doing better than restaurants. The number of people going to shops is 81% of what it was in 2019. People are using their credit and debit cards more than last year. It is up by 4%.

The government knows businesses are having problems. The Chancellor, Rishi Sunak, has announced money to help them. He will give £1 billion to businesses that are struggling because of Omicron.

text: Meanwhile, analysts are warning that the economy is likely to contract in December even if restrictions in England remain unchanged. Andrew Goodwin, a UK economist at the consultancy firm Oxford Economics, said: “Though the government has opted to defer a decision on introducing further restrictions until after Christmas, it seems likely that a mix of greater consumer caution and reduced mobility will ensure that the UK’s GDP falls in December.”
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text, focusing on simple language and B2 level comprehension:

Experts are looking at the economy. They think it might get smaller in December. This could happen even if England does not change the rules about what people can do.

Andrew Goodwin works for a company called Oxford Economics. He studies the UK economy. He said something important.

He thinks people will be more careful with their money. They may not go out as much. This means the UK's economy, which is called GDP, will likely go down in December.

The government has not decided if they will make new rules before Christmas. But even without new rules, the economy could still get worse. People being careful and not going out much can hurt the economy.

text: Ikea has increased the price of its flat-pack furniture by up to 50%, blaming supply chain costs caused by Covid-19, in a move that will further stoke growing concern about the rising cost of living. After customers complained that prices appeared to have risen sharply after Christmas, the retailer said it was no longer able to absorb increased costs and was passing them on to consumers. An Ikea spokesperson tweeted: “Unfortunately, there has been a significant increase in costs across the supply chain, including in raw materials, transport and logistics. As this is still ongoing, it is necessary to increase prices across many of our products.” Archived versions of Ikea’s website from as recently as October showed significant price increases, including a Malm desk that has gone up from £99 to £150, a jump of more than 50%. A Jokkmokk table with four chairs is also up 50%, from £99 to £149, compared with earlier this year. A Hemnes daybed has gone up from £215 to £279, a 30% rise, while an Alex nine-drawer unit increased 35% from £85 to £115, according to archived versions of the Ikea website from earlier this year. A Kura children’s bed was up by 14% from £129 to £150, while Ikea’s Klippan sofa, one of the Swedish store’s most popular items, is £20 more expensive – a rise of 11% – at £199. Ikea confirmed that the company had raised prices across multiple countries and ranges. A spokesperson said: “Since the start of the pandemic, Ikea has managed to absorb the significant cost increases experienced across the supply chain while keeping prices as low and stable as we possibly can. Now, like many other retailers, we have had to raise our prices to mitigate the impact on our business. “Price increases vary but remain in line with what we are seeing globally at Ikea, which is approximately a 9% average increase across countries and the product range. Affordability remains at the heart of our business, and our focus will always be on continuing to offer quality, sustainable home furnishings at an affordable price for the many people.” Ikea warned earlier this year that prices would rise, citing factors including bottlenecks in shipping raw materials from Asia to Europe.
b2_text:
Ikea has made its furniture more expensive. Some items now cost up to 50% more. This is because of problems with getting materials and shipping them. These problems are linked to Covid-19. This makes people worry about the cost of things going up.

People noticed that prices at Ikea went up a lot after Christmas. Ikea said they could not pay for the extra costs themselves anymore. So, they are making customers pay more.

An Ikea person said that it costs more to get materials. It also costs more to move them around. Because of this, Ikea has to raise prices on many things.

Old versions of the Ikea website show that prices have gone up. For example, a Malm desk used to cost £99. Now it costs £150. That is a big increase.

A Jokkmokk table with four chairs also costs 50% more. It used to be £99, but now it is £149.

A Hemnes bed used to cost £215. Now it costs £279. That is a 30% increase. An Alex drawer unit went from £85 to £115.

A Kura bed for children now costs £150. It used to cost £129. The Klippan sofa is also more expensive. It now costs £199. It used to cost £20 less.

Ikea said that prices have gone up in many countries and on many products. They have tried to keep prices low during the Covid-19 pandemic. But now they have to raise prices. This is to protect their business.

The price increases are different for each item. But on average, prices have gone up about 9% across all countries and products. Ikea says they still want to sell good furniture at prices that people can afford.

Ikea said earlier that prices would probably go up. They said it was hard to get materials from Asia to Europe. This also made things more expensive.

text: The wider furniture industry has suffered significant delays, with the online furniture retailer Made.com saying that up to £45m-worth of orders have been delayed. It blamed a profit warning on factory shutdowns in Vietnam, clogged ports and extended shipping times. Rising prices at Ikea come amid broader concern about the cost of living, after UK inflation hit a 10-year high of 5.1% in November. Soaring energy bills and rising taxes prompted 2022 to be dubbed the “year of the squeeze” by a thinktank report published this week.
b2_text:
The furniture business has problems. Many things are late.

Made.com is a shop that sells furniture online. They said that orders worth 45 million pounds are late. This is because factories in Vietnam closed. Also, the ports are full and ships take a long time. This made them warn that they might not make as much money as they thought.

Ikea is also raising prices. This is happening because things are costing more in general. The cost of living in the UK has gone up a lot. In November, it was the highest it has been in 10 years. It went up by 5.1%.

Energy bills are going up a lot. Taxes are also increasing. A report said that 2022 will be a hard year for people because of these costs. They called it the “year of the squeeze.”

text: The government is to hold emergency meetings with the bosses of the UK’s biggest energy suppliers, after providers warned on Thursday of a “national crisis” that could lead bills to increase by more than 50% to £2,000 a year. Kwasi Kwarteng, the business secretary, is to hold virtual meetings on Monday with energy suppliers, who are pushing the government to intervene to alleviate the unprecedented rises in consumers’ bills caused by soaring wholesale gas prices. The energy industry believes the crisis, during which more than 26 energy suppliers have gone bust at a cost of £1.8bn to date, could be made more manageable if the government axed the 5% VAT on bills imposed when the UK was part of the European Union. Other interventions the industry would like to see considered include extending fuel grants and moving green levies from consumers’ bills into taxation. Trade body Energy UK said on Thursday that consumers could expect their bills to soar by as much as 50% from 1 April. While wholesale prices continue to climb steeply, the UK’s price cap on energy bills stops companies from immediately passing those costs on to their customers. The price cap, set by the industry regulator, Ofgem, has been at a record £1,277 Since 1 October. Ofgem is expected to raise the cap significantly on 1 April. EDF has said the cap could hit £2,000 by next October, when the cap is reviewed again. Analysts at Investec believe the expected bill increase in April would add 1.8 percentage points to inflation next year. On Thursday, the shadow energy minister, Ed Miliband, called on the government to stop families being “clobbered” with the increased cost of heating and powering their homes, by removing VAT on bills for six months. Spain has cut energy taxes, while Germany has slashed green levies on household bills, designed to support the development of renewable energy. But Energy UK said measures like these would save less than £300, significantly less than the expected £600 rise in the average annual bill when the price cap goes up. One plan being formulated by the energy industry to would involve a government-administered loan scheme to spread the impact of the price increases over several years.
b2_text:
The government will have important meetings soon. They will talk to the leaders of the biggest energy companies in the UK. The energy companies said there is a big problem. This problem could make energy bills go up a lot. Bills might increase by more than 50%. This means some people could pay £2,000 each year.

Kwasi Kwarteng is in charge of business. He will talk to the energy companies online on Monday. The companies want the government to help. They want the government to stop the big increase in energy bills for people. The price of gas has gone up a lot. This is why bills are getting more expensive.

Many energy companies have closed. More than 26 companies have closed. This has cost £1.8 billion so far. The energy industry thinks the government could help. They want the government to stop charging VAT on energy bills. VAT is a tax of 5%. The UK had this tax when it was part of the European Union.

The energy industry has other ideas too. They want the government to give people more money to help with bills. They also want the government to pay for "green things" instead of people paying for them on their bills. "Green things" are things that help the environment.

Energy UK is a group that speaks for energy companies. They said that energy bills could go up a lot on April 1st. They could go up by 50%.

The price of gas is still going up. But there is a limit on how much energy companies can charge people. This limit is called a "price cap." The price cap stops companies from charging people too much right away. The price cap is set by Ofgem. Ofgem makes rules for the energy industry. The price cap has been £1,277 since October 1st. Ofgem will probably raise the price cap on April 1st.

EDF is an energy company. They think the price cap could be £2,000 by next October. The price cap is checked again in October.

Some experts think that the higher bills in April will make prices go up in general. This is called inflation. They think inflation will go up by 1.8% next year.

Ed Miliband is a politician. He wants the government to help families. He does not want families to pay much more for heating and electricity. He wants the government to stop charging VAT on energy bills for six months.

Spain has lowered taxes on energy. Germany has lowered the cost of "green things" on people's bills. These "green things" help make clean energy. But Energy UK said these changes would not save people much money. They would save less than £300. The average energy bill is expected to go up by £600.

The energy industry is thinking about a plan. In this plan, the government would give loans to energy companies. This would make the price increases happen slowly over several years.

text: The plan would involve one or more commercial lenders – such as banks – covering the immediate cost of buying energy on wholesale markets at record prices, with a sum of at least £7bn. The loans would not require a government guarantee, but officials would be responsible for ensuring repayments. “We regularly engage with the energy industry and will continue to ensure that consumers are protected through the energy price cap, which is insulating millions from record global gas prices,” a government spokesperson said. “We also continue to support those most in need through our £500mhousehold support fund, the warm home discount and winter fuel payments.”
b2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at a B2 CEFR level:

Energy companies need money. They need to buy energy now. The price of energy is very high.

One idea is for banks to give them loans. These loans would help them buy energy. The amount of money needed is at least £7 billion.

The government would not promise to pay back the loans. But, government workers would make sure the banks get their money back.

A government person said they talk to energy companies often. They want to protect people from high energy prices. There is a limit on how much energy companies can charge. This helps many people.

The government also helps people who need money. They have a fund of £500 million. This fund helps people pay for heating. Some people also get money to help with heating in the winter.

text: On Thursday the treasurer, Josh Frydenberg, gave a mid-year economic update predicting a solid economic bounceback from Covid restrictions. We’ve looked under the hood to see what the treasury’s crystal ball says is in store for the economy, what might go wrong, and how government finances will fare if they’re right. Forecasts The budget papers project the Australian economy will grow in real terms by 3.75% in 2021-22 and 3.5% in 2022-23, before easing back to 2.25% and 2.5% in the final two years of the forward projections. The unemployment rate is tipped to fall to 4.25% in that time. The treasury thinks Australians will be ambitious with their pay demands and bosses generous in a bid to keep workers, because wages growth is supposed to take off from 2.25% in 2021-22 to 3.25% in 2024-25. Inflation is projected to reach and stay at the mid-point of the reserve bank’s target range (2.5%) in 2022-23. Assumptions The treasury has assumed that with more than 80% of Australians aged 16 and above now vaccinated, rates will climb to more than 90%. So far so good. But the rest of the assumptions are … a little rosy. The treasury assumed lockdowns will no longer be required, with “most domestic activity restrictions” lifted by the start of 2022 and only basic density restrictions in place. There may be “temporary strengthening of activity restrictions” to contain localised outbreaks – but these short, sharp lockdown-like restrictions are assumed to have no material impact on the outlook. Remaining state border restrictions are assumed to be lifted by early 2022 and the Omicron variant “is not assumed to significantly alter current reopening plans or require a reimposition of widespread health and activity restrictions”. Migrants will start returning from 2022, with international students ready to go for the first semester of next year. What could go wrong In a word: Covid. If a new variant of concern emerges (beyond Omicron) requiring more significant health responses, the international border could be closed for another six months and public health orders and precautionary behaviour could drive down spending.
b2_text:
On Thursday, Josh Frydenberg spoke about the economy. He is the treasurer. He said the economy will get better after the Covid rules.

We looked at what the government thinks about the economy. We wanted to know what could happen. We also wanted to know if the government's plans will work.

The government thinks the economy will grow. It will grow by 3.75% this year. Next year, it will grow by 3.5%. After that, it will grow slower. In the last two years, it will grow by 2.25% and 2.5%.

The government thinks the unemployment rate will go down. It will go down to 4.25%.

The government also thinks people will want more money. Bosses will give them more money to keep them working. Wages will grow from 2.25% to 3.25% in a few years.

The government thinks prices will go up. This is called inflation. It will reach 2.5% in 2022-23. This is the middle of what the Reserve Bank wants.

The government is making some guesses. They think that most people will get vaccinated. More than 80% of people over 16 have already had the vaccine. The government thinks it will go up to 90%. This is good so far.

But other guesses might not be right. The government thinks there will be no more lockdowns. They think most rules will be gone by the start of 2022. There might be some small rules about how many people can be in a place.

They think there might be some short lockdowns if there are small outbreaks. But they think these lockdowns will not hurt the economy much.

The government thinks state borders will open soon. They also think the Omicron virus will not change the plans to open up. They don't think it will make them put rules back in place.

The government thinks people will start coming to Australia again in 2022. International students will be ready to come to school next year.

What could go wrong? The biggest problem is Covid. If a new virus comes, it could be bad. The borders might close again for six months. People might be scared and not spend money.

text: The treasury projects this could mean 1% is shaved off gross domestic product in 2021-22, and unemployment is about 1% higher. The rebound would instead come in the second half of 2022. The papers also note that revenue assumptions and nominal GDP are also sensitive to changes in the iron ore price, with a US$10 fall shaving $3.9bn off GDP this year and $0.9bn off tax receipts next financial year. If the government has to pay higher interest rates on bonds, then debt could blow out by a further 5.4% of GDP by 2032. $16bn of mystery spending The budget papers reveal that there is about $16bn of mystery spending over the next four years, consisting of decisions taken but not announced, or measures for which the cost is not-for-publication. That’s more than 10 times the size of mystery spending last year. The papers make it impossible to calculate the size of the war chest for announcements to be made before the election, by mixing in a bunch of commercially sensitive spending items like vaccine purchases. But a treasury official in the lockup suggested it was about half and half … so, an $8bn war chest for the election. There will also be $940m more revenue collected due to decisions taken but not announced or not for publication measures. Debt and deficit For a government previously concerned with the debt and deficit disaster, there is still red as far as the eye can see. The deficit is tipped to be $99.2bn in 2021-22, an improvement of $7.4bn since the budget despite the Delta lockdowns. The deficit will still be $57.5bn in 2024-25 (or 2.3% of GDP), and only shrinks to 1.8% of GDP in 2031-32. Net debt is projected to be 30.6% of GDP at June 2022, rising to a peak of 37.4% in 2025, then down to 35.5% in 2032. The papers say that despite the economic recovery the government is sticking with the first plank of its budget plan – strong and sustained recovery – so don’t expect austerity measures to try to cut the debt and deficit.
b2_text:
Okay, here's a B2 level rewrite of the text, following your instructions:

The government thinks things might not be so good. The economy might grow less. They think the economy could grow 1% less than expected in 2021 and 2022. Also, more people might lose their jobs. About 1% more people could be unemployed. The economy might get better again in the second half of 2022.

The government also makes money from iron ore. If the price of iron ore goes down, the government will have less money. If the price goes down by $10, the economy will lose $3.9 billion this year. Next year, the government will get $0.9 billion less in taxes.

The government borrows money by selling bonds. If the government has to pay more interest on these bonds, the country's debt could get much bigger. The debt could increase by 5.4% of the total economy by 2032.

The budget papers show some spending that is not explained. There is $16 billion of spending that is secret. This money is for things the government has decided to do, but they have not told anyone yet. Or, they do not want to say how much these things cost. This secret spending is much bigger than last year. It is more than ten times bigger.

It is hard to know how much money the government has for announcements before the election. This is because they have mixed secret spending with things that are private. For example, they are buying vaccines. However, someone from the government said that about half of the $16 billion is for the election. So, they might have $8 billion to spend before the election.

The government will also get more money. They will get $940 million more because of decisions they have made. But they have not told anyone about these decisions.

The government used to worry a lot about debt. But now, the country is still losing money. The government will lose $99.2 billion in 2021 and 2022. This is better than they thought, because of the Delta lockdowns. In 2024 and 2025, the government will still lose $57.5 billion. This is 2.3% of the total economy. In 2031 and 2032, they will still be losing 1.8% of the total economy.

The country's debt is also going up. It will be 30.6% of the total economy in June 2022. It will go up to 37.4% in 2025. Then, it will go down to 35.5% in 2032.

The government says the economy is getting better. But they will still follow their plan to help the economy grow. So, they will not cut spending to reduce the debt.

text: Britons are many times more likely to have experienced shortages of food and fuel than people in half a dozen EU member states, according to a poll. Global supply chain problems prompted by the pandemic have disrupted the international trade network since the summer, with transport backlogs combining with labour shortages to create scarcities of various goods around the world. The government has argued that the shortages are part of a worldwide pattern and no worse in the UK than elsewhere, although logistics experts and other professionals – particularly in the food sector - have said the problems are amplified in Britain by a shortage of east European workers, including drivers, since Brexit. The YouGov poll showed residents of the UK were multiple times more likely to have experienced, or to know people who have experienced, shortages of food and fuel than people in France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Sweden and Denmark, and somewhat more likely to have experienced them than those in the US. Asked in early December whether they had personally experienced any scarcity of foodstuffs in recent weeks, 56% of respondents in the UK said yes, while 9% said they had not personally experienced any but knew people who had. The corresponding figures in the US were 49% and 10%, but in continental Europe, the proportion of people who said they had been personally affected was between three and nine times lower: 18% in Germany, 16% in France, 12% in Sweden, 8% in Denmark, 7% and 6% in Italy. The proportion saying they knew people who had experienced food shortages ranged from 13% in France to 8% in Denmark and Italy – where 58% of respondents said they were not even aware that supply chain problems had led to food shortages. The UK was also the only country where substantial numbers of people said they had experienced fuel shortages in recent weeks, since the crisis in September and October. One in three Britons (33%) said they had personally experienced a recent scarcity of fuel, compared with no more than 10% in any other country. Only 8% of German respondents, 7% of those in France and 5% of those in Italy said they had been personally experienced fuel scarcity, with 37%, 38% and 53% respectively saying they had not even heard of the issue – compared with just 11% of respondents in Britain.
b2_text:
A survey showed that people in the UK had more problems getting food and fuel. This was compared to people in some countries in Europe.

The COVID-19 pandemic caused problems with global trade. It was hard to move goods around the world. There were not enough workers, and things were delayed. This caused a shortage of some things.

The UK government said that other countries also had these shortages. But some experts said the UK had more problems. They said that after Brexit, there were not enough workers from Eastern Europe, like drivers.

The survey asked people if they had problems getting food and fuel. Many more people in the UK said yes, compared to people in France, Germany, Spain, Italy, Sweden and Denmark. More people in the UK also had problems compared to people in the US.

In the UK, 56% of people said they had trouble getting food. Another 9% said they did not, but they knew people who did.

In the US, 49% of people had problems, and 10% knew people who did.

But in Europe, fewer people had problems. Only 18% in Germany, 16% in France, 12% in Sweden, 8% in Denmark, 7% in Spain, and 6% in Italy had problems getting food.

Some people in Europe did not even know there was a problem. For example, 58% of people in Italy did not know about food shortages.

The UK also had problems with fuel. One in three people in the UK (33%) said they had trouble getting fuel. This happened after problems in September and October.

In other countries, much fewer people had problems. Only 8% in Germany, 7% in France, and 5% in Italy had trouble getting fuel. Many people in these countries did not even know about the fuel problem. 37% in Germany, 38% in France and 53% in Italy did not know about it. Only 11% of people in the UK did not know about the fuel problem.

text: Just Eat has entered the fast grocery delivery market by partnering with Asda in its first tie-up with a supermarket in the UK. From January, Just Eat customers will be able to add a range of products to their baskets starting with five Asda stores, with the exact locations to be announced in the new year. “We live in an on-demand world,” said Andrew Kenny, the UK managing director of Just Eat. “We want to make sure we are getting our customers the food they want, when they want, when they want it. Our tie-up with Asda means we can help people access everything from store cupboard essentials to fresh groceries in a matter of minutes.” Just Eat follows rivals Deliveroo and Uber Eats, which already have fast delivery deals with some of the UK’s biggest supermarkets. Best-known for restaurant and fast food delivery, Just Eat said that up to 1,000 grocery items would be made available for customers to order seven days a week. The two companies anticipate the partnership to be extended to more Asda stores throughout next year. The partnership builds on an existing relationship, with Just Eat delivering pizzas and meal deals from Asda Kitchen, the grocer’s indoor cafe and diner, which operates at 42 locations nationwide. “We’re always looking for new ways to offer customers more choice and extend the number of delivery options available,” said Simon Gregg, the vice-president of online grocery at Asda. “The trial will also see Asda become more accessible to a wider customer base through Just Eat’s significant presence in the on-demand food delivery space.” Just Eat has more than 60,000 restaurant partners it offers a delivery service for, covering 95% of the UK. The food delivery service has more than 10,000 grocery and convenience store partners on its platform internationally, including brands such as Spar, Shell and 7-Eleven. Last month, Asda appointed Stuart Rose, the Conservative peer and former boss of Marks & Spencer, as chairman.
b2_text:
Just Eat will now deliver groceries. They are working with Asda, a big supermarket in the UK. This is the first time Just Eat has worked with a supermarket in the UK.

Starting in January, people can buy food from Asda on the Just Eat app. At first, only five Asda stores will be part of this. We will know which stores later.

Andrew Kenny works for Just Eat. He said people want things quickly. He wants Just Eat to give people the food they want, when they want it. Working with Asda means people can get food and other things from the store very fast.

Other companies like Deliveroo and Uber Eats already deliver groceries from supermarkets. Just Eat is now doing the same.

Just Eat is known for delivering food from restaurants. Now, they will also deliver up to 1,000 grocery items. People can order these items every day of the week.

Just Eat and Asda think they will add more Asda stores to the app later.

Just Eat already delivers food from Asda Kitchen. Asda Kitchen is a cafe inside some Asda stores. There are 42 Asda Kitchens in the UK.

Simon Gregg works for Asda. He said Asda wants to give customers more choices. This new delivery service will help more people buy from Asda. Just Eat delivers to many people.

Just Eat works with over 60,000 restaurants in the UK. They deliver to most of the country. Just Eat also works with many grocery stores in other countries, like Spar, Shell, and 7-Eleven.

Recently, Asda chose Stuart Rose to be their chairman. He used to work for another store called Marks & Spencer.

text: European markets have taken something of a fright before Christmas on Monday thanks to concerns about new restrictions to tackle the omicron variant - and Wall Street has followed their lead. Here are the opening snaps from the three main US benchmark stock indices: S&P 500 DOWN 59.17 POINTS, OR 1.28%, AT 4,561.47 NASDAQ DOWN 227.60 POINTS, OR 1.50%, AT 14,942.08 DOW JONES DOWN 455.76 POINTS, OR 1.29%, AT 34,909.68 The mood has improved somewhat over the course of the day, however. The FTSE 100 has fallen by 0.9% to just over 7,200 points - but that is an improvement over the first few hours of trading. The pound has recovered against the US dollar - it is almost flat for the day at about $1.3235. Here are some of the other notable business events from today: Rolls-Royce won the backing of Qatar for small modular nuclear reactors. A $10bn spreadsheet error was among the reasons for a £47m Standard Chartered fine. Ex-Tesco boss Sir Dave Lewis was appointed to lead GSK’s consumer products spinout, which is expected to become one of the FTSE 100’s biggest companies. UK pubs and restaurants have warned of plummeting sales and “decimated” bookings. Data showed UK high streets have also suffered markedly, with falling sales in what should have been their most profitable weekend. The annual shindig for corporate types at Davos has been postponed for the second year in a row. Cruise ship company Carnival has said it will be back to 2019 earnings before various costs by 2023 - but that the first half of 2022 could result in another loss. You can continue to follow the Guardian’s coverage from around the world on our homepage and via our live blogs: In the UK, Boris Johnson and ministers are meeting to consider further coronavirus restrictions for England In our global coronavirus coverage, Thailand is considering ending quarantine-free travel, and the EU is set to back the Novavax vaccine The bounce on European stock markets has run out, it seems.
b2_text:
On Monday, European markets were worried. This was because of new rules to stop the Omicron virus. Wall Street in the US also became worried.

Here is how the US stock markets started:

*   S&P 500 went down by 59.17 points, or 1.28%, to 4,561.47.
*   NASDAQ went down by 227.60 points, or 1.50%, to 14,942.08.
*   DOW JONES went down by 455.76 points, or 1.29%, to 34,909.68.

Later in the day, things got a little better.

The FTSE 100 in London went down by 0.9%. It is now a little over 7,200 points. But this is better than earlier in the day.

The British pound went up a little against the US dollar. It is almost the same as yesterday, at about $1.3235.

Here are some other important business news items:

*   Rolls-Royce got money from Qatar to build small nuclear power plants.
*   Standard Chartered bank had to pay a fine of £47 million. One reason was a mistake in a spreadsheet that was worth $10 billion.
*   The old boss of Tesco, Dave Lewis, will now lead a new company that makes products for GSK. This new company is expected to be very big.
*   Pubs and restaurants in the UK said that their sales are going down a lot. They said that many people have cancelled their bookings.
*   Shops in the UK also did not sell as much as they hoped. Sales went down during what should have been their best weekend.
*   The meeting in Davos for business people has been cancelled again. This is the second year in a row.
*   The cruise ship company Carnival thinks they will make as much money as in 2019 by 2023. But they might lose money in the first half of 2022.

You can read more news from the Guardian newspaper on their website.

*   In the UK, the government is thinking about new rules to stop the virus.
*   In Thailand, the government may stop letting people travel without staying in quarantine. In Europe, the EU may approve a new vaccine called Novavax.

It seems like the good news for European stock markets is over.

text: The FTSE 100 is wavering around a 1.1% decline for the day - perhaps it is waiting for direction from the UK cabinet, which is about to meet. However, any leaks (or indeed official messages) are likely to come very near the end of the trading day, if not after. The Dax in Germany is down by 1.8% and France’s Cac 40 has lost 1.1%. The Stoxx 600, which combines all of the above and more, is down by 1.5%. Britain’s largest pub chain JD Wetherspoon has appointed two employees to its board in response to criticisms of its corporate governance. Four out of about 100 managers of Spoons pubs were chosen after shareholders and employees said it would “benefit from having more pub experience at board level”, the company said on Monday. Debbie Whittingham, a regional manager for the West Midlands, and Hudson Simmons, area manager for Sheffield, will join the board, while another two will be “associate employee directors”. Tim Martin, Wetherspoon’s founder and chairman, has previously lashed out at those who have criticised the company’s corporate governance in lengthy letters published on the stock market’s news service. However, he said: Pub and area managers, and other members of pub teams, have always participated in weekly decision-making meetings, which distil suggestions from the ‘front line’. The appointment of employee directors will extend this approach to board meetings and will help to preserve the culture of the company for the future. It was cautiously welcomed by the High Pay Centre, a thinktank focused on pay, corporate governance. Luke Hildyard, the High Pay Centre’s executive director, said: The perspectives workers directors can offer in terms of improvements to customer service and employee relations are obvious. The new Wetherspoons directors would have more credibility and independence if they’d been elected by colleagues rather than appointed by existing board members and it should also be remembered that boardroom representation is a complement not a substitute for full trade union rights and recognition. But this is a positive step by Wetherspoons that will benefit both workers and shareholders in the long term. One to watch on the UK politics front: the prime minister has called a cabinet meeting at 2pm.
b2_text:
The FTSE 100 is going down. It has lost about 1.1% today. Maybe it is waiting to see what the UK government will do. The government leaders will meet soon. But we might not know what they decide until the end of the day.

The Dax in Germany is also down. It has lost 1.8%. The Cac 40 in France is down too. It has lost 1.1%. The Stoxx 600 is a group of many companies. It is down by 1.5%.

A big pub company in Britain is called JD Wetherspoon. People said the company needed to be run better. So, Wetherspoon has added two workers to its board. The board is a group of people who make important decisions.

Some people who own shares in the company asked for this change. They thought the board needed people with more experience working in pubs.

Two managers from Wetherspoon pubs will join the board. One is Debbie Whittingham. She is a manager in the West Midlands. The other is Hudson Simmons. He is a manager in Sheffield. Two other workers will also help the board.

Tim Martin is the boss of Wetherspoon. He did not like it when people said the company was not run well. He wrote long letters about it. But now he says that the workers will help. They will share ideas from their work in the pubs. This will help the company in the future.

A group called the High Pay Centre studies how companies are run. They think this is a good idea. Luke Hildyard works there. He says that workers on the board can help make the company better. They can improve customer service and how the company treats workers.

But he thinks the workers should be chosen by other workers. He also says that workers should have the right to join a union. But he still thinks this is a good step for Wetherspoon. It will help the workers and the people who own shares in the company.

In UK politics, the Prime Minister will meet with the government at 2pm. It is something to watch.

text: As Andrew Sparrow points out on the Guardian’s UK politics live blog, there is not usually a cabinet meeting on a Monday, so this is an emergency coronavirus meeting. Dress codes and wine pairings have not yet been released. You can follow updates on the cabinet here: One for the central bank watchers: Germany’s new government has picked a new head of its central bank: “career central banker” Joachim Nagel. Nagel’s predecessor, Jens Weidmann, was perhaps the European Central Bank’s most prominent internal critic -arguing against the stimulus that it has used to prop up the EU economy. (All eurozone central bank heads get a place on the governing council, which sets monetary policy for the bloc.) Nagel, a former Bundesbank board member, will take over on 1 January. Reuters summarised his recent career as: A former board member of the state-owned development bank KfW Bank, Nagel currently works for the Bank for International Settlements, which is often considered the central bank of central banks. Early in his career, he was also a consultant for the SPD, the party that took over government earlier this month and will make the Bundesbank appointment one of its first decisions. Germany’s finance minister under the new coalition government, Christian Lindner, said on Monday: In view of inflation risks, the importance of a stability-oriented monetary policy is growing. He is an experienced personality who ensures continuity at the Bundesbank. The World Economic Forum at Davos has been postponed to the summer because of concerns about the coronavirus variant, it said on Monday. The event, usually held every year at the Swiss ski resort, was scheduled for 17 to 21 January 2022, but will instead happen in “early summer”. In January the World Economic Forum will instead run online meetings. Davos usually serves as an occasion for many of the world’s most powerful people from the realms of business, economics and politics to gather and pontificate about the world’s problems. However, the meeting of thousands of people from all over the world has been difficult to continue during pandemic conditions. The 2021 event was cancelled in favour of online events in the summer.
b2_text:
Here are the news updates.

Andrew Sparrow wrote on the Guardian's blog. He said there is a special meeting today. It is about the coronavirus. Usually, the cabinet does not meet on Mondays. We do not know what people will wear or drink at the meeting yet. You can find updates about the cabinet online.

Germany has a new leader for its central bank. His name is Joachim Nagel. He has worked at central banks for a long time. The old leader was Jens Weidmann. He did not agree with the European Central Bank very often. He did not like the plan to help the EU economy. Each country in the Eurozone has a leader on the group that decides money rules. Nagel used to work for the Bundesbank. He will start his new job on January 1st.

Reuters news said that Nagel used to work for KfW Bank. Now, he works for the Bank for International Settlements. This bank is for other central banks. Early in his career, he helped the SPD party. This party is now in power. They will choose the new Bundesbank leader. This is one of their first decisions.

Christian Lindner is Germany's finance minister. He said that it is important to keep money stable because of inflation. He said Nagel is experienced and will keep the Bundesbank steady.

The World Economic Forum in Davos will not happen in January. It is now planned for the summer. This is because people are worried about the coronavirus. The meeting was supposed to be from January 17th to 21st, 2022. Now, it will be in "early summer".

In January, the World Economic Forum will have online meetings instead. Usually, important people meet in Davos. They talk about problems in the world. These people are from business, economics, and politics. But it is hard to have this meeting with so many people during the pandemic. The 2021 event was cancelled. They had online meetings in the summer instead.

text: In a statement, the event’s organisers said: Current pandemic conditions make it extremely difficult to deliver a global in-person meeting. Despite the meeting’s stringent health protocols, the transmissibility of Omicron and its impact on travel and mobility have made deferral necessary. The number of shoppers across British high streets fell over the weekend before Christmas, according to new data from Springboard that show people spurned city centre shopping during what should have been the biggest weekend of the year. Retail footfall was 19% down for the week ending on Saturday compared to the equivalent in 2019, Springboard said - although it was higher than December 2020, when the UK government dramatically u-turned to put in place a Christmas lockdown. Shopping centres fared particularly badly, with footfall down by 27% on 2019, but high streets were also down by a fifth on 2019. Retail parks, which are generally accessed by private car and are often open-air, performed slightly better. Weekend traffic overall fell compared to the previous weekend by 8.5% in Central London and by 6.4% in cities outside of the capital. Diane Wehrle, insights director at Springboard, said: The nervousness of shoppers about making in-person shopping visits inevitably meant that large city centres lost out to smaller high streets, particularly over the weekend when footfall declined from the week before in Central London and large cities outside of the capital whilst rising in market towns. There has been a bit of movement on currency markets as well this morning: sterling is down by 0.4% against the US dollar. One pound will buy $1.3195. That in itself is not a huge move, but it puts the pound perilously close to its lowest level since December 2020, when the UK was facing the prospect of belated Christmas restrictions in the hope of limiting the spread of a new coronavirus variant (a familiar tale). If it drops below $1.3165 it will mark a new low for 2021, an unusual situation considering the Bank of England only just last week shocked markets with an interest rate rise - pre-empting the Federal Reserve. However, the Fed has itself also made it clear that it will tighten the US money supply. The prospect of a series of interest rate rises next year has made the dollar more attractive to investors.
b2_text:
The people who planned an event said something. They said it is hard to have a meeting where people come together from all over the world. This is because of the virus.

They had rules to keep people healthy at the meeting. But the virus spreads easily. It also makes it hard for people to travel. So, they had to move the meeting to a later time.

Many stores are in areas called "high streets" in Britain. A company called Springboard has new information. It shows that fewer people went to these stores before Christmas. The weekend before Christmas should be the busiest time for shopping. But people did not go to the city centers to shop.

Springboard said that the number of shoppers was lower than in 2019. It was 19% lower for the week that ended on Saturday. But it was higher than in December 2020. At that time, the government changed its mind and made rules for a Christmas lockdown.

Shopping centers did not do well. The number of shoppers was 27% lower than in 2019. High streets also had fewer shoppers. They were down by 20% compared to 2019.

Retail parks did a little better. People usually drive to these parks in their own cars. These parks are often outside.

The number of cars on the road was lower than the week before. It was down by 8.5% in the center of London. It was down by 6.4% in other cities in Britain.

Diane Wehrle works for Springboard. She said that people were worried about shopping in person. This means that big city centers lost shoppers to smaller high streets. On the weekend, fewer people went to shop in central London and big cities. But more people went to market towns.

The value of money has changed a little. The British pound is worth less than before compared to the American dollar. It is down by 0.4%.

One pound can buy $1.3195. This is not a big change. But the pound is close to being worth the least it has been since December 2020. At that time, Britain might have had new Christmas rules. This was to stop a new type of the virus from spreading.

If the pound goes below $1.3165, it will be worth the least it has been in 2021. This is strange because the Bank of England surprised everyone last week. They raised the interest rate. This was before the American Federal Reserve did.

The Federal Reserve has also said that it will make less money available. They might raise interest rates next year. This makes the American dollar more attractive to people who invest money.

text: Mark Haefele, chief investment officer at UBS Global Wealth Management, said the dollar will be, pace the omicron variant, one of the “winners from global growth” during 2022. There has also been a similar bounce on oil markets. The price of Brent crude, the North Sea benchmark, is still down by 3.3% today - but that is a recovery from earlier. Brent crude futures were down by as much as 5% earlier this morning, with one barrel for February delivery going for as little as $69. It is now back at $71.30. Victoria Scholar, head of investment at interactive investor, an investing platform, said: Heavy selling has hit the oil markets again this week with WTI and Brent crude both shedding more than 3% extending losses after a week in the red with Brent already ending down 2.6% as the Omicron variant continues to spread, weighing on the demand outlook and market sentiment. The Netherlands’ latest lockdown from Sunday sparked investor concerns of fresh restrictions in Europe and the US to curb the spread of Covid, prompting fears of a near-term economic slowdown. Brent crude has shed more than 17% from the October high, trading in a descending trendline and retracing around 70% of its prior gains from the August trough. Kit Juckes, a strategist at Société Générale, a bank, is in a festive mood - albeit the wrong feast. “It’s a lot more like Halloween than Christmas,” he said: Oil prices, equity indices and bond yields are lower on a mix of omicron concerns and Senator Joe Manchin’s announcement that he won’t vote for President Biden’s spending bill. Just over half an hour after the FTSE 100 slumped further, it has just regained a percentage point. It is now down by just 1.3% at 7,179 points, having earlier dropped by as much as 2.2%. European stocks have also recovered somewhat: Germany’s Dax is now down by 2.2% and France’s Cac 40 is down 1.4%. All the usual disclaimers apply at this point in the year: a fair few investors will have shut up shop for the holidays, and few of those who remain will have planned any major moves in the absence of central bank activity.
b2_text:
Mark Haefele works for UBS. He helps people invest money. He said the dollar will do well in 2022. This is because the world economy will grow. It will be good even if the Omicron virus spreads.

Oil prices have also changed a lot. The price of Brent crude oil went down. Brent crude is oil from the North Sea. Today, its price is down by 3.3%. But it was lower earlier.

This morning, the price was down by 5%. One barrel of oil for February cost $69. Now it costs $71.30.

Victoria Scholar works for a company called interactive investor. This company helps people invest. She said many people are selling oil this week. The prices of WTI and Brent crude have gone down a lot. They went down last week too. This is because the Omicron virus is spreading. People think it will make the demand for oil lower. They also feel worried about the economy.

The Netherlands started a new lockdown on Sunday. This made investors worry. They think other countries in Europe and the US might also have new rules. This could stop the economy from growing quickly. The price of Brent crude has gone down a lot since October.

Kit Juckes works for a bank called Société Générale. He said things feel bad, like Halloween. He said oil prices are lower. Stock prices are also lower. Bond yields are lower too. This is because people are worried about the Omicron virus. Also, a Senator named Joe Manchin said he will not vote for President Biden's spending plan.

The FTSE 100 is a list of big companies. It went down a lot earlier. Now it has gone up a little. It is now down by 1.3% at 7,179 points. Before, it was down by 2.2%.

European stocks have also gone up a little. Germany's Dax is now down by 2.2%. France's Cac 40 is down by 1.4%.

Many investors are not working now. They are on holiday. The people who are working are not making big changes. They are waiting to see what the central banks will do.

text: That means that there will be lower liquidity and fewer buyers to soak up any sales, so moves can be exaggerated. Nevertheless, that is a notable swing over the course of less than an hour. It may have been partly helped by vaccine maker Moderna. It said on Monday (in an interview published at 10am GMT) that a booster dose of its Covid-19 vaccine appeared to offer protection against the omicron variant. Reuters reported: The vaccine maker said the decision to focus on the current vaccine, mRNA-1273, was driven in part by how quickly the recently discovered variant is spreading. The company still plans to develop a vaccine specifically to protect against Omicron, which it hopes to advance into clinical trials early next year. “What we have available right now is 1273,” Dr. Paul Burton, Moderna’s Chief Medical Officer, said in an interview. “It’s highly effective, and it’s extremely safe.
