I think it will protect people through the coming holiday period and through these winter months, when we’re going to see the most severe pressure of Omicron.” Some detail on how the UK’s shops fared over the last week - usually one of the the strongest of the year: it was not great. Footfall on and near London’s Oxford Street, the country’s biggest shopping district, was 17% below pre-pandemic levels, according to the New West End Company, which represents about 600 shops. Shopping was 5% below the previous weekend, and across the entire week of the 13th December footfall was down by 29% compared with 2019’s figures. Jace Tyrrell, chief executive of the New West End Company, said businesses were “disappointed” with how the weekend went: With less than five days to go until Christmas day and the probabilities of a circuit-breaker lockdown increasingly on the horizon, the retail and leisure sector is now facing a huge amount of financial uncertainty when it should be enjoying a much needed shot in the arm. We are therefore backing the #BusinessBooster campaign and calling on the government to provide urgent and swift financial support. Temporary measures such as a 100% business rate relief for the first quarter of the year, extension of the VAT reduction and introduction of grants could be the difference between viable businesses avoiding closures and job losses in the new year.
b2_text:
It means there will be less money available in the market. Also, fewer people will want to buy things. This can make price changes bigger and faster.

However, the price change we saw was still important. It happened in less than one hour.

The company Moderna might have helped cause this change. Moderna makes vaccines. On Monday, they said something important. They said that a booster shot of their COVID-19 vaccine seemed to protect against the Omicron virus. This information was in an interview published at 10 am GMT.

Reuters reported on this. They said Moderna decided to focus on their current vaccine, mRNA-1273. This is because the Omicron virus is spreading so fast.

Moderna still plans to make a new vaccine. This new vaccine will protect specifically against Omicron. They hope to start testing it early next year.

Dr. Paul Burton works for Moderna. He is the Chief Medical Officer. He said the current vaccine, 1273, is very good. He said it works well and is very safe. He thinks it will protect people during the holidays. He also thinks it will help during the winter months. Omicron will be a big problem then.

Here is some news about shops in the UK. We will look at how they did last week. Usually, this is one of the best weeks of the year for shops. But this year, it was not good.

Oxford Street is in London. It is the biggest shopping area in the country. The number of people visiting shops there was down by 17%. This is compared to before the virus. This information comes from the New West End Company. They represent about 600 shops.

Shopping was also down 5% compared to the weekend before. For the whole week of December 13th, the number of people shopping was down 29%. This is compared to the same time in 2019.

Jace Tyrrell is the chief executive of the New West End Company. He said that businesses were "disappointed" with the weekend.

Christmas is coming soon. There is a chance the government will close businesses again. This makes things very uncertain for shops and businesses. They need money now. They should be making money at this time of year.

That is why they support the #BusinessBooster campaign. They are asking the government to give them money quickly.

The government could do some things to help. They could stop businesses from paying some taxes for a few months. They could also give them grants. This could help businesses stay open and keep people from losing their jobs next year.

text: The FTSE 100 sell-off has accelerated - it is now down by 2.2%. It has hit the lowest level since the start of December as concern over the spread of the omicron variant ramp up. While the UK government is fielding a lot of questions about parties, the hospitality industry is trying to put the pressure on over the lack of them, given how the current lockdown-lite has affected their bookings. The Guardian’s Joanna Partridge writes: Pubs and restaurants have warned of plummeting sales and “decimated” bookings, as pressure increases on the government to offer urgent financial support to struggling hospitality businesses. The weekend just passed should have been the busiest trading period of the Christmas season, but customers chose to stay away, said Nick Mackenzie, the chief executive of the pub and brewery chain Greene King, which runs 2,700 pubs, restaurants and hotels across the UK. “Demand has dropped, bookings have been decimated, some parts of the country we are 70%, 80% down on 2019, so the situation is pretty unsustainable,” Mackenzie told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme on Monday. Warnings from the government had led to “lockdown in all but name”, Mackenzie said, and he urged the chancellor, Rishi Sunak, to deliver “quick and effective support”. You can read the full report here: Some interesting detail from the notice detailing the reasons for the errors Standard Chartered made. One key reporting problem was caused by a spreadsheet error in which a workers put the wrong sign - so it read as positive rather than negative. Sure, we all make that kind of mistake, except in this case the error meant the calculation was out by a staggering $10bn. That sounds like a very bad day at the office indeed. Standard Chartered will have to pay £46.5m after it failed to cooperate with regulators at the Bank of England. It was a record fine imposed by the Bank’s Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA), which is tasked with overseeing the UK banking sector’s financial stability. The fines came in relation to reporting errors related to movements of US dollars, amid concerns in October 2017 about the outflow of cash.
b2_text:
The FTSE 100 is going down fast. It is now down by 2.2%. This is the lowest it has been since December. People are worried about the Omicron virus spreading.

The UK government is answering questions about parties. At the same time, the hospitality industry is worried. They are not getting many customers. This is because of the current rules, which are like a mild lockdown.

Joanna Partridge from The Guardian writes about this. Pubs and restaurants say their sales are going down a lot. Many people are cancelling their bookings. They want the government to give them money to help.

Last weekend should have been the busiest time for them. It is usually the Christmas season. But people stayed home instead. Nick Mackenzie is in charge of Greene King. This company owns many pubs, restaurants, and hotels in the UK. He said that business is very bad.

Mr. Mackenzie said that fewer people are coming. Many bookings have been cancelled. In some places, business is down 70% or 80% compared to 2019. This is not sustainable.

Mr. Mackenzie said the government's warnings made it like a lockdown. He wants Rishi Sunak, the Chancellor, to give them help quickly.

Standard Chartered bank made some mistakes. One mistake was in a computer spreadsheet. A worker put the wrong sign in a calculation. It should have been negative, but it was positive.

We all make mistakes. But this mistake made a big difference. The calculation was wrong by $10 billion. This was a very bad mistake for the bank.

Standard Chartered must pay £46.5 million. They did not help the people at the Bank of England who check on banks. This fine was the biggest ever given by the Bank’s Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA). The PRA watches over the banks in the UK to make sure they are safe.

The fines are because of mistakes in reporting. The bank made mistakes about moving US dollars. In 2017, people were worried about money leaving the bank.
